Ottawa, December 2, 1947.

Sister Carmen, Principal, Fort William Indian Residential School, Fort William, Ontario

On reviewing the September Quarter No. 411, the admission and discharge form of the Fort William Indian Residential School, it is noted that the usual application forms for the new pupils are still to be submitted. We would appreciate receiving these at your earliest convenience.

The discharge of pupils numbered hereunder is approved:

No. 0432
0343
0366
0375

No. 0404
0428
323
420

No. 422.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

PORT ARTHUR, Ontario Sept.18/47.

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into the Fort William Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: ANDREW BOUCHARD.
English name: ANDREW BOUCHARD.
Age: 8
Name of Band:
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid: ?
Father's full name and No.: ?
Mother's full name and No.: Ludy Lexie (Foster Mother - Virginia Bouchard).
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good--Yes
Religion: RO.
Does applicant speak English?: YES
Previously attended: No. school for years

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

Date Sept. 10 Time of day 3pm

J. L. Currie M.D.
Fort Arthur, Ontario,
29th October, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Quarterly Report
Fort William Indian Residential School

The above report was forwarded to you about a week ago, having been received somewhat late from the Principal of the school. The late receipt of this report is understandable, however, for the report for the period ending 30th September is quite an involved one to compile. It is anticipated that future quarterly reports will be received more promptly, for we have made your desires known to the Principal, to have such reports received early.

Unfortunately, in the present instance, the report went forward without being made subject to check at this agency, as well as omitting the required attachments.

It would be appreciated, therefore, if you would return the report in question to this office for our further action and it will be immediately returned to you.

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.
Port Arthur, Ontario,
6th December, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan

Sister Carmen, principal of the Residential School, Fort William, has forwarded to this office your letter of Dec. 2, file 9-11-10 (WT), re the September report.

In this regard, I wish to refer you to my letter of October 29th, copy of which is attached herewith.

I am also enclosing herewith the application forms for the new pupils, as requested.

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, December 22, 1947.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Superintendent of Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of December 6th, we are attaching hereto, for your file, a copy of form # 411 of the Fort William Residential School.

To complete our files, application form for Christie Pervais and Andrew Bouchard are still required.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Fort Arthur, Ontario,
12th January, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.
Att.: Mr. P. Phelan
Training Division

I have received your letter of December 22nd, requesting application forms for admission to St. Joseph's Residential School of Christie Pervais and Andrew Bouchard.

In reply, I am enclosing herewith the application form for Christie Pervais, duly completed and signed. However, with regard to Andrew Bouchard, this pupil was discharged from the above school on December 22nd, 1947. This boy was very much needed at home, as per letter received from Mr. A.H. Jeffrey of Rippon.

Would you therefore advise if the application form for Andrew Bouchard is still required; if so, this will be obtained and forwarded without delay.

[Signature]
J. G. Beck,
Superintendent.
January 28, 1948.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Port Arthur, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, file 210-5, the Department approves the admission of Christie and Melvyn Pervais to the Fort William Residential School.

In view of the information contained in the second paragraph of your letter, it will not be necessary to forward an application form for Andrew Bouchard.

The official name of this school is "Fort William Residential" and we would appreciate it if you would refer to it by this name in future correspondence instead of St. Joseph's.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Fort Arthur, Ontario,
12th January, 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Att: Mr. P. Phelan
Training Division

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter of December 22nd, requesting application forms for admission to St. Joseph's Residential School of Christie Pervais and Andrew Bouchard.

In reply, I am enclosing herewith the application form for Christie Pervais, duly completed and signed. However, with regard to Andrew Bouchard, this pupil was discharged from the above school on December 22nd, 1947. His boy was very much needed at home, as per letter received from Mr. A.H. Jeffrey of Kapigon.

Would you therefore advise if the application form for Andrew Bouchard is still required; if so, this will be obtained and forwarded without delay.

J. G. Burk,
Superintendent.
January 28, 1948.

Mr. J.G. Burk, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Port Arthur, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, file 210-5, the Department approves the admission of Christie and Melvyn Pervais to the Fort William Residential School.

In view of the information contained in the second paragraph of your letter, it will not be necessary to forward an application form for Andrew Bouchard.

The official name of this school is "Fort William Residential" and we would appreciate it if you would refer to it by this name in future correspondence instead of St. Joseph's.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont.,
5th May, 1948.

To: Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Application for Admission Form,
Florence Singleton, Age 8.

The above was admitted to the Fort William Indian Residential School just prior to the close of the last quarter. Her mother has been dead for some years and it was felt she was not receiving proper guidance so in her best interests, she was admitted to this School. She was shown on the required form which accompanied the quarterly school report, but the application form itself was delayed until just now received from this school.

We would welcome receiving approval of this admission and also the other admissions during the preceding quarterly period.

J.G. Burk,
Indian Sup't,
Port Arthur Agency.

Enclosure.

July 18, 1949.

Rev. Sister M. Carmen,
Principal,
Fort William Indian Res., School,
Fort William, Ontario.

The June Quarterly Return for the Fort William Residential School has been received.

On checking the return it has been noted that pupils 430, 433, 438, 419, 0452, 0453 and 0456 were in residence less than the prescribed number of days for the quarter. It is noted also that some of these pupils are being discharged. However, you neglected to indicate the dates these pupils left the residence.

The Auditors and the Treasury Branch insist that the dates showing when pupils leave and return to residence, and the reason thereto be shown in the remarks column when they are in residence less than the prescribed number of days.

Would you supply the information in these cases and also make it a point to show the dates for checking purposes in all future returns.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
July 20, 1949,

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Phelan;

Your letter of July 18th, has been received, regarding the dates these pupils left the residence.

They are as follows:
436 Glen A. Martin April 4th. he is only 4 years old and his parents were ill, when they recovered they took him home.

430 Richard Bannon May 1st. when the parents moved to town and he could remain at home and attend St. Patrick's School.

433 Leo Bouchard April 16th

0452 Rita Bouchard "

0453 Esther Bouchard "

0419 Emelda Bouchard "

These four children were taken home for Easter with the intent of returning to school, but did not return.

There is an error in typing the March Quarterly Return 0455 is given on the "Admission Form" for Gwendolyn M. Martin, and on the blue sheet 0456 is given the first 0455 is correct.

0456 given on the Admission Form June 30th. is for Rachael Na Nabigan admitted on June 27, '49 who was discharged from the McKellar Hospital, but has to remain here all holidays for weekly treatment at the "Clinic."

Trusting this information is adequate, and the apparent neglect has not inconvenienced you.

Yours sincerely,

Sister M. Carmen,
Superior Fort William Indian Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.
February 24, 1950.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.,

We have been advised that Gladys Tookenay included in the membership of the Pic Band is in fact Gladys Mitchell, the legal child of White parents. She, therefore, does not qualify for membership in an Indian Band.

It is presumed that O375, Teresa Tookenay in the Fort William Indian Residential School is the same girl. If that is so, it will be necessary that she be struck off as a grant-earning pupil at the school immediately.

However, if the immediate discharge of this girl will cause her undue hardship and if it is felt that she should remain in residence to the end of June and discharged then, the Department is willing to reconsider the immediate discharge.

May we have your view on the matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

PORT ARTHUR, Ont.,
March 6th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Citizenship-Immigration, Ottawa.

Fort William Ind. Res. School.

Upon a cursory check of the above on Saturday, here, it was decided to withhold the forwarding of the above as several inaccuracies and omission were noted and it was desired to give a more thorough check. This we have done, and even as it is, the report is not totally what is desired, but owing to the unusually tardy submission by the School, we are forwarding it herewith, with several amendments noted.

We have asked the school to prepare the usual admission and discharge summary and when this is to hand it will go forward. Apparently the Sister who has done this report the past several years is no longer at the school and her successor has found much difficulty in compiling the report.

Two Wawea children were admitted Oct. 25th, but they were omitted from the report by the school and they have agreed to enter on report for 31st March, retro-actively.

J.G. Burk, Indian Sup't.
PORT ARTHUR, Ont.,
March 6th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa.

Fort William Indian Residential School,
Pupil 0375, Theresa (Gladys) Tookanay.

Your letter of February 24th received at this Office, dealing with the removal from membership in the Pic Band of the above and re her remaining at the above school until end of June.

I would recommend that this branch continue to pay her tuition until the end of the June term, for it may be necessary otherwise for her guardians to remove her from the school, which would break up her school-year in an undesirable manner.

Mr. Tookanay died about eight months ago and it would be a hardship on the widow at this point to assume full responsibility, especially as she is elderly. However, we are writing her, impressing upon her that we can perhaps assist until June, but thereafter the responsibility for Gladys will remain entirely in her hands.

np/
c.c. to Mrs. Tookanay,
Schreiter, Ontario.

PORT ARTMUR, Ontario.
March 27th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Br., Dept. Citizenship, Immigration, Ottawa, Ontario.

Fort William Indian Res. School,
the Quarterly Return, Ending 31st December

Attached you will find Form I.A. 411, Summary of Admissions and Discharges, at the above school. The regular quarterly report, with admissions orders, went forward to you earlier this month with the explanation that the school officials had neglected this part of the report and we would forward it when they mailed it to us; after some more delay, it finally did come to hand here. However, we expect better co-operation from the School for future reports, since they are now more familiarized with the compilation of this report.

J.G. Burk, Indian Sup't.

April 1st, 1950.

Mr. J.O. Burk,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ontario.

Re: Theresa (Gladys) Tookensay
Your File 9/25-2

We have your letter of the 6th instant
with reference to the above girl. Actually she should
never have been admitted to the Fort William Residential
School as a grant earning pupil, because it appears that
she did not have the proper Indian status.

Under these circumstances, it is difficult
for us to approve paying further per capita allowance
for her. It is realized that it may cause her hardship
but we feel that the mother should remove the girl from
the school at the earliest possible date.

PP/CT

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

To: Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Dept. Citizenship-Immigration, Ottawa.

Referring to your letter of March 30th, we enclose the admission orders of the last two-listed pupils, (453, and 454). The compiling authority at the school was going to include these two admissions retro-actively on the 31st March return (to Oct.25th), and we have been holding the admission orders here until the quarterly report for period ending 31st March was received from the school. However, these Admission Orders are now enclosed.

Regarding the admission orders on the other listed pupils, we have checked out records and find we only have the required copy for our office, the originals having been mailed to you with the Quarterly Return for the period ending 30th Sept., that being the quarter of the year in which they were received into admission at the Res. School; so, as you will perceive they do not bear direct relationship to any admission to the School in the period ending 31st December.

J.J. Burk, Indian Sub't.
Fort William Indian Residential School,
Fort William, Ontario,
March 3, 1950.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur,
Ontario.

Dear Mr. Burk,

In view of the fact that we have been unable to collect board and tuition fees from the parents of these children, we have taken the liberty of including their names on our report.

May we respectfully solicit the co-operation of the Department in assuming responsibility for the maintenance of these children in our school.

Thanking you in anticipation of your usual kind attention to this request, we are,

Very gratefully,

FORT WILLIAM RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Sister R. Thomas,
Superior.
PORT ARTHUR, Ont.,
March 4th, 1950.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration, Ottawa.
Fort William Indian Residential School.

Enclosed you will find the above report, with required attachments.

We also enclose a letter from the Superior of the School concerning two pupils from whom the school has been unable to collect any "board" from the parents and they are requesting our co-operation in having our Branch meet the cost of these children's maintenance.

It would have been better had the School omitted these names from the aggregations on the report until this could have been investigated and discussed with you, and then if approved they could have been added, retroactively, on the report ending 31st March. However, as this report (covering period ending 31st Dec.) was just received and is so late we do not choose to delay it further, so am submitting same as is.

I have not had time to thoroughly check the background of these children, also the financial aspects of the parents, but the children are about one half Indian, but are not holding memberships in any of our recognized bands. However, in view of their being part Indian, and the apparent destitution of the parents, would you consider meeting maintenance costs at this school for the remainder of the term?

[Signature]

Musk, Indian Sup't.

April 21st, 1950.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ontario.

Re: Fort William Indian Residential School

We have your letter of the 4th ultimo with reference to pupils 452 Nila Nagotika and 0464 Eleanor Hardy, who are at the Fort William School.

We allowed a grant for these children for the month of December as we presumed that you would forward the application forms. However, in view of the information contained in the last paragraph of your letter of March 4th, we are doubtful if they are eligible for admission as grant earning pupils to an Indian Residential School. Consequently, we cannot allow a grant for them for the quarter ended March 31st, 1950.

If these children have Indian status, you should forward application forms for them. If they have no Indian status, we cannot pay per capita allowance.

We approve the admission of the undermentioned children to the school. The application forms for these children were forwarded under cover of your letter of April 10th:

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration

Re: Letter April 21st, 1950

In reply to your above letter re admissions to the Fort William Residential School, I wish to advise that the Wawia family is residing at MacDiarmid, a white settlement, and they are unable to send their children to the local school as it is very much overcrowded.

With reference to George Nabigon, his father is in the Fort William Sanatorium, and Clarence Joseph Towegjick's mother is also in the Fort William Sanatorium, and it was considered advisable to transfer these children to the Fort William Residential School.

J. O. Bur., Superintendent.

Reverend Sister:

I have your letter of July 15th in reference to a shortage on your March grant for Fort William Indian Residential School.

As you are aware, the Department has not approved the admittance of pupils No. 452 Nils Nagotika and No. 0464 Eleanor Hardy as their status has not been definitely established that they are Indians, consequently grant for these children cannot be allowed.

As you had shown these children on the return and the Department struck them off, your figures therefore would not coincide with the cheque you had received.

Re: Fort William Residential School,

With reference to your telegram of the 5th instant regarding the four girls who are being sent to the Fort William Residential School, I enclose tickets for their transportation from New Liskeard to North Bay, and also tickets for their transportation from North Bay to Fort William.

In view of the age of these girls, we do not think it is necessary to send an escort with them.

Please advise Mr. F. Matterson, Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, North Bay, Ontario, Telephone 3050 Local 20, regarding the exact date and time of their arrival in North Bay. Mr. Matterson will arrange for their accommodation in North Bay between trains and will also arrange to have them placed on the train going to Fort William.

You should also write the Principal of the Fort William Residential School regarding the date and time of their arrival in that City, so that she can arrange...
October 6, 1950.

Mr. P. Matters,
Regional Supervisor of
Indian Agencies,
North Bay, Ontario.

Re: Fort William Residential School

I enclose for your information a copy of a letter being forwarded to Indian Superintendent Lamothe.

I understand that the girls will have to stay overnight in North Bay, and it would be appreciated if you would arrange for some place for them to stay and see that they catch the first train to Fort William. As you will note from the letter, they will have their tickets.

Any expenses incurred for the maintenance of the girls will be paid upon receipt of a voucher from you.

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Indian Education
Notre Dame-du-Nord, October 13, 1950.

Bernard F. Neary, Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I am returning tickets for the 4 girls being their fare from New Liskeard station to North Bay.

November 28, 1950.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.,

Attached, I am returning six applications for admission to the Port William Indian Residential School.

It is noted that none of the applications have been signed by the parents which is necessary before the Department can consider them.

It is also noted that four of the children are from the Pic Band and two from the Gull Bay Band where day school education is available. Is there any reason why these children should be admitted for institutional care?

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Enclosure:

MFT/IIM
December 11, 1950.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.,

We have checked our records and fail to locate the September Quarterly Return for the Fort William Indian Residential School.

As it is presumed that no return has been submitted, it would be appreciated if you would contact the Principal to have this Return completed and forwarded to your office immediately.

We are anxious to have the September Returns paid up before commencing on the December Returns.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship & Immigration.

Re: File 464-10 (E6)
November 28, 1950

In reply to your letter of the above date, we wish to advise that Mary Michano is attending St. Patrick's High School and living at the Boarding School. The Starr children had been attending a Public School at Coldwell, Ontario, and were urgently in need of the proper guidance. The Wilson children do live at Gull Bay Reserve at times, but the parents are terrible wanderers and when they move on to hunt, or fish, they take all their children with them. Therefore we suggested that these two younger children be placed in Boarding School. We are unable to have the parents sign this form at the present time, as they are off in the bush somewhere trapping.

J. G. Burk,
Superintendent.
December 18, 1950.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.,

This will acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th November with enclosure from Miss Florence Burnside (teacher) and Miss Mary K. Soy (principal) of the White River School, regarding Percy Hannanish who resides approximately 1½ miles from White River. In reply I wish to advise that I contacted the principal of the St. Joseph's Boarding School and they informed me that they would be very pleased to have the boy enrolled at the school. I have written to the parents of the boy today suggesting that he be sent up after the Christmas holidays.

For your information, I may say that I have spoken to the boy's father, Frank Hannanish regarding the child attending Boarding School and he was not very favourably inclined. Mr. Hannanish feels that the boy should live at home as Percy is crippled and he is invariably teased by the other boys, but I will try and persuade Mr. Hannanish to allow the boy to attend Boarding School.

I have sent a copy of this letter to Miss Foy at White River School.

(Sgd) J.W. Burk

J.W. Burk,
Superintendent.
December 21, 1950.

I have now sent in a form of application for admission to St. Joseph's Boarding School, duly signed and completed by Mr. Sam King, the foster parent.

In view of the above, it would be very much appreciated if authorization could be received to pay St. Joseph's Indian Residential School for the board of these three pupils.

We ourselves are not sure what sum would be the most appropriate to pay St. Joseph's Boarding School, but the Sister in Charge did suggest $40.00 per month for each of these three students.

J. G. Burk,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
Port Arthur, Ontario,
November 3rd, 1951.

Res Tuition Grants.

The following children are attending St. Patrick's High School, Fort William, Ontario:

Mary Michane #140 Pic Band - residing at Port Coldwell, Ont.
Robert Michane #140 Pic Band - residing at Port Coldwell, Ont.
Annie Fisher #130 Pic Band - residing at Heron Bay, Ont.

and are boarding at St. Joseph's Indian Residential School, Fort William, Ontario, which was the only suitable place available for these children, who normally reside out of town.

Mary Michane aged 16 has proved to be a very industrious student and was promoted to Grade 10 from Grade 9 for the academic year 1951-2.

Robert Michane aged 18 is attending St. Patrick's for the first time this year, and is in Grade 10 (Commercial). Robert previously was attending the Vocational School in Fort William, and in a telephone conversation with the Principal, we were advised that Robert had been an exceptionally good pupil and only transferred to St. Patrick's as he preferred to attend a Catholic school.

Annie Fisher aged 18 is also attending St. Patrick's for the first time this year and is in Grade 10. She previously attended Spanish Indian Residential School. In a verbal conversation with Sister Superior of St. Patrick's High School, we were advised that Annie seems very anxious to avail herself of a good education and appears very industrious.

Robert and Mary Michane commenced boarding at St. Joseph's on September 4th and Annie Fisher on October 19th 1951. Robert occupies
November 14, 1951.

Mr. J.C. Burk,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Your file 9/25-8

With reference to your letter of November 3rd regarding tuition grants for Mary Michano, Robert Michano and Annie Fisher, it is noted that these pupils are already residing at the Fort William Indian Residential School, and are attending the St. Patrick's High School at Fort William.

It is not clear why you are asking for a grant of $40. a month for board for these pupils as it has been the practice for the Department to pay the usual per capita grant in cases of this nature.

You should arrange to forward the usual application for admission forms for these three pupils for consideration.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

COPY LETTER

Fort William Indian Residential School,
235 South Franklin Street,
FORT WILLIAM, Ont.

November 30th 1951.

Mr. J. G. Burk,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Fort Arthur, Ont.

Dear Mr. Burk,

Some days ago your office informed us that the Dept., had issued orders to have the names of our High School pupils included in the regular quarterly report. We have done this in the case of Mary and Robert Michano. Annie Fisher was not admitted until the end of October.

You may recall telephoning us at the beginning of September stating that you were unable to procure accommodation for these pupils in a private home and requested us to admit them here until such time as different and suitable arrangements were made. We were under the impression the same remuneration would be forthcoming as if they were in a private home. Incidentally the lady with whom Robert was stationed last year told us that she could not to use her own words, "make ends meet" at the rate of $40.00 per month and for this reason had refused to accept him this year.

Our overhead expenditures are exorbitant and we feel that you will agree with us that the per diem rate paid by the Dept., is very meagre when one considers the present high cost of living.

Perhaps it would be well to make a further effort to procure accommodation for these students since the Department apparently is in favour of paying the private individual rather than the institution.

Looking forward to an early reply for which we thank you in advance.

Yours very truly,
PORT WILLIAM INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

M. Thomasina (Sister) Sup't.
Port Arthur, Ontario.
December 8th 1951.

Res: Your file #464-10 (E6)
letter dated Nov. 14/51

Further to your letter dated as above I am enclosing herewith copy of letter received from Rev. Sister M. Thomasina, Superintendent of the Fort William Indian Residential School, which is self-explanatory.

Robert Michano who was boarded out last year in a private home was refused lodging this year as the lady concerned informed me that she could not "make ends meet" at $40.00 a month. Under the existing circumstances would you kindly reconsider your decision and allow the Fort William Residential School $35-$40.00 per month for each of the three Indian boarders, namely Robert Michano, Mary Michano and Annie Fisher, who are attending St. Patrick's High School, Fort William, Ontario.

When these children came into town it was absolutely impossible to secure any private homes in which to place them. Rev. Sister Thomasina very kindly stated she would take them in until such time as we could secure suitable lodgings; this has been impossible to do.

J. O. Burk,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.

December 11, 1951

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.,

Your file 9/25-8

With reference to your letter of December 8 regarding the admission of three High School pupils to the Fort William Indian Residential School, the Department is not prepared to make an exception in this case by making a special allowance for High School pupils residing in the residential school.

The Per Capita allowance for the Fort William Indian Residential School is $246.75 a year. This will be allowed for each of the three pupils. In addition to the usual Per Capita grant, we are prepared to allow the school an amount of $12.50 a month for the three pupils. In other words, in addition to the usual Per Capita grant the school will be allowed $125.00 for the academic year for the three pupils.

We feel that this allowance will be comparable to the rate Sister Ann Thomasina, Principal of the Fort William school requested. Please advise whether the Principal is willing to accept the three children under these terms.

Philip Phelan
Superintendent of Education.

by C.A.P.C.

Port Arthur, Ont.,

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

Mr. J.G. Burk,

Port-Arthur, Ontario,
February 11th, 1952.

Educational Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Your file #464-10 (E6),
letter dated Dec. 11, 1952.

Further to your letter as above with regard to 23 new admissions to the Fort William Indian Residential School, as per September Quarterly Return, we are enclosing herewith 12 application forms duly completed, in connection with the following pupils:

Eugene Singleton
Georgina Shaganash
Maryanne Echum
Victoria Boucher
Isabelle Esquondern
Elizabeth Esquondern

Lillian Legarde
Irene Desmoulin
Albert Twance
Gertrude Barbeau Bonum
Herbert Gilbert Legarde
Mac Oliver Legarde

In the case of Eugene Singleton, his guardian Mrs. Margaret Pitt has signed for this child. His father does not live with the mother, and the whereabouts of both parents are not known. Mrs. Pitt is Eugene Singleton's grandmother (maternal).

With reference to Lillian Legarde, her grandfather (maternal) Mr. Joe Towagejick has signed for this child. Lillian's mother is a patient in the Sanatorium, and the whereabouts of the father are unknown.

We might mention that on January 24th, we forwarded application admission form in connection with Robert Michano included in the total of 23 new admissions. With the 12 forms attached to this letter and the one already sent for Robert Michano, leaving a balance of 10 more forms, please be advised that these will be forwarded within the course of the next few days.

encls.

J. G. Burk, Sup't.
February 14, 1952

Mr. J.O. Burk,
Supt. Indian Agency,
Port Arthur, Ont.,

of February 11th

Gertrude Barbeau Bohum

Philip Phelan,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of
Abraham, Pupil No. 0287,
of the St. Joseph's Indian Residential School at Fort William,
who died at W. Keller Hospital on March 3rd, 1936.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the
Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry,
consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical
Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's
presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of
Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's
death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be
permitted to attend it or send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked
if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

FORM No. 414.
A. STATEMENT OF THE PRINCIPAL OF THE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

1. On what date did this pupil fall sick or suffer injury? Feb. 14 - in the class.

2. At what time of day?

3. When and to whom did he or she report this illness or accident? Feb. 14 - to Mr. Smith.

4. What means were taken to afford relief? Placed in the infirmary.

5. What medicines were used for this purpose and in what dose or quantity? The usual treatment.

6. When was the doctor called? February 15.

7. If the pupil was removed to hospital, at what time was this done and by what means of transport? February 16 - By ambulance.

8. If the pupil was not removed to hospital, what measures were taken for his or her care at the school?

9. Add any other useful information here.

Alice Johnson is the 6th child of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson. She had been a patient of the hospital at Edmonton for 2 years before coming here in September.

Principal.

Note: If the deceased pupil dies in hospital at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who attends him at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to this memorandum.
B. STATEMENT OF THE PHYSICIAN WHO ATTENDED
THE DECEASED PUPIL

I attended Alice Abraham from February 26th to March 3rd. The immediate cause of death was pneumonia from whooping cough, also had tuberculosis.

The contributory cause of death was tuberculosis.

Do you consider that the Principal of the School, and the members of the School staff exercised reasonable care and judgment in regard to the illness and death of this pupil? Yes.

Did they follow out your professional instructions? Yes.

If in either respect, you consider them to have been at fault, it is required that you express your carefully considered views as follows:

The symptoms had been overlooked, were not recognized in hospital, encouraging the developed pneumonia.

[Signature]
M.D.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
June 14, 1923.

Attention: Principal Bruce

Sir:

With reference to the enclosed form, as to cause of death of Alice Aromen, pupil No. 687 of the St. Joseph's Indian Residential School, Fort William, Ont., I beg to report that this girl was transferred from Cochrane, Ont., two years ago to St. Joseph's School.

The body has been placed in the vault at St. Andrew's Cemetery, Fort William, Ont. I would be obliged if the Department would advise if the body should be removed, in the spring, to St. Andrew's Cemetery or to the Fort William Reserve.

In conclusion, I may say that several Indians have already been buried in St. Andrew's Catholic Cemetery at Fort William, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

P.S.
Ottawa, March 20, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 10th instant enclosing report with reference to the death of Alice Abraham, No. 0257, of the Fort William Indian Residential School.

It is noted that the body has been placed in the vault, and she may be buried either in St. Andrew's Catholic cemetery, Fort William, or in the cemetery on the Fort William Reserve. It is understood, of course, that there will be no expense to the Department in this regard.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Bupt. of Indian Education.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Ottawa, September 9th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your enquiry regarding your niece Alice Abraham made to the Treaty Paying Officer at Attawapiskat this year, I have to inform you that Alice Abraham was transferred from the Hospital at Cochrane to St. Joseph's Indian Residential School at Fort William two years ago where she died on March 3rd, 1936.

Instructions were issued for burial either in St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Cemetery, Fort William, or in the Cemetery on the Fort William Reserve. It is not known at present in which of these cemeteries burial took place.

Yours very truly,

Peter Bird, No. 183, Attawapiskat Band,
c/o The Hudson's Bay Company,
Attawapiskat, Ontario,
Via Moosonee, Ont.

if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be
attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after
the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it imprac-
ticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him.
A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal
Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind
might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for
this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach
the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including
an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the state-
ments of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

To the Hon. Mayne Daly,
Dept. General of Indian Affairs.

Honourable Sir,

I am sorry not to have met you when you passed through the country and visited our Industrial Schools, but I am quite contented when I hear that the honourable Premier was enchanted with the work of your Department.

No better confirmation could be given to your excellent speech in the House of Commons in defense of the Indian Schools.

I suppose now that we have but to express a wish to see it realized?

I take the liberty of sending to Mr. Haytin Reed, your Deputy Minister who is so sincerely devoted to the welfare of the Indians, few petitions, viz., one for a boarding School at Rat Portage, (you remember you promised one in your letter of July the 16th that this request will be put in the Estimates) where we would need five or six thousand dollars to begin.
Honourable Sir,

I have the honor to inform you that Mr. J. O. Cornish, the Indian Agent of this district, is away on leave and is not expected to return until the end of this present month.

There are questions in your letter that should be answered more adequately by the established Agent. Therefore, I beg you to send me a full report before his return.

Yours obediently,

W. A. Foster

facility of utilizing the present premises for an Industrial School.

Regarding cost & maintenance, I beg leave to submit the following remarks and figures. I presume it costs on an average $400 or a year to maintain a day school. Having Lake and district are entitled to 6 such schools - five on rainy Lake proper and one to the south. (Two of these schools are already in operation, appropriations have been voted for two more, and Indians have approached me with regard to a fifth). The maintenance of these six schools would mean an annual expenditure of at least $2,400.

A good Boarding School or an Industrial School on a limited scale could be maintained on this amount until such time as circumstances would call for further development.

It is therefore a question of suppressing the day schools in that district, and by combination, all energies in one institution obtain tangible and lasting results.

I shall further observe that the Roman Catholic is the only religious influence exercised over that district where are no conflicting interests in the way.

Another conclusion we arrived at was that the establishment of a school at that point would probably do away with this once cherished for a portion of Father's Point, the old Mission, and Rockville. This had in view of conserving by a very few men an ancient landmark of mission civilization, one of the most ancient forts being there by its great services obtained.

Trusting these few remarks may help solving within the limits of my station what is becoming a serious problem.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Hon. J. S. Wills,
Subl. General of Indian Affairs,

Hon. Sir,

Having had occasion lately to speak to His Grace Archbishop Langevin & Mr. Boniface in reference to certain Indian schools in the Rainy Lake district, over which I have charge, the matter was deemed of sufficient importance to be brought to your notice.

There is question of constructing a number of new schools at Sioux River Reserve and on "Red But" Reserve respectively on Rainy Lake. Application has also been made for a new schoolhouse on Cuthbertson River, valued at £1,000. The money for the first two schools has already been voted, and the Indians are pressing for the construction of these schools, but as it is not an admirable system of day schools in some cases, I have neglected so far to bring the matter on the Department's attention to come to the point. I consider that the amount called for to be expended on Rainy Lake alone (Cuthbertson £1,000, "Red But" and Sioux River combined £600), would be sufficient, in view of exceptional facilities, to provide for a well appointed Boarding School or an Industrial School on a small scale.

The facilities I allude to are the buildings and grounds pertaining to the Cuthbertson Agency. This Agency, by its nature, is not centrally nor conveniently located for its present purpose—it is nearly two miles from Fort Frances where the central and railway lines for the district this Agency is intended to serve. The present Agent Mr. Cornish has pointed this out more than once to Mr. Reid and begged to be fixed in the throat. He also drew my attention to the advantages and...
It is, however, a matter of great uncertainty, owing to the demands made upon the Government for school purposes, whether funds could even be found for increasing the Fort William School, to say nothing of getting funds for an additional Institution.

Yours obediently,

Dep't. Supt:Genl:
of Indian Affairs.
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant addressed to the Hon. Mr. Dely, submitting a proposition for the establishment of a Boarding School at Fort Frances or Rat Portage. In reply I beg to say that I have been directed by the Superintendent General to inform you that the Department is fully alive to the advantages which would accrue from the establishment of such an Institution in the Neighboring District, but I consider it not in view of the fact that the Roman Catholic authorities at Fort William have just completed a large Institution there, aided by a Government Grant, it would hardly be justified in asking Parliament at present for a similar grant for a school in the locality in which we are situated, especially in view of the fact that there will be room for fully 75 additional pupils more than are now provided for at Fort William. It is therefore considered that it would be better, instead of erecting new buildings at Rat Portage to send the children to Fort William, and this course commends itself to the Department for other reasons, one of which is that the other denominations which are carrying on work in the same district would naturally feel entitled to the privileges.

Yours,

C. Cahill, O.M.I.

Sir,

I have the honour to point out that the estimate for the current fiscal year contain a provision for only 20 boarders for the Rat Portage Boarding School whilst our Draft Estimates provided for thirty-five. At the present moment there are thirty boarders, the number authorized by your semi-official letter of the 17th of June 1898 in answer to a letter of the 13th of the same month. All the data in this connection are in the possession of the Department and you will remember that although the provision last year was for only 20 boarders owing to the closing of some day schools and the intention on the part of the R.C. authorities not to urge the establishment of new ones at places where they would be of no benefit, that the number of pupils was increased to 30. If the number for the current year must remain at 20, it will be impossible to expect the Principal to maintain 30 pupils upon the provisions now in force. The pupils will have to be returned to their homes after hardly two years' stay at the school, and the money expended will simply have been thrown away.

I therefore take the liberty to urge the necessity of restoring the original figures placed in our draft estimates.

The question of establishing a boarding school at Fort Frances has been before the Department on two previous occasions. Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 11th November, 1902

The Secretary:

With reference to the application hereunder dated the 6th instant from His Grace, Archbishop Langevin for the establishment of a boarding school at Fort Frances, Ontario, I beg to say:

1. That I do not consider that another boarding school in this neighborhood is required. The Roman Catholics have schools of this class at Rat Portage and Fort William, and the Indians of the five reserves who have asked for a boarding school, as stated by His Grace, are not likely to be benefited to any great extent by sending their children to a boarding school, as hunting, fishing, and working in the lumber camps is what they have to look forward to as means to obtaining a livelihood, the land on their reserves being unfit for farming. Life in a boarding school will not fit them for the hardships they will have to endure in following these avocations.

2. His Grace states that two day schools could be closed to help the new boarding school. The schools to which he refers are Couchiching and Stangemoong. These schools are doing well; the former having enrolled all the children of school age (27) with an average attendance of 16; while the latter has an enrollment of 16 out of a school population of 19, with an average of 10 for last year. It would, I think, be unwise to close schools doing such good work and at least teaching the Indians the three R's which is all they will require for some

23rd September, 1905.

Sir,

The Lady-Superior of the Rat Portage Boarding School called on me today and said that they had two little girls in the school for about a year now that they have had to keep for charity sake, and felt they could do no longer, as it was more than they could do.

It appears that the two girls in question, has neither father or mother, both being dead, they are the offspring of Indians who withdrew from treaty, and they have no relatives in this district or any one to look after them.

The Lady-Superior asked me if the Dept would allow some of the Indians to help care for the girls and take them into their homes. I told her I couldn't say so and asked her to write me and ask if this could be done.

It appears to be a hard case and something will have to be done as the Principal and other Officers of the school say it will be impossible for them to keep them much longer, and do justice to the others.

And as the children in question are total without any protection or anyone to care for them, and are to all intents and purposes Indians I would suggest that the suggestion of the Lady-Superior be acted upon, that it will meet with our approval. Kindly instruct me what reply to give the Lady-Superior, and oblige,

I have the honour to be

Sir

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs,

Dept of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa,
OTTAWA, September 20th—1905.

Sir:

I do acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant reporting that the Lady Superintendent of the Rat Portage Institution school had called on you with reference to two little girls who have been taken into that Institution for charity's sake, but who are no longer able to retain as non-grant earners.

With reference to the Lady-Superintendent's request that the Department allow one of the Indians to adopt these girls and have them taken into treaty, their present status being that of half-breeds, I am of the opinion that the Department does not approve of this course as it would be opening the door to numerous similar applications.

The authorities of the Rat Portage Institution school were well aware when they received these children that they were not entitled to draw upon the Department in case they were not willing to keep them, they should not have taken them.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean

Indian Agent,

On the 20th February 1896, Mr. Hayter Reed, the Deputy Sect. Head of Judicial Affairs wrote the Rev. C. Calhoun of Rat Portage stating that it was the intention to seek a grant in the same estimate to establish a Boarding School at Rat Portage and would like to be informed as to what amount of land at his mission could be utilized for the purpose.

April 7th 1896—In his reply Rev. Calhoun stated that 25 acres had been specially selected as suitable for the purpose in contemplation. The Estimate for 1896-97 provided the sum of $2,500 towards building a Boarding School at Rat Portage.
Rat Portage Boarding School

Situation: This school is situated south of the town of Rat Portage, but on the shore of the Lake of the Woods, and is two miles distant from the town.

Agency: It is in the Rat Portage Agency and in the Manitoba Superintendent.

Land: There are 51 acres of land in connection with the school, the property of the Catholic Mission.

Buildings: The school building are of frame construction with brick veneer, on a stone foundation. The interior is plastered except the ceilings which are of wood. The main building is 36 x 30 ft., 3 stories high, with an extension at the south end, 36 x 26 ft., 2 stories high; also attached to the rear of the main building is a lean-to kitchen, 16 x 14 ft.

The other buildings are: Principal's residence, 20 x 16 ft., with lean-to, 14 x 12 ft.; Workshop, 22 x 16 ft.; Stable and carriage shed, 16 x 18 ft.; Woodshed, 20 x 12 ft.; and dog house for visiting Indians, 18 x 14 ft.

Accommodation: There is suitable accommodation for 40 pupils and 40 of the staff.
Ottawa, February 26, 1906.

The Deputy Supt. General:

With reference to Father Gendron's application for an increase in the pupilage at the Roman Catholic boarding school at Kenora, I beg to say that the present number provided for is 30. They have ample accommodation for 10 more pupils and an unlimited field for recruiting.

Mr. Inspector Semmens reports favourably on this school, which is doing good work and is economically managed, and the Indian Commissioner, when here lately, also referred to the good this school was doing.

The only thing to be looked at is that if ten pupils are allowed this school, the Cecilia Jeffrey school, which is in the same district, will expect and will be entitled to similar treatment.

I think that if an amount could be placed in the supplementary estimates it would be only fair, as thirty pupils is a very small number to finance a school with, and the additional ten asked for will not entail any extra expense for staff.

[Signature]

Martin Benson

Sir,

In September, 1905, Mr. Agent McKenzie reported that the Lady Superior of the Kenora Boarding School had called on him with reference to two little girls who had been taken into that institution for charity's sake, their present status being that of half-breeds. She has written again asking that the Department may reconsider its decision and allow these pupils to be enrolled as grant earners. As the grant for this school has been increased from 30 to 40 pupils and they have not that number as yet on the roll, these two orphan children right, under the circumstances described, be received as grant earners on the understanding that this concession is not to form a precedent.

17th December, 1905
The Deputy Superintendent General,

Mr. Agent McKenzie has again written the Department in reference to the two little girls who were taken into the Kenora Boarding School for charity's sake, their present status being that of half-breeds. As this school has had the number of authorized pupils increased by 10 and as this is a deserving case, I am of opinion that the department would be quite justified in allowing them to be placed on the roll as grant earners, as the school can hardly afford to maintain them and if they are discharged there is no place for them to go. In one instance both father and mother are dead and in the other case the father has abandoned the mother, who is unable to support her daughter.

I beg to refer you to my previous memorandum on this subject, of November 30, last.

In conclusion I may refer to a letter of the 24th October, 1899
(Pyle No 180148/1) written by Mr Smart to Commissioner Laird,
in which it was stated that the Minister could not approve of the
absolute rule which Mr Laird had laid down that none but treaty
children should be admitted into Indian Schools.

The letter read as follows—-----------------"A well defined
"line can be drawn between half-breeds, properly speaking,
"and Indians, and while the Minister does not consider that the
"children of half-breeds proper, of Manitoba and the Territories,
"should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the
"Department, still he is decidedly of the opinion that all
"children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not,
"who live upon an Indian reserve and whose parents on either
"side live as Indians upon a reserve, even if they are not
"annuitants, should be eligible for admission to schools. It
"should be remembered in this connection that boarding and
"industrial schools were not established for the purpose of
"carrying out the terms of treaty, or complying with any provision
"of the law, but that they were instituted in the public interest,
"so that there should not grow up upon reserves an uneducated
"and barbarous class." The North West Government can not
"provide for the education of non-annuitants upon reserves,
"and if we should exclude them from our schools, they would
"practically be debarred from all means of education."

While the foregoing does not approve of half-breed children,
whose parents do not live upon reserves as Indians, being admitted
to the schools, yet it takes into consideration the fact that
there are circumstances under which in all justice half-breed
children should be admitted to such Institutions; and I have
quoted therefrom in order that you may have the full facts before
you, and also as I consider this the ruling in question strengthen
my view of the case.

I have been accustomed to deal with cases of this nature
upon the grounds of humanity and expediency, rather than rules

On the 15th October last Agent McKenzie reported that No 48 of the Wabigoon Band has two children, a boy and a girl. He stated—

"Their father is now dead. He was a White man, and this woman has been a member of that band all her life, and has lived on the reserve, all but about three years which she lived with her husband until he died.

"One of these children has been admitted to the Kenora Boarding School by authority of the Commissioner's letter of the 12th October, 1906, No 123/53, and this is to ask if it would not be as well to have these children admitted to treaty, and their money funded for them.

"No 59 of the same band has also an orphan boy the son of an Indian woman, but the father was a White man, and is now dead, the mother being married to No 59, this boy has also been admitted to the Kenora School, on authority of the same letter above. Could this boy be admitted to Treaty also, as he is to all intents an Indian?

"No 57 has also a little girl. Illegitimate, that should be in treaty, for the same reason as the others, and her annuity funded for her. Kindly instruct me in regard to these children."

In each of the cases cited by Mr McKenzie, as above mentioned, the Department approved of admission to treaty (upon the understanding of course that no arrears were to be paid).

Once admitted to treaty all of the individuals referred to become Indians in the eye of the law, and are entitled to all the privileges accorded such persons. The two children whose case is under consideration are, according to Agent McKenzie's report of the 23rd September 1905 (File 12992/1), the offspring of Indians who withdrew from Treaty. He states "they have no relatives in this district or any one to look after them", and he adds still further—"As the children in question are totally without any protection or any one to care for them, and are to all intents and purposes Indians I would suggest that the suggestion of the Lady Superior be acted upon viz— to arrange
Memorandum:

Deputy Superintendent General,

Pursuant to our conversation regarding the case of the two little half-breed girls who are at present at the Kenora Boarding School, and who it would appear were taken into the Institution in 1904 by the Lady Superior, as an act of charity, I beg to set forth the following facts, which I think are sufficient to prove that in the present case (which may be regarded as exceptional, the children being orphans, and having no one to care for them if sent away from the Institution, which has been proposed) the Department would be quite justified in admitting them to treaty, placing them on the pay-list, which would entitle them to become grant earners at the school.

In September 1905 Inspector Chisholm reported to the Department, in connection with annuity payments at the Carlton agency, (File No 156710/7 A) regarding certain individuals who he considered should be admitted to treaty. With respect to the following he stated:— "No 131. The woman on this ticket has been twice legally married. Her first husband was a half-breed, by whom she had two boys, who are now living with their grand-mother, No 89, a helpless widow, nor is the mother with her present husband any better able to support them. Of course these are not illegitimates, but if any such cases can be considered I would recommend that these be taken into treaty."

The Department after duly considering the matter approved of these two half-breed boys being taken into treaty, and the Inspector was instructed accordingly.

The Inspector also brought forward the following case:—

"No 133 Keeneequonaseew. This man and woman who are old and destitute are keeping a grandchild, a boy, illegitimate, whose mother (their daughter) is dead, and whose father is a half-breed living in the neighborhood, who will never likely provide for the child's support." In this case also the Department approved of the recommendation, and the boy was placed on the pay-list.

INFORMATION OFFICE, KENORA, ONT:

December 18th, 1913

Sir:

On Tuesday the 16th, Dr. Ferguson reported to me that there were several cases of Chicken-pox at the Kenora Boarding School. I requested him to keep a good look-out and see that all possible should be done to break it up, and that all pupils who were affected should be isolated, which was done, but yesterday the Dr. got suspicious, and again reported to me that he was very much afraid that it was Small-pox, and that he would like to have a consultation with one of the other doctors.

I at once advised him to do so, and this morning Doctor Chapman and himself visited the school, and pronounced it small-pox, and they placed the whole institution in quarantine, as quite a number of the children are affected.

The doctor will do everything in his power to keep the disease in check, and not allow it to spread. I thought it my duty to report this matter, and will be glad to have any advice you may wish to give me in regards to this case.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary:
Dept of Indian Affairs:
Ottawa, Ont.
INSPECTOR OF INDIAN AGENCIES
LAKE OF THE WOODS INSPECTORATE

WINNIPEG, MAN December 19th 1913

Sir,

A few days ago there was trouble out in the school which was at first diagnosed as typhoid fever. On a more thorough reading of the symptoms and consultation between our Kenora Medical Officer and Dr Chapman of Kenora was finally declared to be smallpox.

Quarantine has been established and the patient isolated and quarantine of all susceptible children has been carried out. Every possible precaution has been taken to ensure the safety and prevent the spread of the disease.

A new method of handling the situation has been introduced that will help to prevent further infection.

I am,

Your obedient servant

John Semmens
Inspector Indian Agencies
Ottawa, December 23, 1913.

Sir,

I beg to confirm the following telegram sent you on the 20th instant:- Have instructed Dr. Ferguson to look after smallpox, Kenora School.

On the receipt of your telegram of the 19th reporting that smallpox had broken out at the Indian boarding school at Kenora Dr. Ferguson was requested by wire to investigate and take all necessary precautions to prevent the spread of the disease. I may add that the Department is in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent at Kenora who reports that the institution has been placed under quarantine and that everything possible is being done to keep the disease in check. The patients have been isolated and the vaccination of all unvaccinated children has been carried out.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

GENERAL REMARKS.

1.- Owing to the splendid accommodations in general I should think this institution should be allowed to have at least 50 pupils.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR SUMMERS ON THE KENORA BOARDING SCHOOL.

ACCOMMODATION,

There is reasonable room for 45 to 50 pupils.

The Principal finds that in order to give the children sufficient air space he must needs limit the accommodation of the Staff.

Indeed he has a proposal to sell the present building for a soldiers convalescent home and move school to one of the reserves out on the Lake. The reasons he gives for the proposed change are as follows:

1. Parents complain that the school is too far away from them and they do not care to let the children go, for that reason.

2. The land on the Lake is much better and a far greater amount of self help could be secured.

3. It would make the Principal's work lighter and keep him at home more if it were not for the incessant long trips made necessary by the duty of distributing and collecting pupils as well as visiting people on reserves, who require the ministerial supervision.

These reasons for the desired change of location are worthy of consideration from a church standpoint. It may be more difficult for the Department to see their interest in the proposed change. To be plain what is aimed at is likely to put one school at McIntosh for the accommodation of the Savarte Agency and one at Big Island for the benefit of the Kenora Agency. This would extend and consolidate ecclesiastic control of the educational institutions of western Ontario and add to the prestige and honor of the Catholic Church. One cannot but admire the breadth of view these people have and who after all is so well qualified to boost these schools as the Catholic sisterhood.

Date of Inspection, October 4th, 1916.
Ottawa, November 5, 1918.

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Memorandum.

Hon. Mr. Meighen.

August 2, 1919.

Incl.

The attached letter from the Archbishop of St. Boniface suggests that the Government might buy the Indian boarding school property at Kenora for use as a home for disabled soldiers, and erect two new school buildings, one on the Lake of the Woods and the other near McIntosh Station, in the Savanne agency.

The buildings at Kenora are owned by the Church, and I see no indication in the letter that the Church would propose to meet the cost of the erection of the two new buildings. If it is intended for the Government to purchase the school and find the money for the new scheme, it would, no doubt, be to the advantage of the Church, but, at present, I cannot see any reason for carrying out the suggestion. Apart altogether from the doubt as to whether the buildings would be suitable as a home for disabled soldiers, and whether the Government needs such a building, I cannot at present see that the proposed change is urgent in the interests of the Indians for our educational work, and, therefore, I cannot support it.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Extract from Inspector's Report on the Kenora Boarding School. Original on 129992-6

As I understand the Cecilia Jeffrey Shoal Lake Protestant Indian Boarding School is about 1/3 smaller in accommodation than this school and is allowed to accommodate 70. When all the pupils return there will be 79 or 80. If this school be not permitted to retain these, the children concerned will be without any school whatever as there are none around.

Owing to the lack of educational facilities for Indian school children in the vicinity of Kenora, I would recommend that this school be allowed to accommodate all possible. I have inspected the dormitories and accommodations and I feel that they can easily accommodate from 70 to 80.

The allowance of $145.00 for each child is really terribly small. It amounts to 40 cents a day. On this these Indian children are clothed, fed and instructed in civilized ways and the maintenance of all buildings, etc., to accommodate these children must also come out of that. These facts are so plain that surely the Dominion Government Indian Department could arrange for a higher per capita allowance.

J. M. Bennett,

Insp.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. J. M. Bennett, Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kenora Boarding School, states that, owing to the lack of educational facilities for Indian children in the vicinity of Kenora, he would recommend that this school be allowed to take in such children up to the number for which it can provide accommodation and that the grant be paid for them.

At present a grant is allowed for 60 pupils. The Inspector states that he has inspected the dormitories and that the school could easily provide accommodation for at least 70 pupils. He compares the accommodation at this school with that at the Cecilia Jeffrey Boarding School and states that, while the Cecilia Jeffrey School is one-third smaller, it is allowed to accommodate 70 children.

While there are no funds to provide for an increase in the pupilage during the present fiscal year, I would recommend that the Kenora School be granted an increase of 10 pupils from the first of April, next, and that this increase be provided for in the estimates for the next fiscal year. The Architect's Branch will, no doubt, be able to state the number which the Kenora School can accommodate, taking into consideration the requirements as to air and floor space in the dormitories and class-rooms.

Sir:

The Department of Indian Affairs is contemplating purchasing the Kenora Boarding School, which is now owned by the Oblate Order.

Before final arrangements can be made with this Order, it is necessary that a complete valuation of the property be made. If your services are available, I would ask you to undertake this work for the Department. It will be necessary that you furnish me with a detailed list of buildings, furniture, stock of all kinds, the area of land, etc. It is understood that the valuation should show the actual present value of the property, and that you will arrange matters in such a way as to avoid further claims after the transfer has been made.

As it is important that the transaction be closed at an early date, I would ask you to kindly undertake this work at your earliest convenience, and advise me by wire as to the date of your inspection.

Reverend Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kenora Boarding School, dated June 27th, last, states that two teachers should be employed. He further states that it is too much to expect one teacher to perform the classroom work satisfactorily, and, besides, the children need the attention of two teachers.

The Department would be pleased to have your views regarding the above recommendation of the Inspector. We consider that, for the number of children in attendance, two teachers are necessary.

6. There is no doubt it is desirable to get the children to school
at an early age. Holidays The length of these holidays has always
been arranged by the School and also the time when they should be
the agent has not interfered as been asked to these matters
in my opinion the length of the holidays and the time is alright
as it enables the children to accompany their parents on their
picking time, when they are a considerable help, but the parents
do not like returning their children to this School after the
holidays and we have considerable difficulty in getting them back.
We have to use pressures to get the Indians to send their
children to the Kenora School, and the Indians say that they are
cruel to the children, and hit them because of them. I have made all
the enquiries I can but I can get nothing definite, and do not
believe they are cruel. There have been several cases of thrashing,
two since this Principal has been at the School, but no doubt the
children deserved it, the reason given was that the boys were
noisy at table and would not do what they were told, so I have
told the Principal that in future no thrashing should be done
until the matter has been taken up with me, and if I considered
the children deserved it I would not protect them. This order was
given owing to the numerous complaints received.
I may say that the Principal has not had very much experience
with Indians and does not speak good English. The other Superior does
not speak any Indians and has not done this kind of work before,
and none of the staff are English perfect with the exception of
possible one.
My sympathy is at present with Cecilia Jeffrey School as the
finished product is much better than that turned out from Kenora
School, and when I visit the Kenora School the children always
seem to be frightened of the Agent and the School staff, the exact
opposite is noticeable at Shoal Lake. In my opinion it is not a
question of religion but in the way the School is run. This one by
fear the other by kindness.
Every child of school age at the Shoal Lake Reserve is at
school or not available, and very few of their children come from
the Rat Portage Reserve which is situated close to the Kenora School
but the only way I can fill this school is by force whilst we do
not have much difficulty in getting pupils for Cecilia Jeffrey, a lot
of the Indians are willing to send their children to school but will
not allow them to go to this school.
The principal does not believe in not giving holidays to those
children who do not remain at the proper time as it would punish the
staff as well by keeping them away.
I would refer you to the last annual report from the School
where they thank me for assistance my kindness and attention
in all matters connected with the School, and Mr Paget will no
doubt remember the flowery letter of thanks I got from the Principal
and Staff of the School last Xmas this was a personal letter to me
and was written by Mr Paget returned it to me.
There have been three new Indians at the School since I
have been at this Agency, I do not know why so many changes.
Constable on several occasions had to make trip to get
runaway children back to this school last summer.
I wish to assure the Department that this Office does the best
possible in every way to assist the Kenora School and does not make
any distinction or show any favoritism to the other school, the whole
trouble lies in the management of the school or some grievance the
Indians have against it.
I have asked the Parish Priest Father Larentie and also several
People round if they would not take more interest in this School
as things were not going well, but it does no good.
Mr Ferrier might take a trip here and he could inspect this
School and the one at Shoal Lake, and we might then find out where
the trouble is.
