In reply to your letter No 129-1-10 of 18th instant, re complaint re Kenora Industrial School.

I have had an interview with the Principal, and he gives me a few observations he has made since he has been at the School about one month.

He says:

1. There seems to be someone inciting the Indians settled close by the School to agitate against us, to have meetings calculated to give us trouble &c. Reasons, Children not allowed to go home as often as they like, and we do not do here what is done at Shoal Lake. There is someone constituted in authority & desiring secrecy urging them to send their children to Shoal Lake.

2. Asks me to give School support to the children who have not returned to School from holidays back and also to get new pupils. Indian Agent in last 15 years have only brought 3 new pupils to the School.

3. The Indian policeman seems to be unable to bring back the children to the School; would Mr Edwards ask the Mounted Police to help.

4. Is Mr Edwards prepared to punish any fellow carrying stories against the school, i.e., that we are illusing the children, and that there is always some sickness at the School.

5. I will never go to any meeting of the Indians.

6. Why is it difficult to educate the children here, (a) They are too young when they begin to come to School, (b) Their holidays are too long, (c) They are too much in contact with their parents.

In connection with the above:

1. The Principal cannot give me any idea who he refers to, but says it is not the Agent or anyone in this office, it may be the Chief, but he cannot find out who it is, but knows there must be someone or there would not be so much trouble.

Last summer the Principal on his asking me was instructed to allow the parents to take their children to see their children only during holidays and after school hours, he was also told that he need not let the children out of School to see their parents unless he wished to, as in my opinion the Agent had nothing to do with how he ran the School provided it was run according to the laws and wishes of the Department as laid down in their publications and if there was any trouble he was to let me know. This I may say now is the first complaint from the School I have received.

There is no one to my knowledge inciting the children to go to Cecilia Jeffrey School instead of this.

2. All support possible is given to the School from this office and many children have been indirectly sent back to the School through myself and my constable. In fact Hansen has made trips by canoe and train 40 and 50 miles to see Indians who had not seen their children back, and we have brought children back on the boat from the Reserve for the School, but of course have not landed them at the School door. The Mounted Police could not do any more than Constable Hansen has done, but the Principal might be allowed if he asks us for help and does not get it to employ the Mounted Police.

3. I am always prepared to punish any one who carries tales that are untrue, against the School, if the Principal will bring them or some with them before me, but he does not seem willing to do this as I asked him today, the other day who had a complaint to come to the School with the Priest, the Indians turned and said the Priest would not come, so when I saw the Principal he said he said he would not come with any Indian, he would not lower himself, but if I had asked him to bring the Indian it would be alright.

4. I have asked the Principal to come with me to the Reserve on the 2nd, and meet the Indians and we could get at what all the trouble was, but he would not do so, he would meet an Indian at
Sir,

In reference to my letter of the 23rd ult re Kenora Industrial School.

On 2nd instant after the payments, I had a long conference with the Indians and asked their complaints against this School. The main points were that the new Principal was too rough with the children and would not listen to the Indians when they came to the School. He went to the Indian houses with a gun, and frightened them, that he carries a knotted noose with him for the purpose of hitting the pupils.

I visited the School next day and discussed these points with the Principal and he informed me that he was not too rough with the children, but that the discipline was so bad he had to be very strict, he did not use the gun to frighten the Indians, and he did not often use the noose.

The staff at the School did not seem to think the Principal was too strict, and said that more discipline was needed. The last Principal was too lenient.

There have been 7 children run away from this School during the last few days; they have all been brought back by Constable Hansen with the exception of one, who has not yet been located; these children are not sent to the School and we were lucky enough to get them when the Indians came to pay.

The Principal explained to me that the late Principal used to go round and get the children back himself, but he could not do so as it cost too much, I explained he should do his share and not expect the Department to pay everything, but he seemed to think that was entirely the Agents duty and also that it was only the Agents duty to get the children and not the Church or School.

On questioning the children it appears they all ran away because they were afraid of being punished for something wrong they had done.

In conclusion I may say that the Principal was overzealous and is very nervous and excitable and this may be the cause of the trouble. In my opinion another Principal in his place might help matters as the Indians here are very indignant and do not like this man although I believe he is doing what he considers is the best.

The same Indians used to come round at all hours, now he has specified hours, and he has also stopped the Indians from camping on the School property, this is alright but I do not think he has enough tact in his dealings with the Indians, and is making the same changes too suddenly.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.

P.S. The Principal and myself are very friendly, but I do not approve of the way he making these radical changes. One of the runaway children informed me that the teacher had told him if he reported anything to me he would be thrashed.
Ottawa, October 10, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letters of the 23rd ultimo and 4th instant, both referring to general conditions at the Kenora Boarding School. I have to thank you for your detailed report and for the assistance you have given the institution at this time.

In the light of your explanations, the Department is convinced that you have done your duty at this school, and that the difficulties arise due to a lack of confidence on the part of the Indians of the band. I might inform you that the Deputy Superintendent General is communicating with Rev. Father Boys, of Winnipeg, in an effort to remedy conditions.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

October 26th, 1922

574107

Honorable Sir,

The question of taking back to the Kenora Boarding School No. 78 Arthur Mutchener and No. 131 Adelard Savoie, having been brought up again, I must state:

1. That these two boys have a very bad record in our school and have caused a great deal of trouble to the staff on account of their personal character and of their influence on the other pupils.

2. That on the 12th instant it was decided between Inspector Bennett, the Indian Agent and myself that we are going to send these undesirable pupils to the Chief Indian Industrial School.

I do not think it would be wise to change this decision and was announced publicly by Inspector Bennett and the Indian Agent to all the pupils and staff of the school.

3. That I feel sure this transfer shall prove beneficial to the above named boys and shall save our institution from many more bad influences as they are so now convinced.

I am sure this will meet with your approval.

I remain, Honorable Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, Oct. 30, 1922.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, informing the Department of your wish to transfer No. 78 Arthur Mushenow and No. 131 Adelaide Jasine to the Qu'Appelle Industrial School at Lebret, Sask. This request should have been forwarded through the office of Mr. Agent Edwards, whose recommendation would have been attached. The Department has written to Mr. Edwards, advising him that in all matters pertaining to leave or truancy he and yourself should take concerted action, as individual rulings and requests will be sure to result in misunderstandings.

There are but two courses open to the Department in connection with the two boys named above: they must either remain in the school or be discharged. We are not able to authorise a transfer to Lebret. The Indian Act, Section 10 (subsection 1) reads in part: "Provided, however, that such school shall be the nearest available school of the kind required". The advanced age of these boys would also complicate matters if we tried to commit them to another school.

You and Mr. Agent Edwards should decide whether or not these boys are to remain in the Kenora Boarding School. You have the Department's authority to discharge them, if our representative and yourself decide this is in the best interests of the school.

I trust that you will be able to make a satisfactory arrangement and that there will be no more trouble at the institution. A copy of this communication is being addressed to Mr. Agent Edwards.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Rev. C.M. Kerbret, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Boarding School,
Kenora, Ont.

Memorandum.

Honourable Charles Stewart:

I wish to draw to your attention that Mr. A. M. Ross, Box 362, Lenora, Ont., has failed to submit to the Department his valuation of the Lenora Boarding School property. The commission was offered him under date of July 19th, last, and we asked him to kindly undertake the work at his earliest convenience and advantage by wire. On July 27th he accepted the work and on the 28th of the same month wired the Department as follows: "Have made inspection of Lenora Boarding School property and report of valuation will be made within a few days."

On August 24th the Department reminded Mr. Ross that we were waiting for his report. Again on September 22nd we called for the valuation immediately. On October 10th we telegraphed Mr. Ross for his report. He wired, in reply: "Report Lenora Boarding School will be in your hands 17th." On the 30th ultimo we informed Mr. Ross that we would make other arrangements for a valuation of the property in question.

Will you please inform me the name of another resident of Lenora, who is competent to make a valuation of the Lenora Boarding School property.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, Oct. 11, 1922.

Dear Father Boys:

I wish to acquaint you with a situation that has arisen at the Kenora Boarding School. Rev. Father Kerbrat has as yet failed to win the confidence of the Indian band. Several children have run away and have been located by the Indian agent, after some difficulty and considerable expense. The discipline at the school has not been very good, and the present principal has adopted rather severe measures, in an effort to better conditions.

I am convinced that a letter from you to the Rev. Principal, urging him to move slowly and bend every effort to gain the sympathy of the Indian band, would assist at this time. I am directing our agent to cooperate in every way possible with Father Kerbrat. The principal should be informed that it is his duty to assist in the return of runaways and to undertake active recruiting. Discipline must be maintained, but methods should be carefully considered.

I am sure that you will cooperate with this Department, in an effort to improve conditions at the Kenora Boarding School.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Very Rev. F. B. Beys, O.M.I.,
Provincial of the Oblate Order
of Mary Immaculate,
222 Provencher Ave.,

Sir,

The Principal of the Yenorah School telephoned me at 9 a.m. this morning that five of the boys had run away—76, 104, 131, and 101.

Two of the boys #76 and 121 came to my office at three o'clock this afternoon, and said they had run away because they were afraid of being punished by the Principal, and he was always blaming them for things.

I went to the School and saw the Principal who informed me that the only boys he would take back were #116 and 104, and he would not take the others back at all; he said he had applied to someone for permission to send some of the boys to LeBreton Industrial School as he could not manage them.

Under the circumstances I have sent them to my Interpreter's house to be kept until I hear from the Department what is to be done with them.

The boys' ages are 17, 17, 16, 15, and 17. They are almost old enough to be discharged, and one of them had been working on the Government Road at Red-Litt, and getting big wages during his summer holidays; he is old enough to fend for himself.

I shall be glad to receive instructions as to whether they should be sent to another School or discharged. It seems better to me, if we send them to some other School for a few months before discharge, so as to show other boys they cannot run away with impunity.

I may say whilst at the School, I met Mr. Bennett, an Ontario Catholic School Inspector, and discussed the matter with him; he thinks the boys should be sent to another School before discharge.

This School is causing us much trouble and I do not think we can remedy matters until we have a new principal. We cannot get Indians to send their children to the School, whilst under the control of this man.

I may say I do not interfere in any way with the running of the School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir, Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent
Sir,

In reply to your letter No 129-1-1 of 10th instant, re Kenora School.

I had to take an Indian from Assiniboin band who had been accidentally shot to Winnipeg, and whilst there called on Inspector Bunn in reference to the above. Mr Bunn quite approved of the action, I had taken in this matter, and phoned Rev Father Boys of St Boniface, who kindly said he would come to Kenora this week and look into the matter for us and if necessary make a change in the Principal.

Inspector Bunn did not approve of transferring the children the Principal did not want, and thought they should be sent back to the same school, under a principal who could manage them. He quite agreed that as the Indians had not the confidence they should have in the Principal he should be changed.

When Rev Father Boys arrives, I will go into the matter with him and feel sure, we shall have no further trouble.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I have your Numbers 108-12 of the 12th and 15th instant, concerning the discipline at the Kenora Boarding School. I have noted that 5 truant pupils have been held by you, awaiting the Department's instructions.

In the light of your second letter, in which you expect an improvement following Father Bays' visit, I wish to suggest that the 5 boys be returned to the school, but that they should understand that you are supporting the principal in his efforts to maintain discipline and that truancy will not be countenanced. You might address the big boys at the school, with a view to assisting the principal at this time. Their practice of running to your office with their complaints should stop. If they have any troubles, they should be told to you when you are visiting the school.

In all matters pertaining to leave or truancy, the principal and yourself should take concerted action, as individual rulings will be sure to result in misunderstandings.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Honorable Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th inst., re. some trouble in our Kenora Boarding School.

I have lately made a short inspection of that school and gave some instructions to the Principal.

My intention is to follow developments and direct if possible the activities of the new Principal, or replace him and have things go on normally.

I sent the results of my first investigation to Rev. Father Guy, but as I feel the Agent in Kenora shall readily understand our position, I would beg that this report be not communicated to Him.

Yours, faithfully,

[Signature]

J.-B. Bégin

Acting Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

Herewith I beg to enclose my report and valuation of what is known as the Kenora Boarding School, at present owned by the Oblate Order.

This report is contained in the following schedules:

1. Buildings and Land.
2. Machinery, Implements & Miscellaneous Articles.
3. Furniture and Furnishings.
4. Livestock.

In connection with this report and valuation I would say that the property has been carefully and thoroughly examined and found to be in good condition, less the ordinary wear and tear. The situation of the school is ideal for the purpose for which it is used, being of easy access by both land and water. When making my investigation I found that this establishment was well managed and the property had all the ear-marks of careful superintendence.

In my detailed valuation I have endeavored to be fair and reasonable to all concerned and have given due consideration to the wear and tear wherever necessary. In reference to the Buildings and Land Schedule, I would say that I have omitted one frame house as it had no commercial value whatever. This is a building that is the furthest removed of any from the school building proper, and to all appearances had been abandoned.
OTTAWA, November 15th, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge your letter of the 10th instant, enclosing your report and valuation of the Kenora Indian Boarding School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Sir:

I have to inform you that arrangements are being made for the purchase of the property at the Kenora Indian Boarding School. Will you ask the Rev. principal for a description of the 118 acres to which the Oblate Fathers hold title. Your early attention to this matter is requested.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Sir,

Confirming telephone conversation had with an officer of your Department today, I have the honour to state that the Minister of Justice has authorized the employment of Mr. H.A.C. Machin, Barrister, Kenora, Ont., in connection with the searching of the title to some land at that place.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

In reply to your letter #129-1-1 of 15th instant, The Principal cannot give me exact particulars of the boundary of the 118 acres, but says the land is divided up about as follows:

Land cleared (broken and cultivated) 3 acres.
Pasture 15 "
Ready for breaking 2 "

Land covered with small brush and timber 25 "
Wood land (stony, hilly woodland) 35 "
(50 acres) (fit for cultivation) 15 "
Swamp, most of it covered with willows about 23 "

This swamp will make hay land if cleared and properly drained.

118 acres.

The Principal also informs me that there is also an additional 45 acres, owned by the Oblate Fathers, on which the School is built, of this about 6 acres is cultivated; the balance is hilly, stoney land lightly wooded; if cleared about 10 acres would be suitable for grazing.

I was unofficially informed a few days ago that this property has been valued at about $60,000 if this is so, in my opinion it is a high valuation.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, Nov. 28, 1922.

Sir:

I have your No. 108-12 of the 22nd instant, relative to the property of the Kenora Boarding School. I have noted that the principal cannot give you a proper description and that there is an additional 45 acres to which title is held by the Oblate Fathers, on which the school is built. Your opinion that $60,000 is a high valuation for the property has been noted.

In reply I wish to inform you that the Oblate representative in Ottawa assures us that copies of the deeds to the Kenora Boarding School property have been directed to you from Winnipeg and should be in your office about this date. I am therefore requesting again that you will give a proper description, by metes and bounds, of both parcels of land owned by the Oblate Fathers.

It appears, after an examination of our files, that the block which was surrendered by the Indian band in January 1917 comprises 115.8 acres. The other parcel is roughly 45 acres and is the site of the school. The Department would be pleased if you could give a proper description of both these blocks, after an examination of the deeds.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, Nov. 28, 1922.

Sir:-

I have to refer to the first page of your report on the valuation of the Kenora Boarding School. You have mentioned 116 acres of land, 15 of which is cleared. Immediately following this statement there are two items of 15 acres cleared and 113 acres uncleared. This would make a total acreage of 128.

Further, the Department is of the opinion that the above refers to a parcel of land that was originally part of the Indian reserve. You have not mentioned in your valuation the block of 45 acres more or less, which is the site of the school.

The Department is not asking that you go to any trouble further in this matter, but I would be pleased to have an explanation of the difference in the figures referring to the first block of land and an explanation why the parcel of land upon which the school stands is omitted from your report.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aest. Deputy & Secretary.

A. M. Ross, Esq.,
P. O. Box 382,
Kenora, Ont.
MEMO FOR FILE:

Father Guy believes that Mr. Agent Edwards has by this time a copy of the title to the Kenora Boarding School property. The Department of Justice has given us the name of the lawyer in Kenora who can be given the searching of the title.

Before this is done, I believe the valuator, Mr. Rose, should be more definite regarding the land that belongs to the school. I understand that there are two parcels - one of 118.8 acres acquired in January 1917 after a surrender by the Indian Band (Res. No. 38 B.) The price was at $5.00 an acre, or $594. I have pointed out to Father Guy that very little work has been done on this property since it was acquired by the Oblate Fathers (15 acres is cleared) but that the valuator has offered the figure $9400.00. The other block of land is roughly 60 acres; it is on the edge of the lake and is the site of the school. The valuator did not mention this parcel in his report.

I am writing Mr. Agent Edwards, explaining these facts and asking him to give the lawyer the commission of searching the title which secures a proper description to both parcels.

Mr. Moffat should be asked, after the title has been searched, to prepare an O.C. for the authority to purchase. Lastly, it may be necessary to secure the Receiver General's Check as the amount is in excess of $25,000.00.

[Signature]

P.S. To Guy: Letter 159 a. in all.

Ottawa, 12th December, 1912.

Sir,

This Department proposes purchasing from Lee Roy, C.S. Obleto de Immaculate Conception, his interest in the Kenora school property, consisting of land, school and farm buildings, boat house, wharf and all other structures on said land, together with all equipment, furniture, furnishings, machinery, implements, miscellaneous articles and livestock now in use in connection with this Institution. I am enclosing a copy of a letter dated the last instant, from our agent at Kenora, Ontario, Mr. Frank Edwards, describing the terms of the transaction. The sale is to be executed on the parcel firstly described to be 34,100 acres conveyed on the 27th January, 1911, to Thomas Ryan. I am also enclosing list of the real estate, furniture and furnishings, etc., included in this purchase.

It is desired that you have your agent at Kenora search the title to the property in question and submit a draft transfer of the same to His Majesty's representative by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs with his report to you in this matter. The purchase price of the entire property is $40,000.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant, Deputy and Secretary,
The Dept. Minister of Justice,
Ottawa.

In the title, known as Transfer 553.1k and Parcel No.22, the acreage of this property is not given but my map shows it as 51 acres which, in all probability, includes the 5½ acres sold to Mr. Ryan, thus leaving approximately 45 acres of what might be called the school site property, and in my opinion the 45 acres is the most valuable portion of the land holdings of the Reverend Fathers. This is because of the fact of it having such a large water frontage. Notwithstanding, I have made my valuation along most reasonable lines and am putting the 45 acres in at $150.00 an acre, although the 5½ acres were, I believe, sold to Mr. Ryan at about $350.00 per acre. This acreage of course has a very large water frontage which, no doubt, accounts for the price received for it.

In further reference to these land holdings, I would like to say that the school site property itself will become an exceedingly valuable one and would be, in fact, at present of considerable value in the event of the property being put up for sale, as it lends itself to the requirements of the summer tourist, and in all probability, if it were put on the open market today, this land and buildings thereon would be readily saleable. Notwithstanding this, I have endeavored to put a fair and reasonable value on the property as a whole as I possibly could.

I am correcting pages 1 and 4 of my first report which, I trust, will explain my error and be satisfactory to you and, therefore, I am enclosing you a completed detailed report, in duplicate, as corrected.

I would at this time state that in the detailed list of Furniture and Furnishings in my first report, I overlooked stating to you that I omitted, and still omit, the Furniture and Furnishings of the Chapel contained in the school proper and used for religious services, as I was not informed as to whether these were to be included with all of the

Extract from letter of 3rd January 1923 received from Indian Agent Edwards, Kenora, Ont.

Had a busy time last week. Xmas day at Kenora School giving out toys and prizes. We had a Xmas tree and every child got a toy & some candles. I gave special prizes to the best boy, the best boy writer, the best girl singer and the best girls fancy work, they did not cost much and gave a lot of pleasure to the children.

On Thursday, I got the Manager of the Y.M.C.A. to take his small moving picture out with him and we gave the children a show. Quite a lot of the older Indians were there and enjoyed it, many of them had never seen moving pictures before.

I am President of the Kenora Boy Scouts and on Saturday took 27 of them for a snowshoe walk to the reserve and the School, where the Principal gave them tea, and we intended to have a shooting match (C.C.'s) but the weather was too bad snowing, so we are going to take them there some other time and have a hockey match, the Boy Scouts against the Indian Children, and shooting match after. I think it makes better feeling to get the white children take an interest in the Indians and it makes the Indians less shy.

The Priest was very pleased and wants me to get literature and he may start a troop at the school, as they have one at LeBreton. He wants to know if we could get the Government to let us have some educational films occasionally for these moving picture machines as he believes different departments supply them free, and they are of great educational value. Mr. Mercer of the Y.M.C.A. will take out his machine and show them occasionally if we get the films. The only cost I believe will be the express on the films. Do you know where we can get them? I understand some firm in Winnipeg distributes them they could come down here one day and be sent back a couple of days after.

If this could be worked, perhaps it might pay to buy a machine for the School, and it could be used by the Cecelia Jeffrey School occasionally when they get the electric light in. The machines I understand cost about $50.00 or $60.00. This is only a suggestion.

The Principal at the School, is improving and the Indians are beginning to think more of him, he has a mess of things at the start, but after getting called down by myself and the Priest from St. Boniface, he changed his ways and I present years to be doing good work.

What amount was put in the Estimates for the School at Polling Portage last year, and have the Church promised to do anything?

(Sgd) Frank Edwards
Ottawa, January 8, 1923.

Sir:

Mr. Paget of this Department has brought to our attention your unofficial report on the Christmas activities at the Kenora Boarding School. The Rev. Principal and yourself are to be congratulated on the interesting programme arranged for the children in residence. I have noted that educational films could be used to advantage, and I regret to inform you that no Government department has for distribution pictures suitable for a school. However, if you make application to the University of Manitoba, or the University of Toronto, I am convinced that their Extension Departments may be of some assistance in this connection.

I am pleased to learn that the Rev. Principal has been more successful in winning the confidence of the Indians of the vicinity.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Memorandum

Supt. Indian Affairs,

It appears from the correspondence on file that the Department is about to purchase the property of the Kenora Boarding School and included in the property is a part of approximately 113 acres which was acquired from the Department. Patent has been issued embodying a description compiled from information supplied by the school authorities. The school authorities are now endeavouring to register this patent with the local registrar who informs the Department that he cannot complete registration as the description is not sufficient. I agree with the Registrar on this point and to provide a correct description it would be necessary to have a survey made of the property.

I consider that instead of either the Oblate Fathers or the Department going to the expense of having this survey made the old patent cancelled and new patent issued and registered it would be more advisable and I think legally sufficient to acquire title to this particular portion of the property by requesting the return of the patent issued by the Department and also Quit-Claim from the Oblate Fathers any interest they may have in said parcel. Should this procedure be adopted, no further action need be taken on the Registrar's letter other than the withdrawal by the Oblate Fathers of their application for the registration of the patent.

It is noted in the valuation prepared by A.M. Ross (see ref. No.57537 hereunder) that he included in the property lot 113 acres of land which he states is known as the East part of Section 11 and part of K.16. The sketch plan accompanying his report shows the correct location of L.8 and K.16 and it is apparent that the 113 acre parcel transferred by this Department cannot be considered as being in either of the above mentioned locations. I have indicated its correct position in pencil on his sketch.

Chief Surveyor.
Kenora, Canada
January 4th, 1923.

The Deputy Minister of Justice,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 15th instant (189-1-1), it is to be observed that the provision for cancellation contained in section 70 of the Indian Act contemplates the issue of amended letters patent, so that it does not seem to apply to a case like the present where the intention is that the land should remain vested in His Majesty. Moreover, if the method you suggest were adopted we would have no means of satisfying ourselves that no mortgage had been given or other dealings had with regard to these lands during the period they were vested in the Oblate Fathers. Unless, therefore, your Department is willing to accept the assurance of the present owners that no encumbrance has been created or other dealing had in connection with these lands since the letters patent, I think it would be better to have a new survey made and clear up all outstanding questions at the present time.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Memorandum.

Mr. MacInnes:

It is the wish of the Deputy to secure the permission of Council to make a payment of $48,000 to the Roman Catholic Church, in connection with the transfer of the Kenora Boarding School to the Crown. Arrangements for the purchase of the property, including buildings, other improvements, live stock, chattels and effects, have been completed by the Department of Justice, whose agents have found satisfactory title to the land in question, known as parcels 22 and 8666 in the Kenora Land Titles Office.

Funds in this connection were appropriated by Parliament in the Supplementary Estimates, 1922-23. The Kenora Boarding School is modern, well equipped and adequate for the purposes of Indian education. It is the policy of the present Government to meet capital expense attendant upon the education of its wards. An independent valuator has mentioned $67,593.50 as the value of the Kenora Indian Boarding School.

This Department wishes to have the concurrence of His Excellency in Council in our proposal to arrange for a Receiver General's cheque for $48,000, payable to Les Rev. Peres Oblats de immaculate Conception and the Department of Justice's agent, jointly.

[Signature]

R.J.F.
Ottawa, February 28, 1923.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned begs to report that it is considered desirable by the Department of Indian Affairs to acquire the Kenora Indian Boarding School from the Roman Catholic Church. Arrangements for the purchase of the property, including buildings, other improvements, live stock, chattels and effects, have been completed by the Department of Justice, whose Agents have found satisfactory title to the land in question, known as parcels 22 and 6666 in the Kenora Land Titles Office.

The Kenora Boarding School is modern, well equipped and adequate for the purposes of Indian education. The property has been valued at approximately $67,000.00

Under the arrangement between the Department and the Church authorities, the purchase price for the entire school property has been fixed at $48,000.00, and funds for this purpose were provided for in the Supplementary Estimates 1922-23, Vote No. 546. It is proposed to apply for the Receiver General's cheque for the said sum of $48,000.00 payable to the Oblate Fathers of the Immaculate Conception and the Agent of the Department of Justice jointly.

The undersigned would accordingly recommend that this expenditure receive the approval of Your Excellency in Council.

[Signature]

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 28th February, 1923, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that it is considered desirable by the Department of Indian Affairs to acquire the Kenora Indian Boarding School from the Roman Catholic Church. Arrangements for the purchase of the property, including buildings, other improvements, live stock, chattels and effects, have been completed by the Department of Justice, whose Agents have found satisfactory title to the land in question, known as parcels 22 and 6666 in the Kenora Land Titles Office.

The Kenora Boarding School is modern, well equipped and adequate for the purposes of Indian education. The property has been valued at approximately $67,600.

Under the arrangement between the Department and the Church authorities, the purchase price for the entire school property has been fixed at $48,000, and funds for this purpose were provided for in the Supplementary Estimates 1922-23, Vote No 546. It is proposed to apply for the Receiver General's cheque for the said sum of $48,000 payable to the Oblate Fathers of the Immaculate Conception and the Agent of the Department of Justice jointly.

The Honourable

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs

MEMO FOR FILE:

I visited the Kainai Lubicon Residential School about the 28th and 29th of July. The Rev. Principal is an extremely nervous type, due, I believe, to overseas experience. I have reported to Father Guy that his position is not fair to him, as the details and noises of an institution are somewhat wearing on the nerves. He is doing as well as can be expected and is ably assisted by a Lay Brother, who is a host in himself.

The management is continually bothered in the summer by the parents wishing to take their children home. For the past eight years they have taken a two months' holiday. This should be looked into. The Sisters are French, but have fairly good English at their command. I intend to look up the qualifications of Sister Gregoire, who was formerly at Qu'Appelle.

The dormer roof outside sash and doors of the main building require paint. This should be attended to in 1925. The work on the barn is going forward with despatch and I authorized an expenditure of $160 for a hay fork and track in the loft. A confirming letter should go forth if the account is not in.

I promised favourable consideration for cement, to be used for flooring a 40 x 15 ft. henhouse which has been infested by rats. Mr. Orr estimates 10 bbl. cement, at an estimated cost of $45, are required.

I also promised that 6 enamel tubs would be sent for the laundry. The management will be responsible for installing them. They have absolutely no suitable equipment of this kind.

The following equipment and repairs will be required in the near future:

1. Lumber for an addition to the implement shed.
2. A drain from the school to the barn to carry water. I believe they have the pipe already.
3. A 10 horse power motor for cutting wood and pumping water. (City electric power is used and the water supply is from the lake to 2 pressure tanks.)
4. 25 bbl. cement for a retaining wall around the water tank.
5. A metal wall in the boys' playroom.
6. A dryer and steam boiler required. (The washing machine is equipped for steam.)
7. The eaves at the rear of the main building need enlarging.
8. A proper root cellar is required.

The school has very little opportunity for farming, as it is situated on rock, at the edge of the lake. They have a good boat for transportation to and from the city of Hanna and the reserves.
Kenora Ont. Sept 23rd - 1924

Dear Sir,

In regard to the management of this Indian Industrial School that you maintain here, I think it is time some investigation into the management of the Institution should be made. From complaints that come to me, it seems to me that the mode of punishment that is being adopted is inhumane and barbarous, and should not be tolerated in any civilized community.

Chief Pines granddaughter from Big Island and another girl Mary Robinson and another whose name I have not got were first whipped and beaten by the Priest and then their hands tied together and their feet tied together, and four of them put in the cellar and kept there for 4 hours. And the one the chief's grandchild was shut up the the toilet (an outhouse) with her hands and feet tied together. And this kind of humiliation was continued for 4 days. This happened in May last. The Sabaaskong Indians reported this to the Indian Agent Captain Frank Edwards and asked him to investigate this thing. But the Agent has never done anything.

Minakijikat

#83 at Sudbury

Acknowledged this little letter 1/8

I believe the Principal is doing his best, but he is too nervous (he is suffering from shell shock) for the position of Principal of this school, and I would suggest that he be given a rest and another man take his place, one who would make himself more friendly with the Indians.

The Indians here object to sending their children to this school, and the school register shows the difficulty experienced in getting the pupils back from their holidays. The Principal, owing to shell shock has not got that human touch that appeals to these people.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

P.S. Mr. Harris met the Principal which he was inspecting the School and can give you his opinion.

Please refer to my letter 23rd April 1922.
Sir,

Referring to your letter 129-1-1 of the 30th ult., enclosing letter from #63 Assabaska Band, which letter in my opinion was written for this Indian by an educated white man.

The woman, #63 Assabaska (Sabastong) is the mother of two children #090 and #0125 pupils at Kenora Residential School, and she is living with a half breed Joe LaPointe or Sabeska.

Josephine the eldest child refused even to go with her mother for the holidays, but Mary, the youngest did. Owing to Mary not returning to the school after the holidays I had to send the Constable after her and wrote her to the office to see why she had not returned back to school. As the mother made certain accusations against the school I allowed them to bring Col. Macdonald, barrister, to my office and we went into the whole matter and decided there was nothing very serious in it.

If you will refer to my previous letters you will see that the Indians complained of the Priest hitting the children, and he promised me not to administer corporal punishment.

On April 28th last five girls ran away from the school and at night came to my house, as it was then too late to send them back to school. I allowed them to sleep at the Agency, and gave them their breakfast the next morning going back to the school afterwards that day. The children informed me they had nothing against the school but ran away because they were not allowed to play with Chief Pine's grand daughter.

The Indians inform me that he left Kenora for Winnipeg at 10 o'clock A.M. on April 29th last, and that none of the children were whipped or beaten, but he is informed as we did not want corporal punishment administered. Two of the children were locked in the cellar and two others locked in other places for about 2 hours and they had their hands tied together.

Chief Pine's grand daughter used to shut herself up in the dormitory toilet at night to vex the Sister in charge, and was therefore shut up in the same toilet for about 2 hours as a punishment. This toilet is inside the building and not an outhouse. Her hands and feet were loosely tied and she got them free long before the 2 hours were up. This humiliation occurred only once, not 4 days as stated.
Ottawa, October 20, 1924.

October 22nd 1934

Sir,

Attention Mr. Carrier,

Referring to Department letter 129-1-1 of Sept. 30th and my reply thereto of the 8th inst., I took this matter up with the Principal of the Kenora School, and on 17th inst. he wrote me the following extract from his letter of that date:

"We have the right to punish pupils and we will punish them whenever we think it necessary or useful to do so; the false reports spread broadcast against us of late will not prevent us from punishing any pupil that deserves punishment."

The above extract was the Principal's reply to a request I made of him for information as to what punishment if any had been given to the two Benning boys who recently ran away from school.

On the 20th inst. I replied to the Principal's letter above quoted extract from his letter is as follows:

"You will remember some time ago Indians complained of being threatened and hit for trivial offenses, and now a report goes in connection with children having had their hands and feet tied, and having been locked up in the cellar for several hours. There was a considerable amount of truth in these allegations, and in my opinion this is partly the cause of the difficulty experienced in getting the children to return to school after holidays, and also in getting new pupils to attend school.

I do not wish to interfere with the working of the school, but on receipt of complaints it is my duty to investigate them and see that the school is carried on in the right manner, as even although the principal is appointed by the Church, he has to meet with the approval of the Department."

On the 22nd inst. the Principal replies to the foregoing extract from his letter as follows:

"As for our difficulties with the local agent I leave it to the Indian Department and the Church authorities to settle them as best they can.

From the above it will be noted that the Principal appears to be very displeased with me, and I am writing this for your information. I can assure you I have given every assistance to the Principal in helping to get the pupils back to the school, and also in all other matters relative to the school's welfare.

The Assistant Deputy Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent."

IS SUICIDE VICTIM AFTER KILLING MEN

Indian Boarding School Scene of Murderous Assault.

KENORA, Ont., Feb. 12.—Brother A. Pollnaire d'Amour, assistant principal of the Indian boarding school here, was shot dead, and Joe Bernicott, a hired man, was severely wounded by Fransois Balou, employee of the institution, early this morning. After his murderous assault, Balou ended his own life with the same weapon.

Authorities investigating the crime are unable to assign any reason for the killing, as there had been no quarrel and no other indication of trouble. It is believed that the murderer had gone temporarily insane. Bernicott, who was wounded in the jaw, is expected to recover.

Bernicott and Balou, according to the school account, were engaged with their duties in the stable and after milking the cows Balou left with two pails in the direction of the school. Bernicott thought he was being murdered, but on turning around he saw Balou pointing a gun in his direction.

The next moment Bernicott was struck on the side of the face with the full charge of the short gun. The wounded man rushed toward the school, followed by his assailant. Just before reaching the building Balou stopped to reload the weapon, and when Brother d'Amour interceded, the latter was stabbed with a shot through the left eye. He died instantly.
IS SUICIDE VICTIM AFTER KILLING MEN

Indian Boarding School Scene of Murderous Assault.

KENORA, Ont., Feb. 15.—Brother A. Pelletier d'Amour, assistant principal of the Indian boarding school here, was shot dead, and Joe Bernicott, a hired man, was severely wounded by Francois Salou, employee of the institution, early this morning. After his murderous assault, Salou ended his own life with the same weapon.

Authorities investigating the crime are unable to assign any reason for the attack, as there had been no trouble and no prior indication of trouble. It is believed that the murderer had gone temporarily insane. Bernicott, who was wounded in the jaw, is expected to recover.

Bernicott and Salou, according to the testimony, were engaged with their duties at the school when after milking the cows Salou left with two pails in the direction of the school. Bernicott thought he was long in returning but, looking around, he encountered Salou pointing a gun in his direction.

The next moment, Bernicott was struck on the side of the face with the full charge of the short gun. The wounded man rushed toward the school, followed by his assailant. Just before reaching the building, Salou stopped to reload his gun. When Brother d'Amour intervened, the latter was silenced with a shot through the left side. He died instantly.
Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter 12th February 1925, informing me of the appointment of Mr. Ferguson as Principal of the Kenora Residential School in place of Mr. Herbert resigned.

I received word this morning that a murder had been committed at the School, so I went there with my constable and Coroner Annie. Our Medical Officer Mr. D. Ferguson was already there with the Provincial and Town Police.

It appears that a man named Francis Selou shot at Mr. Bernicot in the barn (these men were rummaging through the School). Bernicot was badly wounded in the left cheek, he ran away from the barn and into the School, brother Albert Selou (who has been at the School over 17 years, and is well thought of) came out of the School and called out for his brother about, and Bernicot ran round him. Selou again, took another and apparently severely hit, shot the brother in the head, killing him immediately. Selou then appeared to have disappeared for some time, and the police were searching for him, but without success. The time I quoted was only a guess made on the basis of information that he was found two rummages about 100 yards in the bush, it appeared that when he found himself locked for he committed suicide by shooting himself.

The inquest will be held tomorrow, no active steps yet taken for the murder.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Rev. Father J. Terreault, C.M.I., is here and is taking over the Kenora School.

I presume the above transfers meet with the approval of the Department.

Father Terreault has only been in charge at Kenora for a short time, but I would like you to note that his work here has been very good, so as attesting the good feelings of the Indians, who is in every way so improving under the late Principal Rev. Terreault.

There is no doubt in my mind that Father Terreault is in every way fully fitted for the difficult task of starting a new school.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edward,

Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, April 25, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, with reference to the appointment of principals at the Kenora and McIntosh Indian Residential Schools. The Department has just received from the Very Rev. J. B. Boys, O.M.I., 340 Provencher Ave., St. Boniface, Man., an intimation concerning these appointments and approval has been given. I note, with satisfaction, that the Rev. Father Perreault has given splendid service at the Kenora institution. I trust that the new principal for Kenora, the Rev. J. M. Baillargeon, O.M.I., who has had previous experience at this class of school, will meet with much success.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
J. M. BENNETT, M.A.
Inspector of Separate Schools

Toronto,

Could a few of the worst trouble be transferred by Indian Agents order to some far away Indian schools? The school hasn't much control of the Indians. The Agent knows their haunts and children make him responsible for placing them in residence and for truants and the matter will be settled. If an Indian agent does not do his duty when he understands he should be removed. The Education of the Indians should be his greatest interest. Agent Lewis and some still I have met sure do deserve praise and credit for what they do.

Other schools have no trouble on this matter. Why should "enera" rather than that the Indian children growing up should have the idea that school teachers are there simply to turn the school into a day school and let the parents send them when they like.

An Indian agent who will show the Parents that he supports the school every time.

The agent to place the children in residence and see that they stay and if necessary teach them a lesson by transferring them to another schools.

Or an attendance officer with better beat responsible for it. However I feel it to be the Agent's Duty and only he will accomplish a result. He is the only one that has any control over the Indians.

Or it may be like at Spadina. It is situated far from the reserves. Transfer most of the enerera children to some other school and bring outsiders to Kenora.

The school authorities have enough to do to instruct and develop the children under their charge. Remove these hindrances which make the Indians feel that the teachers are not there for Indians or else how will the rising generation of them have these Christian principles necessary for citizenship?

I am rather late in sending this but it is caused by a natural hesitancy on my part in sending such to you since most likely it is outside my business. But conditions in Kenora are certainly not what they should be and it is not asked the fault of the school authorities.

Do what you can but write a letter as confidential. I trust you will find a solution.

Yours sincerely,
Toronto, Nov. 18th 1925

The Secretary,
Dept. Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir; -

I intended to write you before now concerning some conditions existing in connection with the Kenora Boarding School. I would like this to be treated as confidential and whatever you can do in the matter will be appreciated.

On the day following my last visit there I again called over to the school to see the principal since he was not present at my visit. I seldom tell them in advance. Kenora school is too close to the children's home and is in urgent need of a truant officer. Unless this is done then I cannot see how the authorities in charge can keep a regular attendance and spirit of work.

All school authorities cannot be responsible for gathering the pupils and reclaiming runaway pupils. The Indian Agent, say in Kenora, is the one who knows these Indians and where they live. He only has the roll and knows those of school age. He should place these children in residence and so govern their parents that they will recognize the law. The school authorities are at the mercy of Indian criticism and the school looked upon as a jail while the Indian Agent stands aloof.

Why should this be so? Why should the school have to gather the pupils? Why should the school be placed in the position of a truant officer and seek those that the Department wishes to train and educate? Why should the school authorities have to pay dearly seeking the country side and lakes for runaways when there is a Department meter beat at Kenora which could be used for that purpose. I feel that if the Indian Agent at Kenora had upheld the school authority and show the Indians that he stands behind the school things would not be as difficult in this school. A few years ago when many ran away, I personally knew that Mr. Edwards in deliberately taking the part of a sort of Judge between the truants and the school authorities publically, did more to disrupt the organization of this school than you maybe are aware of. A principle in Education is this. School authority must be upheld. No wonder the Indians have no respect for authority around Kenora. If this school has trouble today it can be traced to its source.

The only authority the Indian knows is that of the the Agent. Now in the case of Kenora, if he would place the children in residence, go after truants and teach respect for authority the whole situation would be remedied. But when Indians know he will take their part or ignore things what can you expect. Authority and discipline cannot remain in Kenora until these Indians are taught a lesson.
Ottawa, November 24, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to Mr. Indian Agent Edwards and his relationship to the Kenora Indian Residential School. Your suggestions and recommendations have been noted and will receive consideration when decisions affecting our work at this school are being made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. M. Bennett, B.A., M.A.,
Inspector of Separate Schools,
47 Browning Ave.,
Toronto, Ont.
EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR BENNETT,
dated March 9th, 1927, on the Kenora
Indian Residential School.

"There is another problem that this school
has to contend with. Whole families come regularly
to see children and when they are sick. They squat
for days near the school and, considering it to be
their perfect right, they demand to be fed. They
must be fed or they are offended and get real mad.
Naturally, the school doesn't want to antagonize
these people or they will lose the children. The
Indians feel it is Government money that pays all.
It is a problem. Have you anything to suggest?"
Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

My Dear Mr. Scott:

Rev. Fr. J.E. Baillargeon O.M.I., Principal of Kenora Indian Residential School, has requested me to bring to your attention a rather peculiar situation.

His children are bound to return to school on the 15th inst but it is a certain fact that the largest number of them (if not all) will not be brought back by their parents. The "blueberry season" is very late this year and as blueberry picking is the main money earning medium for the Indians of the district during Summer, all hands must be used with the conclusion that none of the parents will agree to bring back their children to school. That reason would seem frivolous in our civilized quarters but, the Indians it is peremptory.

On the other hand, the Principal cannot afford to lose any per capita grant on account of the many difficulties he has to struggle with. Of course, it might be objected that the Principal should have sent the children home a fortnight later. To this he would answer that he could not foresee the lateness of the season and secondly that the Indians, specially those around large centers were keen to have their children with them in order to allow them to participate in the celebrations attending the Diamond Jubilee of the Confederation.

The Principal has asked me to respectfully lay the whole situation before you with the request that for this present year the holiday term be extended 15 days for the children of his school, per capita grant being allowed meanwhile. You will kindly communicate your answer to the Rev. Principal and if you think in order to advise me at Gravelbourg.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Library and Archives Canada / Bibliothèque et Archives Canada
www.collectionscanada.gc.ca
Ottawa, August 12th, 1927.

Reverend Sir,

Rev. Father Guy has written with reference to difficulty you anticipate in the matter of the return of the pupils to the Kenora Indian Residential School following their annual leave. You will understand that the Department does not like to establish a precedent by allowing longer holidays with grant and I am requesting both you and Mr. Indian Agent Edwards to make every effort to have the pupils returned to school as soon as possible. When the quarterly return is being forwarded to the Department, both Mr. Edwards and yourself should make a report in the matter for the Department's guidance.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J.E. Beallargeon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.

Indian Commissioner,

Sir,

I beg to enclose a letter from Rev. J.U. Poltras, dated 24th June, with enclosures respecting the Roman Catholic Boarding School in course of erection at Rat Portage.

The plans were submitted to me by His Grace the Archbishop of St. Boniface on the 18th instant on the train between St. Albert and Calgary. To prevent the money lapsing the plans being suitable I authorized His Grace to direct that the materials be bought and work commenced immediately.

The amount of appropriation for this school is $2,500 and as the building proposed to be erected as per plans approved by me (copy of which will be forwarded as soon as can be procured) will cost over $3,000, I would recommend that the total sum appropriated for the purpose be paid direct to His Grace the Archbishop of St. Boniface with the understanding that the building will be completed this summer in accordance with the plans approved by me, the Church assuming the cost over and above the amount appropriated.

This matter has been mentioned verbally to the Minister in Winnipeg and he has expressed the wish that it be referred to him on his return to Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Deputy of
The Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs

Ottawa.
OTTAWA 2nd July 1897

Mr. [Name],

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st ultimo with enclosure from the Rev. J. U. Poitras respecting the R.C. Indians of 1 in case of operation at Fort [Name]. I have not yet heard from Mr. [Name] regarding his instructions. I have written to Mr. [Name] regarding the same subject.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Acting Secretary
Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with enclosures from the Rev. J.U. Poitras respecting the R.C. Boarding school in course of erection at Rat Portage; and in reply I beg to say that Cheque No. 6625 in favor of His Grace, the Archbishop of St Boniface, for the sum of $2500 is enclosed herewith, this being the amount of the appropriation for this school up to the 30th June last.

The accounts which accompanied your letter above quoted are returned herewith in order that the same be paid by His Grace out of the Cheque sent. Any unexpended balance up to the 30th June last will have to be refunded; it would be well for His Grace to pay for all material purchased and work done up to that date, out of the appropriation.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Secretary

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina, N.W.T.
Sir Stewart,

The Cheyenne
and Kiowa

Potatoe

The papers herewith?

From [signature]

[Signature]
Memorandum for the Acting Deputy Supt. Genl. of Indian Affairs.

With reference to the Appropriation of $2500.00 made for the Roman Catholic Boarding School at Rat Portage, now in course of erection, the undersigned begs to report that His Grace the Archbishop of St Boniface has caused to be forwarded to the Department accounts amounting to $2005.00 for materials purchased for the building, together with an estimate of additional outlay which is made up as follows:

Plastering 100 yards @ 25¢ per yard ———— $250.00
Two chimneys, cost of building ———— $64.00
One ———— $98.00
Painting (two coats) ———— $300.00

The Indian Commissioner in a letter dated the 23rd ultimo, recommends that the total sum appropriated for the purpose be paid direct to His Grace the Archbishop of St Boniface, with the undertaking that the building shall be completed this summer in accordance with the plans approved of by him (Mr Forget), the Church not exceeding the cost over and above the amount appropriated.

Mr Forget goes on to say that the matter was mentioned verbally to the Minister at Winnipeg, and he expressed the wish that it be referred to him on his return to Ottawa.

The undersigned has the honour to request that the action to be taken in the matter may be indicated.

Acting Secretary.

6th July, 1897.
October 10th July, 1877.

T.M. Horne, Secretary

33 June 1905

[Signature]
Our services, and bearing half the cost of the maintenance of their children's school, also cost of funeral expenses, we are fairly doing our duty.

I consider half cost of keeping, which includes clothing, bedding, victuals, fuel, light and kindred helps, averages at least $500 per day or $600 per month.

Neskota was in our charge from the 10th of February 1901 to 18th January 1902, or 11 months. At $600 per month this makes $6,600. The half of this sum is $3,300 which is the amount I think the Indian Department will contribute towards the keeping and caring of said Neskota, its helper and fostered ward.

I might say that she had been receiving help from the school for a year previous to our taking them in charge.

I beg to remain

Your most obedient servant,

Rev. Ch. Catill
Principal Ind. B. School
[Signature]

P.S. To remain
Indian Boarding School, Rat Portage, Ont.
21st Jan., 1917.

J. A. Sevigne, Esq.,
Inspector Ind. Agencies

Dear Sir,

I beg to report to you the death of George Neshtota (aged about 10 years) which occurred on the 16th inst. on the premises of the Rat Portage Boarding School.

Said Neshtota had been in the keeping of the school since the 10th of February, 1916.

Last winter I reported to yourself and Dr. Hanson the case of this Indian who was ill at the time and had no relatives in the neighborhood, who could provide for him. I was advised by Dr. Hanson to take said Neshtota under my charge, give him the necessary attention and then apply to the Indian Department for compensation.

Considering the dangerous and loathsome nature of the disease (consumption and violent scrophulous sore), it was necessary to set apart a building for his exclusive use. Clothing and bedding were supplied, a great quantity of which were consumed owing to the necessities of the disease. Light, fuel and victuals were also regularly supplied and skilful nursing performed by the sisters.

At times, when it was wetter, it was necessary to hire help to attend on him; the hired help was continuous during the last months of his illness.

I consider that by freely giving
his reserve to help him wander here some years ago, and until last year was able to support himself by doing chore work, but the loathsome nature of his disease forced him to quit working and he took refuge near the school property where he remained until his death. The amount of compensation viz $75 seems to me fair and most reasonable for carrying to such a case, and would therefore most respectfully recommend the same to your favorable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

J. T. Arthur Levisay
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

OTTAWA, OCTOBER 7, 1907.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Mr. Inspector Scrimshaw's report on the Rat Portage boarding school, and in reply I beg to say that your remarks on the same have been noted and the Department will await the result of your enquiries as to what can be done to remedy the water supply of this school.

Your recommendation that additional fire-escapes should be provided is approved of, and you are hereby authorized to have another fire-escape furnished for this school.

As the need of Rat Portage has been shown, the Department considers it would be well to erect the new "Honora" for the school, and you will be good enough to communicate with the Church authorities and ask them to sell it the Honora for the school instead of the Rat Portage Boarding School.

The Department is pleased with the satisfactory manner in which this school is carried on as shown by Mr. Inspector Scrimshaw's report.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary.

The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 2nd ultimo in regard to Mr. Inspector Semmens' report on the Rat Portage Boarding School, and to say that the Church authorities agree to have its title changed to "Kenora", by which name it will henceforth be known.

As to fire escapes, the matter is, so far, only partially attended to.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

SPECIFICATIONS of the work and material required in the erection and completion of proposed Fire Escapes for the Indian School Building of Kenora, according to drawings prepared by The Scott & Hudson Building Company, Limited.

The platforms on slant of roof to be made of 2" x 4" wood frame and covered with 1" x 4" wood strips laid 1" apart well nailed and securely fastened to roof having 3/8" x 1¼" iron rails and ½" round iron uprights or balusters. The ladders running from roof down will be made of 4" x 2" flat iron and 5/8" round iron rungs, rails of same to be as above specified, that is, 3/8" x 1¼" and ½" uprights all well and securely put together by drilling and riveting together, these ladders to be properly tied to roof and windows with iron ties; they are also to be tied to walls of building by plugging said walls and using Coach screws and then braced with iron braces, braces to be bolted to ladders and fastened to walls with Coach screws as above specified.

The iron platforms under 2nd storey windows to be covered with 1" x 4" wood strips fastened to iron supports with bolts, ladders to be two (2) feet wide, opening to be left in floor of platform for access to ladders.

Roof platforms to be 3' wide.

The railing around on roof of wing to be of wood 2" x 4" rails and 1¼" balusters securely braced, the steps on this roof leading down to platform will also be of wood with iron railing as before specified.
Scott & Hudson Building Company

Ottawa, April 11, 1907.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of Mr. Inspector Servona's report on the Kenora Boarding School, which shows this school to be in a most satisfactory condition, with the exception of the water supply and drainage, for which a grant was asked, but too late for the supplementary estimates.

With reference to the details furnished in your letter of the 18th ulto as to the cost of providing a water supply and sewage system, I beg to say that the Department agrees with you that an expert should be engaged to make a detailed estimate and report on the system which would be most advisable to introduce into this school. Upon receipt of this information the Department will then be in a position to decide whether funds can be provided to proceed with the work this year.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Secretary.

The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.

May 22, 1926.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

The Rev. Principal and Mr. Indian Agent Edwards both urge the provision of an engine for the Kenora Indian Residential School launch. It is stated that this replacement is most urgent. Funds are available for certain expenditure at this school and I have enquired as to the best and most economical method of satisfying the request. The Consulting Naval Engineer of the Department of Defence recommends the purchase of a 32-40 h.p. Redwing engine from Messrs. R. A. Sproule & Sons, Ottawa. This engine has run from one to two thousand miles and has been lately completely overhauled at the factory. It is equipped in a most modern fashion and is stated by both Mr. Indian Agent Edwards and Messrs. R. A. Sproule & Sons as quite suitable for the school launch. The cost of this engine, new, today would be over $1,400. The one offered can be secured for $500, f.o.b. Ottawa. The only charge, other than carriage, would be for a battery (estimated cost $30.) I have seen the engine running and it appears to be in first-class condition.

Sproule & Sons, at my request, offered to properly crate and ship this engine to Kenora, so that it may be placed in the school launch and operated for one week - payment to be made at the expiration of this trial if our officers are entirely satisfied.

I shall be pleased to have your authority to complete this arrangement.

[Signature]

Russell D. Perrier

Supt. of Indian Education.
May 22nd., 1926.

Messrs. Red Wing Motor Company,
Red Wing,
Minnesota, U.S.A.

Gentlemen,-

We have just sold our used model "B" Red Wing, which you had back at the factory and overhauled after the fire in our boat, to the Dominion Government here, who are taking it to one of the Northern Lakes on trial, after having seen it run on test here. You will recall what model it is and that you recently added Bosch electric starting and complete modern pressure oiling.

We have been requested by the Department to have you forward proper instructions covering this model to their post and would therefore ask that you comply, sending as complete instructions as possible to,-

The Reverend Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ontario.

Business has been dull in the marine trade here this Spring, but you may rest assured prospects developing will be attended to with due to our mutual profit.

Thanking you for past favours and you will attend to this promptly,

Faithfully yours,

for the firm.
R. A. SPROULE & SON
BEECHWOOD AVENUE
OTTAWA
CANADA

Manufacturers
Sales Agents
May 22nd., 1926....

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Canada

Attention Mr. Ferrier.

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Complying with your request, we shall ship on Tuesday next, C.P.Ry. prepaid, to your agent Edwards, at Kenora, the Red-Wing, Model 32-40 inspected at our plant, while running this morning. It is understood that this is being shipped for acceptance by you, after trial in the boat under average running conditions for one week, when if everything is satisfactory, you will make payment as arranged. On the other hand, if it does not meet your requirements, you are to assume full responsibility for carriage charges and for the return of the motor to us here, undamaged and in the same condition as when it left us.

We are forwarding you, besides the motor with reverse gear, two unit Bosch electric starting and lighting system attached, your officials in Kenora to attend to the supply and attaching of a suitable 6 volt battery for starting and lighting. Enclosed inside the crate will be the oil gauge, the ammeter panel and ignition switch.

The base of the engine will be left with sufficient oil, but we would suggest that a close check be kept on the float gauge at rear of motor, which should be half way up the glass for correct oil level.

The adjustments on the carburetor are made and if the motor is set in the boat without these being disturbed, properly connected up to propeller shaft coupling, etc., there should not be any further trouble. We recommend starting by hand with hand lever being forwarded first few times. See that spark retarded and throttle lever open, prime with good gas in primers and after running have your local electrical man check generator and ammeter for charging of battery.

We have instructed the Red Wing Company to forward full instructions which should reach Kenora before the engine.

Thanking you and awaiting your further commands,

Faithfully yours,

[Signature]
for the firm.
Ottawa, May 25, 1926.

Sir:

With reference to the supplying of an engine for the Kenora Indian Residential School launch, I have to inform you that the Department has asked Messrs. R. A. Sproule & Son to ship to you a Redwing, Model 38-40. This engine, run from one to two thousand miles, has received excellent care and has recently been overhauled at the factory and equipped with the latest starting and lighting system. The arrangement with Sproule & Son is explained in the first paragraph of their letter of the 22nd instant, copy of which is enclosed. If, after a week's trial, you and the Rev. Principal are thoroughly satisfied that the engine is suitable and a good bargain at payment will be made.

I wish to refer you to the letter of Sproule concerning the battery, etc. You may purchase a 6 volt battery, after securing prices if necessary. The school authorities are responsible for the installation.

The engine is as shown on page "A" but is fitted with a new cylinder and lighting and starting equipment as shown on page "B". Both pages are enclosed. The bed plate for the engine is as shown on page "C". Mr. Sproule suggests that allowance should be made when ordering the bed for the gear teeth on the fly wheel.

Giving oiling instructions, etc., are given on the points on the motor which require attention. The Redwing Company are sending you and the Rev. Principal a full set of instructions.

We are satisfied that this is an excellent engine and would prepare a voucher, in duplicate, in favour of Sproule & Son, certify to it and send it under separate cover by express letter. Remarks concerning the terms are being offered, so that preparations for shipment are received. Sproule & Son, O. P. H., freight prepaid.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.
Ottawa, May 25, 1926.

The Rev. Principal and yourself should determine what repairs to the roof and eaves are necessary and have two or more responsible contractors quote on the work. Quotations should be submitted to the Department, for our consideration. It may be possible to include whatever outside painting is necessary in with this award, as I note that it is one of the urgent requirements. It might be well to include with the cupboards, shelving, chapel seats, etc., (see page 2 of your 108-12 of March 2nd) the repairs to the basement floor, window openings and new doors.

A decision concerning what amount of expenditure can be incurred in connection with the laundry will be reached after it is learned what the improvements at present under consideration will cost.

You might make a suggestion concerning the disposal of the old engine of the school launch. I am sending the Rev. Principal a copy of this letter, for his information and guidance.

Ottawa, May 27, 1926.

Sir:

I have your 108-12 of the 14th instant, with general reference to repairs and replacements at the Kenora Indian Residential School. You have already received information concerning the engine for the school launch and instructions concerning the purchase of window blinds. I am authorising Mr. Inspector Bunn to purchase twelve beds and mattresses.

You may accept the offer of Charles Ratchford, Plumbing Contractor, of Kenora, as detailed in his letter of the 19th ultimo (which is returned herewith) viz.: repairing and replacing lavatory fixtures at a total cost of $85. When you are submitting an account in favour of the contractor, return his written offer.

You are authorized to secure competitive prices for the installation of a suitable hot water tank for the school and award the business to the firm quoting the lowest.

I note that the Rev. Principal has stated that the alterations to the laundry, the installing of a boiler, etc., can be postponed. It is possible that some of these improvements can be done this year, but a decision cannot be reached until the cost of the other repairs and replacements is determined. You should have the Rev. Principal indicate what seats, tables, cupboards and shelves are required, listing the material necessary and indicating the probable cost of the labour that cannot be supplied by the school. Consideration will then be given to authorising the work on a day labour basis, under your direction.

Encl.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Sir,

In reference to your letter 129-1-5 of the 10th inst. regarding the marine engine for the Kenora Indian Residential School, I may say I returned from Treaty payments yesterday and have today seen the principal.

The engine is now installed, and a long trip was made, but the principal says the two front bearings burned out on the trip from oil-loss due, apparently, to badly fitting side plates and defective packing. However, when the engine is packed again, the principal thinks it will be all right.

He also says the self-starter does not appear to be very strong, but no doubt this difficulty will disappear with a trifle of wear in the newly babbitted bearings.

We therefore recommend that the account for the engine be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
