Dear Sir,

As requested by you we have closely examined the Galvanized Iron Roof on the above school and wish to report as follows:

The original roof was tinplate and apparently after it had rusted out, a galvanized iron roof was laid on top of the old tin roof. Laying the roof in this manner has caused the galvanized iron roof to rust out from below, while the surface still looks reasonably good, close examination shows it to be full of pin holes. There is however part of the original tin roof that has never been recovered that is in not too bad a condition, but it should at least have a good coat of Asphalium Paint. The other part of the roof—galvanized iron—has been eaten off by the galvanized iron, but to make a first class job we would recommend putting a new "Keystone Apollo" galvanized iron roof over the entire main roof. The galvanized iron roofs on the lean-to's can be put in good condition by repairing the soldered joints and repairing the flashings.

The sewers and rain water leaders also need considerable repairing.

The cost of covering the entire main roof with 28 gauge "Keystone Apollo" galvanized iron, with standing seams, repairing the lean-to galvanized decks and flashings, repairing the sewers and rain water leaders, as well as removing the old roof covering, would be $667.50.

Sir,

Referring to your letter #129-1-5 of May 27th, 1926 I enclose herewith tenders received for repairs etc. to Kenora Indian Residential School.

The principal has had included in the tenders the seats, tables, cupboards and shelves he requires, as he claims it is impossible for him to purchase the material and get men to do this work.

The repairs to roof and eaves appear to be necessary, likewise the exterior painting, since the woodwork is threatening decay for lack of this.

The principal will try to find a purchaser for the old boat-engine, which I fear is of small value.

It appears to me that the Campbell Heating Co. would make the best job of the metal roof-work, with Bergman and Nelson for the painting and woodwork.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edward

Sir,—
Replying to your letter #129-1-5 of the 3rd October last, re Kenora Indian Residential School.

I have had the Campbell Heating Company put in new windows so that they will open on the fire escape. I have also had them put a new floor for the back entrance as this had not completely worn out, and it was impossible to repair it enough to keep out the cold. The amount for both these repairs will not amount to much as Mr Campbell was able to do the work before taking his men away from the School, after putting on the new roof.

The Principal reports as follows re the motor boat engine:—

"In regard to the report on the motor boat, I beg to state that I will forward same as soon as it is ready. This requires extra work, and as I have already told you, my health is not good, in fact, I have all I can do to attend the ordinary work. If I could afford to pay a secretary, the Department could have immediate attention given to their demands, but, as the grant I receive is not even sufficient to cover the strictly necessary expenses, I am obliged to do my work alone even sometimes to the prejudice of my health."

As soon as this report is received I will send it on to the Department.

I may state that Dr Ferguson reports 15 cases of chicken pox at this school, and they are now quarantined.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

This engine under conditions which I thought at the time, and do still think, were very disadvantageous to me. When I went to the Agency, I took with me the mechanic who was supposed to have made a satisfactory job, and in reply to some questions asked him by the Agent, he admitted the shortcomings already spoken of above, but, of course, in a manner calculated to minimize them. For it is quite natural to his immediate pecuniary advantage to have the whole thing settled and OKed there and then.

It is not to be supposed that such a mechanic, having just completed a job, would immediately commit himself to any statement which might compromise his chances for settlement; and I felt at the time, as I do now, that I was the victim of circumstances which had been brought about, (1) by the proximate negligence of the vendor whose duty it was, in my opinion, to have sent one of their own men to install such a high-priced engine, and one withal which was guaranteed by them to his satisfaction; (2) the remote negligence of the purchasers who, one would have thought, would have sought to protect themselves by a proper care for the proper installation of such an engine.

Finally, it was left upon me either accept the engine there and then, or to refuse it, and even at that time the engine was still in commission, as I have already stated, it was not giving that degree of satisfaction that inspired any confidence for the future; furthermore, the apparent reluctance of the mechanic to involve himself in any statement likely to give rise to the suggestion that the installation was not all that could be desired, made my position a very undesirable one indeed.

In conclusion, the only alternative would have been to have the engine returned to the Company "at my own expense," and in the same condition etc., etc., etc., and it was mostly due to the fact that I did not have the engine returned; I am fully aware of the very accommodating nature of the term "in the same condition," and could not afford to run the risk of a refusal by the Co. to accept the engine.

I am Sir,

Yours respectfully,

J.E. Baillargeon

(J.E. Baillargeon O.M.I.)

Principal.

Indian Residential School,
Kenora - Ontario,
February 20th, 1927.

Sir;

In accordance with your request concerning the statement of Inspector Bennett as to the condition of the motor in our boat, I herewith append my report on the matter.

At the time the engine arrived here, I was unfortunate in not having at my disposal, the services of one of our own expert mechanics whom I was expecting. The only alternative therefore, was to hire a mechanic in Kenora, and after making extensive enquiries, a man was recommended to me who undertook to do the work. The installation being accomplished, a trial trip was made on the lake, and I had certainly no reason to be enthusiastic over the result!

In the first place, neither the self-starter nor the oil-pump ever worked at all. The packing however, is to be considered as the greatest trouble; for, upon the occasion of the trial trip above mentioned, not less than twelve gallons of oil were consumed, and this was a quantity certainly out of all proportion to the distance travelled, and I am unable to say that there was any marked improvement in this respect upon the few other occasions when the boat was taken out.

Upon the few subsequent trips made by the boat, the engine never ran smoothly, and the last occasion upon which it was to be taken out, the engine had barely been started when, probably owing to there being no pin through the lock-nut, some part of the mechanism got out and smashed the oil-pan, with the consequences too well known to require further details.

As to whether the engine left the Company in this condition, or whether we are to attribute the mishap to the negligence of the mechanic who installed it, I am not in a position to say. Now, I need not add anything about the present condition of the motor, since a representative of the Red Wing Motor Co., Mr. Anderson, who has examined the engine a few days ago, is to make his report concerning this matter.

Remarks.

In view of the fact that the vendors guaranteed this engine, it seems to me that it would have been both to their own interest, and to that of the purchasers had they undertaken to send a man to install it, and failing this precaution upon their part, that the purchasers themselves would have stipulated for this condition. The guarantee that the engine would give satisfaction is, I presume, based upon the supposition that it would be properly installed, and this being so, it seems incredible that the Company as guarantors, did not take any step to insure this condition, and so it appears that they have not done their utmost to make good their guarantee.

In view of the above circumstances related in my report, the fact that I accepted the engine may not seem to be altogether consistent with the facts stated concerning the trial of the boat following upon the installation of the engine. I am bound to say that I was unwilling from the start, to accept this
KENORA, Ont., February 10th, 1927

Capt. F. Edwards
Indian Agent
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

In compliance with your request I was out to the Indian School and inspected the damage done to the motor in the Indian School boat. I find that one of the connecting rod bolts broke on the big end on the front cylinder and the rod broke through the upper and lower base of engine. This was purely an accident and is liable to happen to any motor. To repair this engine it would be better to ship it back to the factory and have them rebuild it. This of course would be quite an expense and would suggest that for the small difference in the cost for a new motor it would not pay to ship the old one to the factory for repairs.

The cost of a 40 H.P. Red Wing motor with electric starter generator and storage battery complete F.O.B. Kenora, is $1243.00. This would be a later type motor than the one at present in the boat. If this motor is purchased from us we will allow you $200. for the old motor and make the installation of the new motor free of charge and guarantee the motor for one year.

Yours very truly,

Anderson Boat Works,

per,

J. Anderson.
Enclosed herewith please find a letter from the Rev. Principal of Kenora Residential School and a letter from the Anderson Boat Works, both reporting on the motor in the school launch.

You will note that the principal claims he was not satisfied with the engine when it was installed, but I'd like to draw your attention to the fact that before I certified the vouchers for the engine I interviewed the principal and the mechanic he mentions in my office, and they expressed their satisfaction, so I do not think we can accept responsibility for the breakdown.

In the circumstances I would recommend that as the accident was beyond their control they should get a new engine.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,

Ottawa.

Ottawa, March 14, 1927.

Sir:

I have your 108-13 of the 23rd ultimo, with enclosures, concerning the motor in the launch at the Kenora Indian Residential School. I am satisfied that, if the engine had been installed by an expert, a new one would not be required at this time. My advice is that the school authorities make arrangements for a new engine and, if they feel that the Department should bear any portion of the cost, they should make a special plea for a grant in this connection. If this action is taken, you might inform the Rev. Principal of the offer of the Anderson Boat Works, viz.: to install a 40 H. P. Red Wing Motor with electric starter, generator and storage battery, complete, and to guarantee for one year for $1245.00, less $200 for the old motor.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Ottawa, March 17th, 1927.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kenora Indian Residential School, states that the junior classroom is overcrowded and, consequently, there is not sufficient air space for each child in attendance. He also states that the plaster is falling off the walls of the boys' playroom, and that one of the new toilets overflows every time it is used. Please furnish a report regarding the classroom accommodation, and the repairs mentioned by the Inspector as being required.

The Inspector states that there is no more wood on the school property for fuel, and recommends that the Department arrange that the school can obtain the fuel required from the nearby Reserve. You might take this matter up with the Indians, and ascertain whether they would allow the school to obtain the fuel required, and the terms upon which same could be secured.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, March 22, 1927.

Sir:

The Department understands that some steps should be taken this summer to effect better ventilation in the case of the barn at the Kenora Indian Residential School. I should be grateful if you would discuss this with the Rev. Principal and, if necessary, secure the advice of some competent person. A small fee for such person's inspection and recommendation will be paid. I believe that hoarfrost gathers in considerable quantity on the inside of the building and, when there are changes of temperature, the result is most injurious to the stock. Your careful attention to this matter is requested.

You may also engage the services of a competent expert on steam heating, have him make an inspection of the boiler at the school and also the heating plant generally. The Department wishes to have a report as to what replacements or repairs are required and an estimate of the cost.

Another matter has arisen out of the visit of the Very Rev. Father Magan, vice Very Rev. Father Beys who has been transferred to Edmonton. I am informed that the kitchen range has outlived its usefulness. Please let me know if this is also your opinion and, if so, what type of equipment will be most suitable.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Sir:

Dr. A.D. Ferguson, Medical Officer of Health, has this day made a report on the water supply at the Kenora Indian Residential School, showing the smallest amount of water in which colon bacilli were found as being 20 C.C. for both taps tested.

We have accordingly forwarded to the principal of the school directions for the sterilization of the water as employed for the water supply elsewhere within the jurisdiction of Dr. Ferguson.

Indian Residential School,
Kenora - Ontario
March 30th., 1927.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a copy of your letter to our Indian Agent, Mr. Frank Edwards re the proposed installation of a new engine in the School launch. I refer to your advice however, that the school authorities make arrangements for the purchase of more land. I know that I could not possibly proceed along these lines without the definite assurance that the Department would be willing to defray the cost, or at any rate, a considerable portion thereof. You may therefore accept this as the special plea for a grant in this connection as mentioned in your letter.

Owing to an excessively wet season last year, our crop of hay and potatoes was a failure, and we had to buy both commodities at high prices. Moreover, added to this handicap, we have lost no fewer than five head of stock during the past few months; and as two of these were work horses, we were obliged to replace them immediately by cash and costly purchases. Finally, the amount of sickness in the school during the past winter has been quite exceptional, and this fact in addition to the above mentioned misfortunes does not leave us in a position to contemplate any such expenditure as the purchase and installation of a new engine for the boat would involve us in.

May I add that I have never, at any time, realized the possibility of getting anything aside out of the grant to this school, which would serve as a standby for such occasions as the present, and indeed I may say that where everything is going all right, it is only with the greatest care and caution that we are able to meet ends meet, and at a time of misfortune like the present, it is more than we can do to entertain any expenditure other than for absolute necessities in the nature of food and clothing, for the children and members of the staff.

Trusting I shall hear from you favourably concerning this matter,

I remain, Sir.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

March 17th., 1927.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs

Sir:

I beg to apply for authorization to have the following urgent repairs and improvements done immediately in our school:

1) Plumbing repairs; lo) to the pipe from sink to sewer in the girls recreation hall, which pipe is completely obstructed. We have done all we can to clear it, but unsuccessfully.

2) To the lavatory in the boys room. The water runs only with difficulty, owing either to a defect in bowl or to the pipe being obstructed.

We also need the services of a mechanic to adjust, as soon as possible, our water pump which is going out of order, and to overhaul our electric motor in the workshop.

Besides, I want to notify the Department that the children's lavatory for the summer should, by all means, be removed to a more suitable place; and that, probably, we will need the help of a man to blast the rock where we want to dig at least six or seven feet deep. Moreover, the present lavatory is partly burnt, and has to be rebuilt. Therefore, I ask the Department to kindly authorize me to make the necessary expenses, the amount of which would be almost impossible to determine before we have the work done.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am Sir,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
(J.C. Baillargeon, M.I.)

Dear Sir:

We beg to submit the following report, as requested by you, on the condition of the Plumbing at the Indian Residential School, Kenora.

The Outdoor Latrine for Summer Use has been partly burned, and is such condition that it is beyond repair. We would suggest that a new Latrine be built, the cost of the Carpenter Work for building would be approximately Two Hundred ($200.00) Dollars.

It would also be necessary to blast out rock for the pit, and this work would cost approximately One Hundred and Fifty ($150.00) Dollars.

The Plumbing Repairs required, are as follows:-

Boys' Toilet needs Washers in the Flush Tank Supply Valves;

Girls' Toilet needs Washers in the Flush Tank Supply Valves;

Girls' Toilet, Soil Pipe needs cleaning;

Girls' Playroom, Lavatory needs new trap with Clean-out;

Boys' Sleeping Quarters, Self-closing Hot and Cold Water Taps in Wash Basins, need adjusting and small repairs;

Girls' Sleeping Quarters, Self-closing Hot and Cold Water Taps in Wash Basins, need adjusting and small repairs;

Hot Water Supply Pipes in Laundry Room have been frozen, and will need to be replaced.
We might point out that there is no Ventilating System in the School, and should the Department decide that a Ventilating System should be installed, it would be necessary to design a Complete System before an estimate of cost could be given.

We trust the information contained in this Report is that which you require.

Yours truly,

THE CAMPBELL HEATING COMPANY,

[Signature]

DMC/C.
The Plaster in the Boys' Playroom is in a very bad state of repair and needs to be patched. This Room also require re-decorating. It is impossible to give an approximate price on this work, owing to the fact that the decorating could be done in several different ways, and it would be necessary to know which style of wall finish would be required.

The Girls' Playroom, which at present has a Seating Capacity of Thirty-five Pupils and a Floor Space of Four Hundred and Fifty Square Feet, is below the Standard size. The Floor Space required for this number of Pupils is Six Hundred and Thirty Square Feet, and the writer would suggest that a General Contractor be called in to report on the best method of increasing the size of this Class Room to the size required.

On inspecting the Heating System we found that the Boiler is not low enough set to satisfactorily heat the Building with the present one pipe Steam System. Also some of the Mains are too small. Further, some of the arms leading to the Risers are too long, and the water of Condensation from the Radiators is not being properly handled under these conditions. The end of the Mains, where they return to the Boiler are slightly below the Water Line of the Boiler. We do not think it advisable to lower the Boiler in an effort to overcome the present difficulties, because it would be necessary to change the size of the present Steam Main and the cost of this work would be out of proportion to the benefits obtained.

We would suggest that the present system be changed to a two pipe Vapor Vacuum System of the Dunham Trane or Webster type and a Pump and Receiver be used to handle the condensation. The cost of doing this work and supplying all materials would be in the neighborhood of One Thousand ($1000.00) Dollars.

The present Heating Boiler was found to be of sufficient size to properly warm the Building - Aime the Radiation was sufficient.
Capt. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Re Indian School.

We wish to make the following additions to our report of March 24th.

The present Range is a two oven #A.D.18 Huron Chief, manufactured by the Western Foundry Co., of Wingham. We find this Range needs complete new Fire Box Lining, including Grates. The Damper in the Smoke Pipe needs to be adjusted, and requires a new Towel Rail, a new Fire Door and a new Ash Pit Door - The cost of making these repairs would be approximately Seventy-five ($75.00) Dollars;

All Window Frames and Door Frames in the School are very loosely fitted, and we would suggest that a good Asphalt Caulking Compound be put in around these Frames, with a proper Caulking Gun - The cost of this work would be approximately One Hundred and Twenty ($120.00) Dollars;

The Wooded Fire Escape Platforms need to be replaced with new ones at a cost of approximately One Hundred and Twenty-five ($125.00) Dollars;

The Brick Work on the Chimneys requires to be rebuilt from the Roof, owing to the fact that the present Brick Work has become loose, and this is destroying the draft required by the Kitchen Range and the Heating Boiler. There are two Chimneys on the Building, and this applies to both of them - The cost of this work would be approximately Forty ($40.00) Dollars;

Grates in the present #7-35 A. Empress Steam Boiler, manufactured by the International Heater Co., of Utica, N.Y., require new Connecting Bars and Connecting Links - Also four Grate Bars - The cost of putting these in would be approximately Eighty-five ($85.00) Dollars.
Kenora, Ont.
April 6th, 1927.

Sir:

I beg to reply herewith to your letter 129-1-5 of the 22nd ult. regarding ventilation of the barn at Kenora Residential School. The principal, in discussion, suggests a "King" ventilator costing from $150 to $200, but I have asked for a report from Mr. Andrew Gordon here, who built the barn.

Mr. Campbell's report on steam-heating is enclosed herewith. The principal refers me to a report to the Department dated Sept. 14th, 1925. Would you kindly look this up?

The kitchen range is recommended for repairs in Mr. Campbell's report, at an approximate cost of $75.

With reference to yours 129-1-5 of the 17th ult. Mr. Campbell suggests that, the available space in the junior classroom being 450 square feet as against the requisite 630 square feet, a general contractor be asked to indicate the best way of achieving an increase.

If voted funds permit, I would recommend instant attention to the other needs reported by Mr. Campbell. All seem necessary. We would call for the usual tenders, and I would suggest in addition the spending of $640 on inside and outside painting largely as per tender of Messrs. Bergman and Nelson of July 15th, 1926, little having been done in this regard since the Department acquired the building.

I took up with the Town Council the matter of wood as reported by the Inspector, and since they cannot offer enough dead and fallen wood on their lease of part of Res. 30B I have asked the principal to locate the wood needed, when I shall again take the matter up with the Council and the Indians as required.

Your obedient servant,

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir;-

Re the proposed installation of a new engine in the school boat, I beg to inform you that I have laid the proposition before my superiors at St. Boniface, and they state that they are unable to assist in the matter, while the school, as you are well aware, is not in a financial condition to entertain the idea. It remains therefore, entirely with the Department as to whether or not we are to have the use of the boat next summer.

That the need exists, there is no question whatever, and it is a need, moreover, which will be more acutely felt next fall, in view of the fact that the very economical boat service we were fortunate to secure a few times last fall, is no longer available, and as far as I can see, we shall be, (failing the use of our own boat) entirely dependent on the costly services of the companies in Kenora.

Yours faithfully,

Sr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Jupt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir,

My trip to Ottawa has given very little result as far as Kenora School is concerned and I am greatly disappointed. I have made urgent requests in behalf of that School because its needs were greater than those of any four Indian Residential Schools, but to no avail.

The Agent at Kenora advises the Principal of the School that the Department of Indian Affairs consider their offer to meet half of the cost of a suitable engine for the launch as fair and reasonable. Perhaps it is, but practically it means nothing, the school being hardly able to meet current expenses.

A boat is absolutely necessary to Kenora School, and this year more than ever, the Lake of the Woods being so high that the road between the School and the Town of Kenora is covered with water.

I hope the Department will reconsider this matter and will see his way clear to pay full expenses for a suitable engine.

Yours sincerely,

Reverend J. Magnan, O.M.I.
Provincial.
June 8, 1927.

Dear Father Magnan:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, addressed to the Superintendent of Indian Education, with reference to the requirements at the Kenora Indian Residential School.

Relative to meeting the cost of a marine engine for the school boat, I wish to state that last year the Department supplied equipment which was considered quite suitable. This evidently was not installed by an expert and the school authorities must take a large share in the responsibility for the present replacement need. In view of this, I consider the Department's offer to meet half the cost of a suitable engine is more than fair. I note that the school is hardly able to meet current expenses. I wish to suggest to you that the church authorities do as is done in the majority of Indian residential schools, i.e., provide a grant for special purposes from time to time.

Mr. Ferrier has asked me to refer to the first sentence of your letter and to point out that, since your visit to Ottawa, the Department has arranged for proper ventilation of the barn; has made repairs to the kitchen range and to the plumbing; has overhauled the electric motor and pump; has asked for a full report and recommendation from the Dunham Heating Company on the entire heating system, with a view to taking whatever remedial action is necessary; is ready to proceed with the painting and with the repairing of the walls and with the replacement of the church roof, as soon as quotations have been received. I am favourably considering replacing the dining room tables, building cupboards, etc., renewing the platforms on the fire escapes, repairing the chimneys, repairing the wharf and renewing the roof of the henhouse.

You may rest assured that, whenever funds are available for the purpose, the Department will give favourable consideration to all legitimate requirements. But I am sure you will understand that we cannot replace expensive equipment which, because of improper care, has failed to give service.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Very Rev. J. Magnan, O.M.I.,
340 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.

Dear Sir,

Your heating of Domestic Hot Water.

At the present time you have a 80 gal Tank connected with the heating boiler and no Jacket Heater.

I would suggest that, as this tank is about done and has only 1" connections, that you have installed in basement a 210 Gall Tank with 2" connections to a Gurney Cottage Heater No. 906, and not have it connected to Heating Boiler.

This will give you all the hot water that you would use, and will burn 24" wood and has a large door and capacity for wood.

The approximate cost of this is:

THREE HUNDRED & SEVENTY FIVE DOLLARS..................$375.00

If done at the same time.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

[Signature]
The only practical solution of your heating problem, is to tap all radiators for return, opposite to the steam opening, and in this opening install a Trane or Dunham Radiator Trap. These openings should be tapped as near the bottom of radiator as possible, so as to receive all the condensed water.

A return line of piping should then be installed, connecting all of the traps to a Trane Electric Pump and Receiver located in the basement near the boiler. The Steam Main then would not carry the condensed water from the radiators.

To provide for the water that would condense in the Steam Main, Steam Traps should be installed to properly drain the Steam Main into the receiver. You have a good dependable and cheap supply of Electric Current, and the operation of this small motor would cost very little. The present steam main would then be used only to supply steam to the radiators, and the steam would be dry.

One desirable feature of this Plan, is that the work could be done without cutting off the heat or taking out any part of Steam piping, and could be done of necessity in the winter time while the boiler is being used.

Another desirable feature of this system is that you could admit only what steam is required to each radiator and they would all heat evenly regardless of the amount of pressure on the boiler.

You would also do away with the use of Air Valves on the Radiators, all the air in the system being eliminated in the basement.

Having lowered the waterline in your heating system by installing the receiver it would not be necessary to lower the boiler.

The approximate cost of this would be:

ELEVEN HUNDRED & FIFTY DOLLARS.........................$1150.00

You to supply board for workmen.

If this is done we would guarantee to heat your building to your satisfaction in the coldest weather.

Yours respectfully,

Yates, Heale & Co.

[Signature]
Aug 18th 1926.

Rev. Father Baillargeon,
Principal, Indian Boarding School
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have inspected the Steam Heating System in your School, and beg to submit the following report.

Plan of the Heating accompanies this letter.

The amount of Radiation is more than sufficient, and you would have not trouble if all the Radiators got hot.

The Boiler is apparently of sufficient capacity and the draft I am told is adequate.

The chief trouble lies in the system of piping which is employed on this job and shown on plan.

Another source of trouble is in the height of the boiler setting. On account of having rock to deal with, the boiler has not been set as low as it should have been.

In order to use the present system of piping, the boiler should be at least 12" lower.

As at present used, the condensed water will pile up toward the North end of building, while the South end will work fine.

The branches in the North part are entirely too long and too small and have too little fall to work in connection with the South end, or to work well at all for that matter.

It is a system that should never be used when any other could be put in because all the condensed water having to come back to the boiler through the same pipe that takes the steam, causes a certain amount of this condensation to be re-evaporated, causing the steam to reach the point of maximum saturation before reaching the Radiators, when the aim should be to supply as dry steam as possible.

An overhead rain could be used in this building without lowering the Boiler, but to do that now would mean to practically tear out most of the heating in the North end of building.

It does not appear practical to lower the Boiler because the resulting Pit would have to be drained, and would entail considerable expense.
October 24/21

The approximate load in equivalent direct radiation being 2700 sq.ft.

The Head room in the Basement is only 6'6" under the joists and to install the new boiler it will be necessary to provide a pit 12" to 15" deep to allow room for steam header. While the excavating of this pit will be somewhat difficult owing to the floor of the basement being rock, it is the only way possible under the circumstances.

HOT WATER:

The Principal, Father Bilgeron advised me that when hot water was needed it was not possible to procure any great quantity at one time. The difficulty, I believe, is due to the boiler being undersized and the manner in which connections are made to the Storage Tank.

We have included in the specification that Contractor shall run a new steam line from steam header to tank, also specified that tank be provided with Hot Water Regulator, Thermometer and Relief Valve, leaving the connections to Jacket Heater remain as at present. In this way, the School Authorities will have controlled hot water at all times.

GENERAL:

The piping of the system itself is in fairly good condition and will only be necessary to re-grade mains to conform to the Dunham layout.

The pipe covering is torn away in a great many places and this will have to be replaced—approximately 50'.

The present flue is 10"x10"x 4b' high. It will be necessary to increase this height 10' to take care of the larger boiler. The School Authorities burn wood throughout the heating season and while a flue height of 8b' would not create enough draft for a coal fired boiler, we believe it will be large enough for this boiler burning wood. The building has good acoustics, being situated on a hill-side amidst open country. We would suggest placing a 10' length of 1b" diameter galvanized pipe of suitable gauge on top of the present flue, securing same securely.

Trusting our efforts in connection with this job meet with your approval and looking forward to the adoption of a Dunham System in this Building.

Yours very truly,

C.A. DUNHAM COMPANY LIMITED
BRANCH SALES OFFICE NO. 2

E.Fox, Engineer.
WINNIPEG, MAN.

June 10th, 1927.

R. Gurney Orr, Esq.,
Dominion Government Architect
(Indian Department)
Ottawa, Ont.

RE: INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - KENORA, Ont

We have inspected the above job and are forwarding to you plan and specification covering the changing over of the present one-pipe steam system to a Dunham Return System, and we wish to make the following recommendations:

**RADIALION:**
The writer checked over the radiation and while the building in general checks up fairly well, the top floor is not adequately heated. This floor is used for sleeping quarters and while the radiation needed is less in proportion to the other floors, we would advise adding the two new radiators shown on plan.

The Principal of the School informed me the two corner rooms on the first floor were cold. We have, therefore, added the necessary sections to the present radiators.

**BOILER:**
The boiler at present installed in the building is a No.7-30-A Empress, Manufactured by The International Heater, with a capacity of 2800 sq.ft. of direct cast radiation. With a radiator load of 2164 sq.ft., and in addition a 220 Gallon Hot Water Tank, this boiler is far too small to handle the system.

We were in touch with the Boiler Manufacturers and they advise us it would be possible to add two new sections, making a capacity of 3600 sq.ft. However, we feel that even a boiler capacity of 3600 sq.ft. will not handle this job to make an efficient system. The present boiler has been in the building a good many years and is not in good shape needing a number of repairs and general patching up and overhauling. We have, therefore, specified a new boiler which will handle the new and old radiation as well as the steam coil in the Hot Water Tank.
Ottawa, June 27, 1927.

Sir,

Referring to your letter #129-1-5 of 19th April last re repairs to the Enora Indian Residential School.

The matters have been left in abeyance until now, owing to the difficulty in obtaining from the Principal what he considered the most needy work, and also his wish that the work should be done whilst the children were on vacation.

The matter of clearing more land can be left for the present, also the basement floor, and the pressure tank.

Enclose please find tenders for the most important work from Messrs Fielder and Bradley, Conrad Swanson and Bergman and Nelson, although Messrs Bergman and Nelson are the highest tenderers, I would recommend in this case that their tender be accepted as they are in the best position to do more efficient work than the other firms and the Revd Principal is desirous of employing them.

Only the most important matters have been tendered on, and they are all very necessary.

As regards the dining room tables, these can be covered &c and so save cost., the cupboards and shelves as tendered for are necessary.

Bergman and Nelson has included in their tender the necessary temporary work on the platforms, pig-pen roof, &c.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

For some time the Department has been in correspondence with the honored Principal of the Lacora Indian Residential School and with the Indian agent, relative to the most urgent repairs and replacements to the buildings there. It is considered essential should be done without delay and an item included in the Main Estimates, Indian Education, so that the necessary funds would be available. Mr. Indian Agent Edwards has, at my request, prepared brief specifications of the work that should be done this year. Two general contractors have tendered on the work, as follows:

Bergman & Nelson - $1,350.00
C. Swanson - $1,145.00

The first and higher of these tenders is not detailed. C. Swanson's bid, however, is in detail and it can be compared with the third tender which is for the painting and decorating, submitted by Fielder & Bradley - the price, $255.00.

Whereas C. Swanson, the lower of the two complete tenders, asks $250.00 for the painting, I wish to recommend that this part of the work be given to Fielder & Bradley and that the carpenter work, amounting to $55.00, be given to C. Swanson. Please let me know if this meets with your wishes.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

Kelly, Miller Inspector, has stated all steam boilers (etc.) is in fair shape, all have been certificates in all cases except the boiler in the resident school.

In this case the boiler inspector says: "Our inspector reports the boiler huge and two tr-cogs also if. I would ask you to have the boiler cut out removed the flues with the boiler and to have the boiler hole. Then these flues are cut, we could use you to have the boiler washed out and cleaned inside only of some. If it is washed out with a pipe we hope the case will be removed. The boiler is in need of repairs, as it is out by the inspector. The fires and chimneys are in good condition and will need repairs. I am likely to receive your notice that these repairs have been made, a certificate for this boiler will be issued for ten years from now. Your prompt attention to these matters will be appreciated, as the heating season is about to commence."

Under these circumstances I have a request for instructions regarding the matter. I shall be glad to meet you at any time, so let me know when you can come to the office and I will make arrangements to see you forthwith, anticipating your favorable reply. I shall be glad to have the necessary authority for your visit.

Enclosed herewith are a few reports of Mr. Kelly, Boiler Inspector, for your file.

The Assistant Chief, Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
etc., etc.

November 9th, 1927.

Sir:

Your letter, Oct. 6th, giving instructions for the protection against fires has been received with interest. In reply I beg to state the following.

In fact our fire escape system does not prove quite satisfactory. The exits which open from the inside lead to two poles, one at each extremity of the building. These serve well for the older children but it would give less anxiety if another means of escape could be placed somewhere in the center of the building for the younger children who are very difficult to awaken and who with the aid of larger pupils could be more easily carried to safety.

A fire alarm is needed and also other hand-fire extinguishers. Those on hand would need inspection.

In regard to your instructions we shall try to carry them out as much as we possibly can.

Yours truly,

J.E. Baillargeon
Principal

Mr. Duncan Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.

OTTAWA.
Ottawa, November 16, 1927.

Sir,

The Department has received a communication from the Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School relative to the fire equipment on hand. The following is an extract from his letter regarding this matter:

"In fact our fire escape system does not prove quite as satisfactory. The exits shown run from the inside lead to two poles, one at each extremity of the building. These serve well for the older children, but it would give less anxiety if another means of escape could be placed somewhere in the center of the building for the younger children who are very difficult to awaken and who, with the aid of larger pupils, could be more easily carried to safety."

I have to request that you will make an early inspection of the fire equipment at the school. You should enquire into the needs of a further fire escape, and inform the Department as to your recommendations in the matter, stating the type of fire equipment you would recommend be installed, and the approximate cost of same. You should also state whether you consider the fire escapes mentioned by the Principal are satisfactory, or whether you would recommend that any changes be made in them. Please also state the cost of installing a suitable fire alarm system or a gong.

You should arrange for the purchase of any refills required for the fire extinguishers at present on hand, and you should see that they are thoroughly overhauled and placed in serviceable conditions. An account, in duplicate, should be forwarded in the usual manner covering the cost of the refills. If any more extinguishers are required I shall be pleased if you will state the number, when an order will be placed here for same.

The above matters should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

WHAT "FIRE-GUN" IS AND HOW IT WORKS

To explain the operation of FIRE-GUN refer.

The pump handle (1) is locked by a counter turn inside, clockwise automatically occurring the shut-off valve located in lower casing (2).

The extinguisher is operated like any ordinary hand pump by the residual motion of the handle. On the first outward stroke a solid stream of fluid is expelled through the nozzle (3) (not shown in this view), which continues during both thrusts and in pumping, stroking until the entire contents are discharged, leaving the pump empty.

The piston rod (4) is connected to each cylinder (5) and (7) with an external (6) and (8) leading to the central valve case.

Range—Shoots effective stream about 30 feet.

**FIRE-GUN** IS BUILT FOR SERVICE — IT PUTS OUT THE FIRE
FIRE DEPARTMENT

FIRE EQUIPMENT CONTINUED.

... easily prevent anyone from reaching in for same in time of need. A hand chemical should be installed near furnace.

FIRE PRACTICE.

Pumping pressure for fire purposes should be checked up frequently, and several persons should be kept posted on this matter; practices with same should be held at intervals. Hose could be tested at these practices and all joints examined for leaks and records taken and turned in to the principal.

FIRE STATIONS.

If fire apparatus is kept on the premises it is also worth having someone know how to handle same effectively, therefore the boys under a proper instructor should have practices and drills to become familiar with this equipment. Fire axes should be placed in convenient spots and the boys taught how to use them properly; axes are generally kept near to fire house or fire extinguishers. Several stretchers should be procured and one in each ward especially, woollen blankets should accompany same.

Large bell should be rung in special manner for fire, fire gongs should be installed in dormitories and one near close rooms, with notices for FIRE ONLY. These gongs to be used for fire drills.

FIRE ARMS.

Fire drills should be instituted and held frequently both at night and during school hours; this will help to have the children familiarize themselves with all the escapes under a regular system.

FIRE PREVENTION.

The teachers should give the children useful information on Safety first and what to do in case of fires. Always on fire prevention is the best form of instruction that get results.

WATCHMAN.

One man should inspect the premises every night and report on same anything found out of place and also be in charge of fire equipment and keep records of apparatus and condition of same.

Respectfully submitted by [Signature]

[Signature]
Captain F. Edwards,

The schools themselves will find the benefit from this instruction. I am sure that to begin with that something like this is along the proper lines to hurry up the safety idea then afterwards they know and can distinguish danger from safety practices and in my past experience the children like these practices and take great interest in it especially if there is a prize in view for their efforts.

From yesterday's inspection I wish to submit the following report and suggestions:

1. Fire escape are loose and require new bolts and firmer attachments to the building. Windows on or leading to escapes should all open out in the same manner. Large windows on the South side cut off the escape platform and in hard to open and should be made to open freely. Signs and red lights should be installed for denoting location of escape. Children should use escapes frequently to familiarize themselves with same this can be done in connection with fire drills mentioned elsewhere. Frosted metal is hard on bare hands. On other portions of the body the palms being exposed makes them difficult to handle in the winter months I therefore would recommend a stout form of escape leading from the dormitory to the ground which will accommodate especially the younger children who are hard to handle when once asleep, the present escape would also clip but could be used in emergencies only if depends where the fire is coming from especially when heavy smoke is concerned.

2. Heating Plant.

The old chimney requires a thorough cleaning out and should be cleaned out at least once a year. When being handled in paper or wooden boxes, a metal ash container should be procured at once. Wood and coal must be kept away from near the furnaces. Basement door should be free to open quickly if kept locked on one side the both sides should be bolted. Laves troughs should not be allowed to leak on entrance steps or fire escapes.

3. Fire Equipment.

Every extinguisher should be recharged once a year the ones there show no mark of recharging on slip attached for this purpose. Firehose in basement requires a hose rack, connections all require rubber gaskets, all valves should painted red and signs put up denoting for FIRE ONLY. Firehose in basement would better if placed near a door or window leading to the outside of building, smoke will
To Captain F. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Honora, Ontario.

Re Inspection of Indian residential school.

Dear Sir,

I certainly appreciate the opportunity you afforded me in going over this inspection with you, and you can always depend on me anytime that I can be of service to you when life and property are at stake, because by co-operating together I am sure that we can not only remedy the conditions in existence there today but I am sure that our Mayor and Council will also agree to enable us to render you all the assistance possible any time when necessary. It is of course necessary to confer with the Council in order to get things arranged so that we could render you assistance in various ways.

I would also very earnestly advise you to get things going at once because this coming season is the season of fire hazards and the inadequate conditions there today need immediate attention in order therefore to reduce the chances of a fire to a minimum it need immediate attention. I might state that if you went to the proper authorities in charge of Fire Rangers that it would be possible to get two of their small fire pumps which we could use for fire at the school or nearby buildings, these pumps are simple to operate, are light to transport and we have hose that fits these connection they would I am sure render excellent service at a fire out there.

I do not believe that the pump in use there today would supply sufficient pressure for more than one effective hose stream in case of fire in a building that size and if more than one line was used the pressure would be so reduced that it would hardly be of any use, therefore more energy is what is wanted and in my suggesting the Fire Rangers pumps they do good work and are idle during the winter months, we had them for one season and while we did not use them for any actual fire we tried them out in severe cold and they worked in an excellent manner. I will help to institute fire drills for the children and familiarize the boys on fire fighting equipment and how to handle the firehose and chemicals & will assist to get you fire gongs for fire signals and will furnish fire prevention data for class rooms and can also address the children the same as is done in our own schools it helps a lot & I am sure that when the Teachers and Children see that it pays to have system they will take a lot of interest in same. I would also suggest that fire prevention exercises be written on fire and safety and prizes be given to the best ones it instills ideas into the little heads that gets there in no other way and it pays to have them learn this as it comes in useful not only to themselves but...
Kenora, Ont.

10-12

Sir:

I refer to my letter 10-12 of the same date.

The Fire Chief has made a report which I have seen, etc. The Rev. Francis L. will be here soon, and I accordingly attend. I am not able to attend at this time, but I shall be there when the Fire Chief returns from his duties, or other wise I may be able to attend. I have no idea what the cause of the fire was, but I can assure you, etc.

Chief Francis will be here shortly, and I shall be there shortly thereafter. We will be able to put out the fire, and the Fire Chief will be able to put out the fire. We will be able to put out the fire, and the Fire Chief will be able to put out the fire.

I have arranged with the Rev. Francis to attend to the present fire, and I shall be there shortly thereafter. We will be able to put out the fire, and the Fire Chief will be able to put out the fire.

I am sending a copy of the Fire Chief's report to the Rev. Francis, and I request that he carry out, as far as possible, the recommendations of the report.

The Assistant Deputy,
Dept. of Indian Affairs

Frank Edward,
Indian Agent,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6197, file 465-5, part 2)
Ottawa, December 16th, 1927.

Sir,

I have your 108-12 of the 6th instant, with reference to fire protection at the Kenora Indian Residential School. I have to thank you for the special care which you have given this question. I note that you have arranged with Fire Chief Dubois of Kenora to supervise fire drills, give lectures, arrange the refilling of the fire extinguishers, check up on the fire hose and give other assistance. Your action in having the present fire escapes repaired is approved. The Department will await your further report concerning the price of the proposed enclosed chute type of escape which is recommended by the fire chief for the special use of the smaller children.

The Department will order 2 - 5 gal. pump tanks and 3 - 1½ qt. size extinguishers from the Pyrene Co. When these arrive, you should see that they are placed in proper positions. Please instruct the Principal to have the chimney cleaned and to see that the furnace room is kept free from inflammable material of all kinds. You may purchase one metal ash container. I regret that the Department cannot authorize the purchase of a special engine and hose for the purpose of throwing a stream of water.

You may arrange to have the windows leading to the fire escapes properly hung. I do not agree that signs and red lights are necessary as all who live in the building should know where the fire escapes are. You may purchase and arrange for the installation of suitable gongs at an approximate cost of $50. You may secure a hose rack for use in the basement and six fire axes, which should be placed at strategic points.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

A. P. MacKenzie,
Acting Ass't. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, December 17, 1927.

Gentlemen:

I have to request that you will forward as soon as possible, freight charges prepaid, addressed to Rev. J. E. Baillargeon, O.M.I., Principal, Indian Residential School, Kenora, Ont., the following:

2 - 5 Gal. Pump Tank Extinguishers, complete with non-freeze charges,
3 - 1½ Quart Pyrene Extinguishers, complete with non-freeze charges.

The price charged should be as low as possible, and should be F.O.B. Kenora, Ont.

Please forward your account, in duplicate, to Frank Edwards, Esq., Indian Agent, Kenora, Ont., who is being informed that the order has been placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of these extinguishers, if in good condition, to certify the account and send it to the Department, when payment will be made.

Your early attention to the shipment of these extinguishers will oblige,

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Form No. 101.
Indian Residential School
Kenora - Ontario.
January 17th, 1928.

Dear Sir:

Necessity prompts me to make application for some urgent repairs to be made in our school. These are mostly plumbing repairs for the water closets.

The water tanks are out of order and occasion a considerable waste of water. In fact, two of them, the water is running almost continually, and would likely need new fittings since these seem to be no good last year. A plumber examined them and done his best to put them in good order, and a couple weeks ago I had a mechanic look at them again whom I hired for the purpose.

These fittings would cost approximately $15.00 each provided we could get them. (I have been told they do not seem to sell fittings without the tanks at the Hardware store) the cost would be between $25.00 and $32.00 each.

Some parts of the fittings should be replaced in two other tanks, which very often, are out of order. This would cost about $6.00 for each tank.

Two closets, however, are badly damaged and should be replaced at the cost of $12.00 each.

I also need one new complete water closet outfit for the convenience of some members of the Staff who have to walk down two stairs, when there should be a lavatory on that same floor or, at least, on the next one. From the Catalog I have (J.H. Ashdown, Windsor), the closest combination needed would cost $75.00.

It would take a number of days to do all of the above in good order, at eight to ten dollars per day, I presume.

The wood work in this connection would amount to about $10.00 (thirty dollars). Now although I have spent over $450.00 since last summer, for repairs that were not included in the contract given to Bargman & Nelson, I would accept to be responsible for the carpenter's wages, if the Department would furnish the lumber.

I need not say that if so many repairs are necessary today, the cause of it is, in no way, imputable to carelessness on the part of any member of the Staff. We do the best we can, but cannot be everywhere at the same time, and prevent every mishap to happen. Children are children, and the particular class we have to look after are runaways and thieves.

I must add that some of the repairs above mentioned, should have been made a long time ago, but I had no authorization and no money to proceed with the work, and I waited until finally, everyone was after me saying it was more than urgent to have the repairs made.

Could you kindly give this matter your consideration, and also your recommendation to the Department of Indian Affairs, as soon as possible, so that we may have the work done at an early date.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain, Sir,

Yours faithfully,

Captain Frank Edwards,
Indian Agent,

Kenora, Ont.

Principal.
Ottawa, February 7th, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from the Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School requesting that certain repairs be carried out to the plumbing of the water closets and stating the new fixtures required.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of any new fittings required to place these closets in a satisfactory state of repair and also for the labour in having the work done. You should keep all expense down as low as possible, having in view the carrying out of a satisfactory job. The Department is not prepared to authorize the installation of a water closet for the use of the staff.

When the above work has been completed, you should forward a certified account, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the cost of any new fittings and for the labour.

It is noted that any carpenter work required in having these repairs made will be carried out by the school authorities without expense to the Department.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Form No. 101.
Sir:

Will you permit me to tell you that I have been greatly disappointed in receiving the answer of the Department to my request of 17th January the 17th, according to which I have been refused the granting of a new toilet for the Staff. Now, as we need this very badly, I will have to have some installation, and as the Department refuses to do anything in this connection, we will have to spare on some necessities and things that make life comfortable to the children in order to be able to meet this expense, which would be an important item for the Government, considering the prosperous state of affairs in the country, according to the recent report of the Minister of Finance.

I am very sorry for this refusal, since the addition asked for is necessary and has to be done by all means.

Would you also be kind enough to obtain for me authorization to spend about £40.00 for a new flooring in the horse stable, which flooring has never been renewed and is completely worn out.

Would you also obtain for me authorization to have washing machine repaired in laundry. Four pieces of wood are completely rotten and must be replaced. I could not tell you what it would cost, because it is impossible for me to know how much work will be required to replace them. Also, the washing machine being surrounded by heavy steel hoops which have to be removed; I should think it would cost approximately £50.00.

A new belt is needed also in the laundry, which would cost about £20.00.

There are but a few of the essentials required in this school, and permit me, Sir, to draw your attention to the fact that I have spent nearly £300.00 on repairs and additions which, I believe, should have been done by the Department. The estimates for alterations and repairs were diminished by one half; the other half I had to make up for, or accept the alternative which would have left us in a miserable state. To do this, I had to borrow money and have the work done while the contract was carried on. This, you may sincerely believe, is surely more than enough for my part, and I have reason to expect the cooperation of the Department for some other requisition.

Should you not, Sir, look into this, as our needs are very urgent, and this would be a source of discouragement because it is very troublesome to obtain these essentials which are not costly. I would appreciate any action you might take to have the above mentioned items authorized by the Department.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J. Bell-Reynolds

Superintendent
Dept. of Indian Education.
Attention Mr. R. Ferrier.

Kenora, Ont.
March 7th, 1926.

Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find letters received from the principal of Kenora Indian Residential School.

There is no question as to the need of new flooring in the stable and of woodwork and a belt for the washing machine. I would therefore recommend this expenditure.

If you could let me know about what is the amount we would be able to spend on this school in the approaching financial year it would give me some idea as to what we could do for them, since beyond doubt many repairs and improvements are badly needed.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edward

Indian Agent.

The Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

E/A Enc.
Ottawa, March 10, 1928.

Sir:

I have your 103-12 of the 7th instant, enclosing a communication from the Rev. Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School, with reference to urgent improvements. You may incur an expenditure of $40 for flooring in the horse stable; $50 repairing the washing machine; and $30 for a new belt in the laundry.

I may say that the Department has asked Parliament to appropriate $9,200 for replacements, repairs and improvements at this school during the coming year. This amount has been assigned as follows:

- Ice house - $1,000.-
- Laundry addition and machinery - $5,000.-
- Heating alterations - $3,200.-
- General repairs, etc. - $2,000.-

You might hand the Rev. Principal the enclosed copy of this letter and, at an early date, make a joint recommendation as to not only exactly how this money should be expended this year, but how the work could best be undertaken.

I should be glad to know how Bergman and Nelson are getting along with their contract, authority for which was sent to you on October 10th, last.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Form No. 101.
Dear Sir:

I beg to submit a report on the Indian Residential School at Kenora with some recommendations.

On my initial visit to this School, I find that the building is very old and the dormitories have insufficient fire escapes. I would suggest, therefore, this be remedied at once. I understand that an architect is to be sent from the Department, and I presume that he will note this recommendation.

The attendance at the School has not been very satisfactory. A number of the pupils leave during the school term and it is difficult to have them return. The launch owned by the School is not in working condition and the School is not in a position to repair it. If the Department could see fit to have the engine repaired it might be used to good effect in bringing the pupils to school in September.

The school is rather inaccessible during the winter months, and the accommodations are not of such a nature that any pupils who are ill can readily be taken to Kenora. I would therefore suggest that regular dental and medical inspection be put in force.

Trusting this will receive your prompt attention, I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

F.J. McDonald
Ottawa, May 12, 1928.

Sir:

I beg to refer to your letter of December 6th, last, relative to fire escapes at the Kenora Indian Residential School, in which you stated that the Fire Chief at Kenora recommended the installation of another fire escape of the enclosed chute type and that he was obtaining a price on same. The Department has received no further information from you regarding this matter, and I should be pleased if you would forward full information regarding this type of fire escape, and the cost of obtaining and installing same. The Separate School Inspector, who recently visited this School, states that the dormitories have insufficient fire escapes, and recommends that this be remedied as soon as possible.

In further reference to the fire equipment at this School, it is presumed that Fire Chief Dubois of Kenora has been supervising fire drills and has tested the present pump and hose and carried out the other arrangements which you made with him as reported in your letter above referred to in connection with the fire equipment at this School.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:

RE FIRE ESCAPES FOR INDIAN SCHOOL AT KENORA,

We beg to report the following on Fire escapes, as suggested by Fire Chief Dubois in his recent report to you.

The photographs which we are placing in your possession are known as the "Charette Fire Escapes" and embody all the essential features required by Fire Chief Dubois.

We found on examining the School and going into this matter more thoroughly, that two escapes were required, one from the Boys' Dormitory on the North side of the School and the other from the Girls' Dormitory on the South Side. The platforms that are there at present can be used by changing their location and altering some of the Iron Work.

The Department at Ottawa can no doubt get complete plans of this style of Fire Escape from the Patent Department, the Patent Number being 273130.

This escape, in our opinion, is exceptionally suitable for buildings, such as the Kenora Indian School, wherein the pupils range in age from 5 to 18 years. These pupils sleep in the building, and as pointed out by Fire Chief Dubois, should a fire occur in the night, it is next to impossible to awaken the younger children, and with this style of Fire Escape, they could be thrown into the chute by the older children. The chute platforms are well protected from heat.

It would be necessary to install a two-flight chute - the cost of doing this work would be approximately $3000.00.
Kenora, Ont., July 7, 1928.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

August 20th./28.

Sir;

Attention Mr. R. C. Orr

With reference to your letter no. 129-1-5 of the 17th. inst. re. repairs to the Kenora Indian school, I had arranged with Mr. Orr and Hon. Peter Heenan that the Campbell Heating Co. of Kenora would do certain of the work, particularly that in connection with the heating alterations.

Mr. Campbell has just been in to see me and informs me that he is very busy at the present time and is unable to do the work required. I would therefore suggest that the heating alterations as recommended by Dunham of Winnipeg should be awarded to Messrs. Yates Neale and Co. of Brandon, as per their tender of $1150.00 to the Rev. Father Baillargeon September 14th. 1925, if they will still do the work at this price. At the same time they could also do some of the other work we intended giving to the Campbell Heating Co.

In speaking over the telephone with the Hon. Peter Heenan he also approves of this course, and I should be glad if you will take the matter up with Yates Neale and Co. so that the work may be started as soon as possible.

Asst. Deputy and Secy., Your obedient servant,

October 22, 1928.

Mr. G. Orr, Architect,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Booth Building,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Orr:

We are today in receipt of a letter from our Western Agents, the Beaver Soap & Chemicals Ltd., of Winnipeg, stating that before Mr. Wyndels can give us the order for your Indian school at Kenora, he must have a letter from the Department stating that our machinery will be acceptable to your Dept.

We wish you would kindly send forward by return mail a letter to this effect as we would like to get this order under way as we understand they are in a hurry for the machinery.

The writer expects to be in Ottawa on Thursday of this week, and looks forward with pleasure to calling on you at that time.

Thanking you in anticipation, we remain

Yours very truly,

The BEAVER LAUNDRY MACHINERY CO. Limited

[Signature]

CDE:BN.
Sales Manager.
Oct. 24, 1928.

Sir,-

Please quote me a price f. o. b.

Kenora, and including sales tax, for one 32"x 40" Vorclene Tumbler, motor driven. I cannot give you the phase and cycle of this meter, but you can obtain this information from the town of Kenora who furnish the electric power to this school. I will be glad to have this price as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Nelson,
Assistant-Supt. and Secretary.

Agent:

Form 52.
Dear Sir:

We received your letter of Oct. 1st, yesterday, and shipped a folder ironer yesterday afternoon.

We wish to thank you for the order and it is most possible the writer will be in Kenora about the end of this week; I will make a point of calling on you and will give you all the information and assistance I can in starting the ironer business.

We are forwarding the bills to Capt. J. Wardes. These you will probably post, call for $2,000 less of $300.00. The order you require was ordered October 4th and dispatched October 6th. On the old shipped to you, the ironer, was in excellent condition and we are very regretful not to have been able to send you the new ironer. We are sure you will appreciate our inability to do so.

Please let us know when you are ready to go, and if not, I am sure we will be able to get another or fit for you at a very reasonable price.

Yours very truly,

THOR COMPANY CO., LTD.

Nov. 5, 1928.

Rev. Sir,

I have to advise you that an order has today been placed with the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co. of Toronto for one Beaver Junior Vorulox Tumbler, 32 x 40, motor driven, at the price of $1,275.00 tax included, f.o.b. Kenora, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

J. De McKean,

Rev. J. R. Ballangrove, O.M.I.,
Principal, Kenora Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.
Nov. 5, 1926.

Dear Mr. Edgar,-

I have just wired you to the effect that there is a misunderstanding, and that it is not the intention to place the order for the Tumbler for the Kamloops School with your firm. I think you will remember when you were in Ottawa that I told you that your price was too high.

I did, however, mention the fact that I would give you the order for a similar machine required for the Indian Residential School at Kasern, and you will receive this order officially today.

Yours very truly,

R. GIBSON, M.R.
ASSISTANT FOR THE DEPARTMENT.

C. D. EDGAR, Esq.,

Kenora Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.
October 3rd 1928.

Dear Sir,

Two of our Sewing Machines are completely out of order and too old to be repaired. A third one is also in a very poor condition. Kindly order as soon as possible two new Machines, "Singers" preferably, an agent of this Company being located in Kenora.

The pews of the Chapel cannot accommodate all the children and the Staff, and we need a new one. The cost of a pew would be $36.00.

Hoping you will consider favorably my request, I remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Mr. Russell T. Perrier,
Act. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.
Enclosed please find letter received from the Principal of the Kenora School re new sewing machines and pews for the school.

I shall be glad to know if the Department will approve of the expenditure of $1,000.

Yours sincerely,

Frank Edwards

[Signature]

[Stamp]
Ottawa, November 19, 1925.

Gentlemen:

I have to request that you will arrange to supply, from your nearest branch office, for the use of the Indian residential school, Kenora, Ont., two (2) Singer sewing machines of the type described in your catalogue as follows:

No. 2 - 5 drawer machine, 127 - J G.O.

Please advise Mr. Frank Edwards, Indian Agent, Kenora, when these machines will be available, and he will furnish directions for delivery.

The account for the machines, which should be in duplicate, should show the retail price and discount of 50% allowed off the 90 day list price "on which terms purchase is made". Please forward the account to Mr. Edwards, who is being informed of the order placed with you, and requested, upon receipt of the two machines, to certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

Yours very truly,

F. H. Paget,
Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

Singer Sewing Machine Company,
Bank St.,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, November 19, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I have to inform you that, at the request of Very Rev. Father Magnan, O.M.I., Provincial Superior of the Oblate Order, the Department is placing an order for the supplying of two (2) Singer sewing machines for the use of the Kenora Indian Residential School. Mr. Agent Edwards also forwarded your request, and he has been informed that the order has been placed for these machines, and requested to furnish shipping directions, and to certify the account and forward it to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. E. Ballargeon, Esq.,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, November 19, 1926.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 24th ultimo, I have to inform you that the Department is today placing an order with the Singer Sewing Machine Company, here, to supply, for the use of the Kenora Indian Residential School, two (2) Singer sewing machines, of the type described in their catalogue as follows:

No. 2 - 5 Drawer Machine, 127 - 3 Q.O.

The above firm have been requested to notify you from their nearest branch office when these machines will be available, and you should then furnish full shipping directions.

The account, in duplicate, covering the cost of these machines will be sent you. This account will show the retail price and discount of 50% allowed off the 90 day list price "on which terms purchase is made". When the machines are delivered, if in good condition, you should certify the account and send it to the Department, in order that payment can be made.

You may arrange for the purchase of a new pew for the chapel of the type required by the Principal. We note that the estimated cost is $36. It is thought, however, that a pew that would be satisfactory for the purpose could be obtained at less cost. You should, however, consult the Principal as to the style and type of pew required, and arrange to purchase same at the lowest possible cost, forwarding an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, December 1, 1928.

Sir:

The Estimates for the coming fiscal year are now in course of preparation, and the Department would like a recommendation from you and from the Reverend Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School, concerning the most needed improvements. I understand that a small addition over the laundry, for the purpose of enlarging the Sisters' quarters, is quite urgent, and that a hopper should be provided. Three other improvements have been mentioned by the church authorities, and I should like to have your opinion concerning their urgency. I refer to an implement shed, a larger boat house and some clearing and drainage. Please let me have a recommendation at your early convenience.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR MCDONALD,
dated September 27th, 1928, on his inspection of the KENORA Indian Residential School.

Six new seats are needed for the Primary Room. [No. 3] will be the correct size.
Ottawa, November 15, 1928.

Sir:

The Separate School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Kenora Indian Residential School, states that six new desks are required for use in the primary room. In this connection I have to request that you will state the name of the manufacturer of the desks at present in use in this room, as it will be necessary, in order to have uniformity in the seating arrangements, if these extra desks are supplied, that they be of the same type as those at present in use. Please also state the size of the desks required. For your information, I may say that desks for primary grades are manufactured in the following sizes:

No. 6 for pupils 5 to 7 years,
No. 5 = 7 to 9
No. 4 = 10 to 12

When we have the information asked for, together with your recommendation as to whether you would advise that these extra desks be supplied or not, consideration will then be given to placing the order.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

RE - Fire Escapes for Indian School, Kenora

Following up the visit of our salesmen to your office recently, we take pleasure in quoting you as follows -

1- Chute Type Fire Escape for Kenora School, running from Boys Dormitory to ground. All as shown on blue print of our sheet #23738-1, dated December 10th, 1928, copy of which we attach.

Price - Five Hundred and Thirty Six Dollars ($536.00).

On two of these Escapes we would quote -

Eleven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($1,150.00).

Figures named in both cases are f.o.b. Kenora, Federal Government Sales Tax included.

The last figure named for two Escapes could be taken as covering an Escape from both the Boys and Girls Dormitories. It is not possible at this time to give a definite quotation on that from the Girls Dormitory, but from the information obtained by our Salesmen this price would be close enough for estimating purposes.

It is our hope that our proposal will be found attractive, and that we shall be called upon to supply the Escapes quoted you.

- over -
Kenora, Ont.
December 19th./28.

Sir:

Re. your letter 129-1-5 of the last inst. I visited the Kenora Indian Residential school yesterday to meet Rev. Father Provincial, Rev. Principal, and Brother Gauthier re. estimates for additions and improvements to the school in 1929.

Frigidaire - This is installed, but the school has asked for an expenditure of an additional $70.00 for an ice making coil. This was apparently omitted when the price was quoted before. I enclose letters from the Frigidaire Corporation, which I would be glad to have you return.

Re. Fire-escapes - Enclosed please find quotations and blueprint from the Manitoba Bridge & Iron Works, Winnipeg, for $1150.00 for the chute fire-escapes as recommended by the Kenora Fire Chief, and approved by the school authorities.

Addition over Laundry - Enclosed is rough sketch of this addition, made by Brother Gauthier. Estimated cost $3000.00.

Boathouse - Sketch of new boathouse, by Bro. Gauthier is enclosed. Estimated cost $700.00.

Lumber Shed - Sketch by Bro. Gauthier of proposed shed is enclosed. Estimated cost $650.00.

Barn - 20' X 36'. Estimated cost $650.00.

Clearing land and draining, about 10 acres, estimated cost $1000.

The Rev. Father Provincial says the wiring in the school is old, and not safe. I am asking the yard inspector to visit the school and give me a report. I cannot give an estimate until he has done so, but as the wires are not concealed I do not think it will be expensive.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy & Sec.,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Agent,
