Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed three sketches of improvements contemplated for Kenora Indian Residential School.

The little Addition, 20x30, over the Laundry is most necessary for the following reasons:

1. To give more adequate quarters for the Sisters;
2. To provide an Infirmary for the girls, Kenora School being the only one having no such infirmary.

Other sketches have been forwarded by Mr Agent Edwards. Hoping you will give this matter a favourable consideration, I remain,

Yours devotedly,

J. Magnan, O.M.I.
Provl.

Mr Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir,

As you have kindly accepted to reimburse the expenses incurred by Rev. Dr. Millargeon, Principal of Kenora School, has made for repairing the engine of his gasoline boat, I take the liberty to send you a full statement and vouchers.

I am going to Kenora today to meet Mr. Agent Edwards and have his advice on Kenora School improvements for next year.

Rev. Brother Gauthier will go to Pine Creek this week with instructions to draw a sketch of alterations and improvements contemplated for that school. It will be forwarded to you as soon as possible, with information as to cost, labor, etc.

I am glad Mr. Graham did not install a Delco at Pine Creek School this fall. A Delco is not sufficient at St. Philip's; it would be still less at Pine Creek. A year ago we have installed a double plant, Lister-Bronston, at our ecclesiastical College at Lebret, but as they are now served by the Provincial Plant, we could dispose of the bigger one, just the thing that would suit Father Brachet. The Engine is a 20 H.P. and the Generator develops 6K,120V. The cost was $2600.00.

The Department may prefer to buy a new one, but it is important to install a good one that will give satisfaction.

Yours very truly,

J. Magnan, O.M.I., Provincial.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.

Kenora, Ont.
Top Floor.—The boys dormitory should be rewired. This could be concealed by wiring from attic.

Most of the other defects on this floor are in the bathrooms and toilets. Switches for bathroom lights must be installed outside the door. The rules are very emphatic on this. I would recommend that a red light be placed at fire escape inside room and another light outside.

The main switch installed on this floor is very unsafe and the wires are not soldered. It appears that there is only one circuit for the whole building.

I would strongly recommend that a new main switch be installed preferably in the basement or ground floor with panel box with fuses to protect circuits on each floor.

In summing up, the wiring with few exceptions is in a very bad condition especially so for a building of this type. It would be advisable to rewire the whole building. If this is not done the items which I have mentioned should be seen to as early as possible.

I would estimate that a sum of from four to five hundred dollars would cover the necessary overhauling, and a sum of around seven hundred and fifty dollars would rewire the school.

Trusting this report meets with your approval,

Yours Truly,

J. Duncan,
District Inspector.
Capt. Edwards,
Indian Agent
Kenora Ont.

Dear Sir,

At your request I inspected Catholic Indian School and found the following defects which should be remedied as soon as possible.

Basement in very unsafe condition. Should be rewired and porcelain sockets to replace brass shell sockets.

Ground floor—The baking room and kitchen should be rewired as the insulation in some places on wires is all charred and in unsafe condition. There are switches in children's dining room, passage leading to kitchen, class room, Father's sitting room, & Sister's dining room requiring attention or renewal. Lights in Father's dining room & Sister's dining room should be rewired and put in proper shape.

First Floor---In the guest room receptacle should be installed for stove & wiring put in shape. Receptacle should be installed in Sister's sitting room, switch & wiring to be overhauled. Sister's dept. wall bracket to be rewired & receptacle for heater. There are several switches on this floor wired with cord. This should be remedied.
Kenora, Ont.
December 27th/26.

Sir:

In reference to my letter of the 16th inst. re. wiring the Kenora Indian Residential school, Mr. J. Duncan, District Inspector of the Hydro Electric Power Commission, has handed me his report, which is enclosed herewith.

I shall be glad to receive instructions as to what should be done at the present time, owing to the danger of fire. The estimates given are only approximate and the local electricians should be required to tender on the job, provided you think it necessary for the work to be done.

The Inspector's charges are $6.00 for his report. I shall be glad to receive authority for this expense and upon receipt of same, shall send in the vouchers.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

As requested by you we have figured on two Open Chute Fire Escapes for the Indian School, Kenora and suggest erecting the one from the Boys' Dormitory on the South Side of the Building and one from the Girls' Dormitory on the West Side of the Building after the proposed additional storey is built on the Laundry Room.

By erecting the Fire Escapes in these positions, turns can be avoided.

The price for the two open Chute Fire Escapes with necessary brackets and bolts would be £1185. delivered at the Indian School.

It is impossible to give an exact quotation on the labor to erect these Fire Escapes. This would necessarily need to be done on a cost plus basis. However we believe that £200. would cover the labor on this work.

Thanking you for the opportunity of quoting you, we are,

Yours very truly,

THE CAMPBELL HEATING COMPANY.

Per. [Signature]

DMC/C.
Kenora, Ont.

Ottawa 10th June, 1929.

Sir,

I have to inform you that on the 6th May the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co., Limited, Toronto, wrote the Department with respect to their account for one motor driven Beaver-Vorclone Tumbler supplied for the Indian Residential School at Kenora. They were advised in reply to communicate with you. A further letter, which is dated the 1st June, has been received at the Department. In it reference is made to an invoice from the Company for the amount of $1,275.00 for goods said to have been delivered in January. Seemingly the Department has not received a voucher or report from you in this matter. Kindly make full report, and if payment is due by the Department to the Company, submit a voucher.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, June 15, 1929.

Dear Sir,

I beg to draw your attention to a paylist dated the 22nd September, 1928, in connection with labour performed at the Kenora Residential School, which paylist seemingly was transmitted to the Department under cover of your letter of the 24th October. The name of T.H. Maranda appears on this paylist. Seemingly this man should have been paid for 50½ hours work, not 60½ as shown on the paylist. This being the case, Maranda received an overpayment of $3.50, which amount you should collect from him and forward to the Department without delay under cover of a letter.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Chief Accountant.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
June 18, 1929.

MEMORANDUM: Honourable Charles Stewart,

It was reported to the Department some time ago that the electric wiring in the Kamora Re Co Indian Residential School was in very bad shape. The Departmental Architect, who recently visited Kamora, examined the wiring and has reported that same is in a dangerous condition. Will you please advise me of the name of a competent electrician in Kamora who can be employed to make the necessary repairs and alterations to the electric wiring at this School, in order to make the system safe.

[Signature]

[Signature]
MEMORANDUM: Dr. Scott.

Some time ago it was reported to the Department that the electric wiring in the R.C. School at Kenora was in poor shape. While at this school I examined the wiring and found same to be in a dangerous condition, and I would recommend that the wiring be completely overhauled, and the necessary repairs and changes made to make the system safe. If you approve I would ask you to please furnish the name of a competent electrician in Kenora who can be employed to do this work.

[Signature]

ARCHITECT.
Ottawa, June 24, 1929.

Mr. John Johanson, Electrician, of Kenora, may be employed to look after the work of having the electric wiring in the Roman Catholic Indian residential school overhauled.

D. S. G. I. A.
Kenora, Ont.
June 22nd./29.

Sir:

Referring to your letter 129-1-5 re. labour on the Kenora School, on my copy of the labour return for week ending Sept. 22nd. it is shown that T.N. Karanda worked 10½ hours on Monday and 10 hours each day the balance of the week. On Saturday the other men did not work but Maranda put in the full day.

This figures out for him 60½ hours that week. I have seen Inspector Hudson who was in charge of the work at the time, and he informs me that the amount paid Maranda is correct.

Trusting this explains the matter satisfactorily,

I am,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

R/S

The Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

June 21st 1929.

H. G. Orr, Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

According to reports the cement floor recently installed in the Indian School at Kenora, Ont., is very dusty, and it has occurred to us that possibly you would be interested in our DuroLithic Mastic floor covering for this cement.

DuroLithic Mastic is Trinidad Lake Asphalt Mastic properly fluxed so as to give long service without dusting, or marking up, and it is resilient and waterproof. The price is very reasonable when service is considered.

This Flooring can be had in plain finish or choice of colors, Green, Tan or Brownish Red. We shall be glad to send you samples of these colors if you are interested.

We are now, through the use of Genasco Hardener, laying floors in Hospitals, Offices, Schools, and Industrial Buildings with entire satisfaction. Although we know that you have used Mastic Flooring, we do not know off-hand that you have used it since we have been making floors with this Genasco Hardener.

Trusting that this may receive your favorable consideration, we remain

Yours very truly,

VULCAN ASPHALT & SUPPLY CO. LTD.

[Signature]

PRESIDENT.

Kenora Indian Residential School,
August 2nd 1929

Dear Sir,

With your kind approval and with the definite understanding that the Department of Indian Affairs would bear the expense, I have repaired the gas-engine of our boat in 1928. Engine and boat are now in first class condition and give full satisfaction.

A statement of the cost was forwarded to the Department in due time, but the bill could not be paid because no funds were then available.

Kindly let me have a cheque covering the enclosed statement as soon as possible. I am now in great need of money because the Department has cancelled an advance of $800.00 that had been granted during the last nine months. It was my intention to advise the Department as soon as I could do without this credit.

Yours sincerely,

J.H. Baillargeon, M.I.
Principal.

Mr Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.
Kenora Indian Residential School,
August 2nd 1929.

Dear Sir,

Thankfully, a part of the pressing improvements requested for our school has been granted. I had made up my mind to wait till next year for the other requirements. But lately, a storm has blown to pieces our miserable implements shed, and the immediate construction of a new one has become an absolute necessity.

Allow me to ask you a further credit of $500.00 for this purpose.

Hoping to receive a favourable answer, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

J.E. Baillargeon, C.I.
Principal.

Mr Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

7500 available

Also fireplaces, electric wiring, buying lumber.
Ottawa, August 20th, 1929.

Sir,-

Referring to your letter of July 16th with reference to the report of the District Electrical Inspector, you may employ Mr. John Johanson, Electrician of Kenora to carry out the necessary alterations and repairs to the wiring system of the Kenora School. The work should be done in accordance with the rules and regulations covering such work in the Province of Ontario and on completion inspected by the District Inspector of the Hydro Electric Power Commission.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, August 21, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to reimbursement for repairs on the marine engine at the Kenora Indian Residential School. I note you refer to a definite understanding concerning the Department's reimbursement; but I am unable to find that any authority has been directed to you. At the present time, our funds are extremely limited, as very urgent improvements have had to be undertaken at your school.

I have also your letter of the same date, and I note that the implement shed has been blown down. Arrangements have been made to finance its replacement, and I have to authorize you to expend not more than $500 for this purpose. If a saving can be effected, the Department will be glad. It is understood that the work will be done by day labour, under the supervision of Brother Gauthier. You should requisition to Mr. Indian Agent Edwards for the materials required and he will make the purchase.

I should be glad if you would let the Department have a report, showing the detail of the alterations and improvements that you have been authorized to effect under the supervision of Brother Gauthier. An estimate of the cost should be forwarded at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. B. Baillargeon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Kenora Indian Res. School,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, August 21, 1929.

Sir:

I have to enclose copy of official letter of today's date to the Rev. Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School. You will note that he has received authority to replace the implement shed, and he will requisition to you for the materials required.

Yours obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

On 160-5, Father Magnan's letter of August 31st lists the requests in connection with Indian residential schools in his ecclesiastical province. Among the requests there appears the following:-

A Hog pen for the Kenora Indian Residential School, at an estimated cost of . . . . . . $650.

Inside painting . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 500.
Ottawa, September 7, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that Father Plourde, O.M.I., has visited the Department, on behalf of the Provincial of the Oblate Order for your Ecclesiastical Province, and, among other requests, he asks that the Department supply a galvanized granary for the use of the Kenora Indian Residential School. I am pleased to inform you that I am today authorizing Mr. Indian Agent Edwards to expend the amount of $150 in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. J. E. Baillargeon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kenora, Ont.
Ottawa, September 7, 1929.

Sir:

The church authorities have requested the Department to provide a galvanized iron granary for the use of the Kenora Indian Residential School. Please discuss this with the Rev. Principal, ascertain his exact requirements and make the necessary arrangements. $150 may be expended in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aest. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
Saint-Boniface, Man. September 6th, 1929

Dear Sir,

Kindly allow me to write over again about the repairs of the Gas Engine at Kenora School. It is not my intention to trouble you much longer about this matter.

While in Ottawa, about two years ago, I asked you if the Department would buy a new Gas engine for the Kenora School Boat, as the one sent by the Department was completely out of order. The cost of a new engine was over a thousand dollars. You told me then that you would pay only half, or a little over five hundred dollars. The School was not in a position to spend any money and this matter was left in abeyance.

During summer 1928, the Reverend Principal decided to repair the old engine, and in doing so he was sure to save money. In fact, the total cost of the repairs was only $464.00. It is true that Brother Luthier worked at it for many days, but no salary was charged.

I said the old engine purposely, for it was welded in many places. I have seen that myself.

In the fall, 1928, I went to Ottawa with R. Fr Guy and I submitted to you again this matter. You seemed to be pleased and you told me you were ready to pay the bill in full. Unfortunately I had not all the vouchers and the payment was delayed. These were forwarded to the Department December 17th. I am glad to say that January 1st, I received a letter from Mr. McLean—No. 13—1—5—stating that "funds were completely assigned, and that consideration to reimbursement could not be given at that time." I was greatly surprised to receive from Reverend Fr Baillargeon a copy of Mr. MacKenzie's letter—No. 13—1—5, August 1st, stating "he was unable to find that any authority has been to him." No wonder! He has no written promise, but the oral promise of a high official of the Department is surely just as good.

Last May you paid me a kind visit and you gave me then the same assurance. As I am the loser you will understand easily why I make myself particularly uneasy about this matter.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from the Kenora Indian Residential School in which the Principal says the boat house is now completed and the new addition to the school building is almost completed. He suggests that it would be better to put a coat or two of paint on the new lumber this Fall, - including the new implement shed as soon as it is built - and probably the Department would agree to this. The carpenter is a good painter and they could employ him for the work, providing we supplied the paint. The amount required for this would be about $375.00 for paint and wages. He has not yet sent in a list of work authorized and what has been done this year on the school, as requested by the Department in a previous letter.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont

Dear Sir,

Referring to your #129-1-5 of the 20th ultimo re employing Mr. John Johansson to carry out the necessary alterations and repairs to wiring system, the Principal informs me that he has asked Mr. Cheyne, Electrician of Kenora, to do this work instead of employing Mr. Johansson as instructed in your letter. The reason for this was that Mr. Cheyne was doing certain other work at the school and he did not think it would be reasonable to employ another electrician as Cheyne was doing part of the work.

I trust this meets with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent

Dear Sir,

I have received a letter from the Reverend Principal, Kenora Indian School in which he states that being in need of beds to replace some old ones beyond repair, he waited until he saw what was needed for the new girl's dormitory and infirmary, which is nearly completed. He makes application for the following:

- 2 dozen beds 6' x 2½'
- 2 " mattresses 6' x 2½', or material to make them.
- 1 dozen mattressed 6' x 3' to replace old ones on larger beds.
- 2 dozen pillows
- 16 window shades 5½" x 2½"
- 10 6" x 34"

These shades are for the new part and for the boy's dormitory.

They also require 1 dozen new chairs for the rooms. These should not cost more than about $3.00 each. I shall be glad to receive authority for the above.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent
The Campbell Heating Co.

Through all our negotiations in reference to the fire escapes it was always pointed out that the present type were useless, and if the writer remembers correctly, Mr. Orr and Brother Gautier were both in accord with this view.

The Chute type fire escape was advocated by the Kenora Fire Chief and Father Ballargeon and they still seem to favor this type of fire escape. However the one set of fire escape is completed and the pole removed.

We might also point out that our equipment is on the job, and owing to the delay caused by waiting for information it will be necessary to remove this equipment and replace it again when a decision is made. Therefore we would ask you for a decision at the earliest possible moment.

Yours truly,

THE CAMPBELL HEATING COMPANY.

Per. [signature]

DMC/C.
KENORA, ONT.
BRANCH Oct. 8, 1929.

Capt. P. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir!

Re Indian School Fire Escapes.

During a conversation with Father Ballargeon this morning he was under the impression that one of the present Fire Escapes be left on the job, that is, the platforms on the North West corner of the Building should be left as they are with the poles left in position for sliding down in an emergency.

You no doubt remember the suggestions of Mr. Orr and Brother Gautier at the time that we were instructed to figure on a steel stair fire escape in place of the chute type of which we had the contract.

At that time it was decided that the landings of the present fire escape be moved around to the new addition on the North and that stairs be put in between these landings.

To refresh your memory we would point out that it was necessary to change the location of the platforms on the South West corner of the school so that the stair could be put in and turned around the corner, landing on the South side of the building - This of course necessitated the removal of the poles.

When we estimated on the cost of erecting steel stairs naturally our price was with a view of using the present platforms on the new fire escapes - It is therefore necessary to ask an additional price of Three Hundred and Sixteen ($316.) Dollars if new platforms are used.
Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed please find letter received from the Campbell Heating Company re fire escapes at the Kenora Indian Residential School. The Principal now requests that one of the old fire escapes be left so as to make additional protection for the children. The Campbell Heating Company's letter explains the whole matter and if you think it advisable to leave the present fire escape and use additional material for the stair fire escape, namely $316.00, I shall be glad to have the necessary authority.

Yours obedient servant,

Frank Edward

Indian Agent

Sir:

The church authorities report that a 10 horse power motor, 220 volts, 3 phase, is now required at the Kenora Indian Residential School. It appears that the old equipment no longer develops the necessary power. Please make enquiries as to the need for this motor and secure a price from Kenora or Winnipeg distributors. This should be forwarded with your recommendation as soon as possible.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Referring to Mr. Orr's visit to Kenora and our inspection of the Kenora Indian Residential School (R.O.). Mr. Orr requested me to get a price from the Campbell Heating Company for installing an extra toilet. Mr. Campbell informs me this would cost in the neighborhood of $88.00.

In connection with the replacing of closet that was broken by the boys, Mr. Campbell informs me this would cost $42.00 for the outfit and $10.00 for labor. I have not given instructions as yet for this to be done as the amount seems high, but I have given instructions to repair two others at a cost of $12.00 as authorized by Mr. Orr.

I shall be glad to receive instructions from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

Indian Agent

P.S. The Sister at the school also requests that four extra wash basins be installed. Mr. Campbell informs me the price of this would be roughly $195.00. She also requests that Mr. Orr supply five glass doors for cupboards. These would cost $6.00 or $7.00 each.
Nov. 27, 1929.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the providing of an extra toilet in the Kemora R. C. School, I beg to say that you may have this work done. You may also arrange for the installation of four extra wash basins and the supplying of glass doors for the cupboards.

Your obedient servant,

A. J. MacKenzie,
Acting, Assistant Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kemora, Ont.

I have received your order dated Nov. 28th, 1929.

In regard to your request for information regarding size motor, voltage, etc., I would advise you to install the following and the lens required for that size as follows:

1 - 10 H.P., 220 Volt, 7 Phase, 60 Cycle, Induction Motor complete with base and starter, 100 A.C., C.B. Switch, 3-1/2" Lens and Lens Frame ($135.50).

We are unable to give free P.O. Service, and will be obliged to charge for delivery. It would take approximately two days to deliver by air express.

The above order, I can fully guarantee, as I installed the same outfit complete in the store last year for a private lady who owns a 4.1 in a very short time.

I look forward to receiving your valued order, I am

Yours Truly,

Boat-House.

The work was started on June the 17th 1929 on the boat-house which measures 20'0"x 50'0"x 12'0" studding. The bldg rests on 6 piers built with sawed ties 6"x9"x 8'0" long, secured with 1"x 12 spikes. Outside ones, at the front, are in II feet of water.

Between the piers, to support the frame, timbers 6"x8"x26' reach the middle of each pier, and the frame is trussed so as to carry the weight to the center of the piers. The end nearest the shore rests on a timber 6"x8"x20' and is trussed the same way. There are two windows on each side, one door 3'x 7' in the middle at shore end, one 2'6"x 6'6" at the far end of the south side and the large door on the lake 10'x 12', and is hung on track and slides to a right angle against the side.

Five feet from each side two timbers 8"x8" serve to carry the walks and principally the trussed arches to raise the boat. Red pine siding is used on outside of frame, and B.C. cedar shingles on roof.

Addition.

The addition to the school, over the laundry, has been carefully built to make it cold proof as much as possible. The frame is of 2"x6" studs, 16" center with one outside and inside sheeting of 1"x6" tongued and grooved red pine well seasoned, and two plies of paper each side, in and out. The paper used is one ply of first quality tarred, and one ply of Barrett roofing lapped 4 in., and strapped over. The paper was placed horizontally on both sides. Outside it was strapped only horizontally, but inside it is strapped vertically, 16" center with 1x2 and horizontally between vertical straps on every lap.

The outside is finished with brick veneer to match the rest of the building as well as the roof and cornices. Here at the cornice special care was taken to bring the two ply of paper without any break around the cornice and over the roof under shingles. Cornices are also painted to match. Metal 26 galvanized has been used on flat part of roof and wet troughs of proper size have been installed.

The inside is finished with three coats hard wall plaster or metallic lath, and good work to match adjoining rooms. Joists 2"x12"x20' are fitted with 3 rows of bridging here used to carry the weight without settle in laundry; the upper joists are 2"x12". Floors are double thru knot, using 1x8 red pine very dry, for finish.

The ceiling in dormitory is metallic to match the adjoining, and the other below is plastered.

Heating, plumbing and electric wiring in conduit have been carried on with the construction, and in accordance with the laws of the Province. Other changes in old buildings have been made as per plan.

The first space at the south end is already finished, and the other at the north side is under construction.

Implement Shed.

An implement shed 10'0"x 34'0", on cement foundation, has also been built, but the doors are not made yet.

November 30th 1929
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs.

Ottawa.

Sir:

Enclosed please find return of labour sheets in duplicate received from the Principal of the Henora Indian Residential School for work done on the new buildings and additions.

Also enclosed please find the Principal's report as to the progress of the work, which was authorized by Mr. Orr.

You will note there is a balance due the Principal for labour paid of $643.37 and he requires an additional advance as the work is not yet completed. I asked him much more he would require, but he said he could not give me any estimate. I informed him you would require this information, but promised to send his request on, and await a reply from you.

The work done has been well done, and I do not think the cost is excessive, but it appears to me when we get all the accounts in, it will amount to more than the Department originally intended spending, although I have not the exact figures of what was agreed to be spent.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your request over the telephone yesterday for information regarding size of motor, voltage, etc., I would advise you to install the following and take pleasure in quoting you as follows:

1 - 10 H.P. 220 Volt, 3 Phase, 60 Cycle, induction motor complete with base and pulley, 1800 R.P.M., ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-THREE DOLLARS and FIFTY CENTS ($133.50).

1 - outlet hammer automatic starter for 10 H.P. 220 volt, 3 phase, 60 cycle motor, THIRTY-ONE DOLLARS and SEVENTY-FIVE CENTS ($31.75).

We are quoting you the above price F.O.B. Kenora, and could make delivery for motor in about three days. It would take us approximately ten days to get delivery of the automatic starter.

The above motor, I can fully guarantee, as I installed the same outfit complete in the Stone Boat orke approximately two years ago and it has given every satisfaction.

Hoping to receive your valued order, I am

Yours truly,

...........H.Cheyne...........

Kenora, Ont.,
December 2nd, 1929.

St. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter No. 129-1-5 of the 25th ult., enclosed please find copy of quotation by H. Cheyne, Electrical Contractor, Kenora, for 10 H.P. motor, 220 volts, 3 phase, for Kenora Indian Residential School (RC).

The Principal has been in to see me this morning and informs me he must have this motor at once as his old one has played out. I have, therefore, instructed Mr. Cheyne to supply the motor and the starter at a price of $165.25 as it must be supplied immediately. This is the cheapest that could be purchased locally and I trust what I have done meets with your approval.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Capt. Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir:-

Re Septic Tank at Catholic Indian School Kenora.

The above Septic Tank is in poor condition. It has for a load the wastes from all the toilets, baths &c., as well as the discharge from all laundry and kitchen fixtures. It is at all times overloaded with grease, which appears to be carried to the disposal bed with the very large amount of flush water. This tank is kept working at this time by using large amounts of solvent chemical. The staff at the school have for the last few years to clean out the different compartments every few months.

The siphon equipment is not in working order, and there is no way provided for emptying this part of the system to make inspection or make repairs.

The filter beds and distributing nozzles need attention, and the outlet from field tile and underdrainage is at present emptying on open ground about ten feet from the shore line where it runs in a rotten stream above grade into the lake. The point where this sewerage enters the lake is not more than ten feet from where the drinking water line is taken to the pumps, although this water intake is said to extend some distance out in the lake. I would say that provision should be made to have it carefully examined as soon as the weather per-
Kenora, Ontario,
Dec. 3rd., 1929.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Sir:

Enclosed please find letter received from C. Ratchford, in connection with the septic tank at the Kenora Indian Residential School, (R.C.). This School has had considerable trouble with this tank and we have had Mr. Ratchford put it right temporarily. On the last occasion I asked him to make a report on this trouble, hence the letter. It would be an expensive matter to do anything this winter, but perhaps the Department might put in an amount in the estimates next summer. I understand the septic tank was built under instructions of the Department about ten years ago before I was appointed Agent. Dr. Ferguson informs me that the water is tested occasionally and there does not seem to be anything wrong with it.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

Form No. 101
Ottawa, January 16, 1930.

Dear Sir,

I beg to say the Department received your letter of the 27th December with voucher No.4887 in favour of the Campbell Heating Company, Kenora, and in reply I beg to point out that on the 18th November you submitted a voucher (No.4799) for $1062.00 in favour of this firm covering steel stair fire escape supplied for the Kenora Indian School, which article is charged for in voucher No.4887, which voucher also covers other charges. Voucher No.4887 is being paid by official cheque No.6719 less the charge of $1062.00. The cheque mentioned is being drawn for £1415.24. This cheque is going forward to the Campbell Heating Company. Kindly explain the matter to the Company.

Yours truly,

F.H.Paget
Chief Accountant.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

He would like, if possible, for you to send him a statement showing the cheques sent him for wages and what has been charged up against these cheques from the Department, as he wishes to keep the expenditure of the different items separately, and would know what additional vouchers to send in.

January 29th, 1930

Dear Sir,

I shall be glad to have authority to purchase refills for fire extinguishers in all the schools in this Agency. These are supposed to be refilled each year and if I had the necessary authority I could make arrangements, or if you have the number of extinguishers at each school, perhaps the material for filling could be shipped from Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent
Ottawa, February 7, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, relative to the supplying of refills for the fire extinguishers in use at the schools in your Agency.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery at each of the schools of the refills required to recharge the extinguishers on hand. When these recharges are received, it is expected that the principals will see that they are installed and each extinguisher placed in good condition and ready for immediate use in case of fire. I shall be pleased if you will give the purchase of these refills your early attention and have them forwarded to each school with the necessary instructions to the principals to have them placed in the extinguishers.

Accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the refills for each school separately.

Your obedient servant,

A. J. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Tenora, Ont.

February 18, 1930.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of January 27th last, I beg to say that I do not understand the statement it contained. It is true that I have received from the Department:

- £1000.00 in July 1929.
- £600.00 "Sept."
- £1000.00 "Dec."

But what about all the wages I have paid, which are not mentioned? For instance, what about the £779.96 I have spent for clearing land? Your letter shows only the £600.00 I have received in this connection.

I was authorized £500.00 to have an Implement Shed put up; I have paid for wages and material concerning same £205.30 and have not as yet received a cheque accounting for this.

This confusion arises from the fact that what I apprehended has occurred! I had taken all possible care to keep the different items separated, and they have been mixed up.

I might say that the £1643.37 had nothing whatever to do with the clearing of land nor with the building of the shed; that sum was solely for wages paid by me for the building of the new addition and the boat-house. A cheque of £1000.00 had been received from the Department at the time the said account was sent, which left a balance of £643.37 to be paid yet. Later on, another cheque of £1000.00 was received which then left on hand £356.63. But we had to keep working at the addition to the school-house during past December and January, as per request of Labor force enclosed.

So, instead of having on hand the sum of £751.33, I have only £56.33. Now, as there is a sum amounting to £205.30 due me by the Department re Implement Shed, and £11.95 material for new addition, the sum of £131.92 is the balance owed me at the present time.

Please give this statement to the Department, and let them know that I am in need of the money owed me.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain Sir,

Yours faithfully,

J.E. Baillargeon, O.M.
Captain Frank D'Arde
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Cheyne the Electrician who has been doing the electrical work at the Kenora Indian Residential School has informed me that the Rev. Principal wishes that wires be installed in the following buildings:

- New Implement Shed
- Store Shed
- New Boat House
- Chicken House

I also suggest installing outlets in the new addition in the Rooms for the convenience of the Sisters.

The cost for the whole installation will not exceed $125.00 and as the lights are necessary I would recommend that this work be done.

If you approve, I suppose Mr. Cheyne can proceed with the work.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, April 19, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 14th instant relative to the request of the Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School to have several of the outbuildings wired for electric light, and also to put in outlets in the new addition in the rooms for the convenience of the Sisters.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with an electrician to install the outlets required in the new addition. The cost of having this work done should be kept as low as possible. The Department is not prepared to authorize the wiring and installing of lights in the outbuildings mentioned in your letter.

When the outlets have been placed in the new addition, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of having the work done.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. MacKintosh,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, May 3rd, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, relative to the request of the Principal of the Kenora Indian Residential School to be supplied with an additional six Pyrene fire extinguishers for the use of the school.

In this connection I have to inform you that the Department is today placing an order with the Pyrene Manufacturing Co. of Canada, Ltd., Toronto, to ship, addressed to the Principal, charges prepaid, the following:

6 - 1½ Gallon Thermone Fire Extinguishers, complete with non-freeze chemicals.

The above firm have been requested to forward their account, in duplicate, to you, covering the cost of these extinguishers, together with receipt attached for the amount of the shipping charged prepaid by them. When these extinguishers are received, you should certify the account and send it to the Department for payment.

Please advise the Principal that the order for these extinguishers has been placed, and he should accept delivery when they arrive at Kenora. They should be distributed throughout the school building at strategic points and readily accessible in case of fire.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

MAY 9 1930

RECORDS

[Handwritten text]

Mr. O'Mara, District Agent, has forwarded a report from Mr. R. C. Ratchford, Superintendent of Schools, regarding the condition of the school at Menora. Mr. Ratchford has visited the school and has provided a copy of his report.

Mr. O'Mara, in his report, suggests several improvements that need to be made to the school facilities. These include the installation of better lighting, improved ventilation, and the addition of more seating.

How much do you believe these changes will improve the learning environment?

[Signature]

Frank Edwards

Assistant Deputy, C. S. Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
KENORA ROMAN CATHOLIC SCHOOL AGAIN HAVING TROUBLE WITH WATER SUPPLY PLEASE WIRE SOON AS POSSIBLE IF YOU WILL AUTHORIZE ANY OF CAMPBELL HEATING COMPANY'S SUGGESTIONS AS PER THEIR LETTER SENT YOU MAY EIGHTH

FRANK EDWARDS
We are advising Proposal One for the reason that the pump, motor and suction line are of the proper capacity to do this job properly, and in the case of the Indian School being without fire protection except that supplied by their own pumping equipment, we strongly urge the installation of Proposal One, along with the present equipment as an auxiliary.

As you will note, Proposal two is only a 1500 Gallon per hour pump and this is not sufficient to do the complete job properly.

Proposal three is our second choice owing to the fact that the pump is of the proper size, but you are now dependent upon the one motor and should it be out of commission you are again without fire protection in the School.

Proposal four you will note is again a 1500 Gallon per hour pump.

INITIAL -

One 1000 Gallon per hour Fairbanks-Morse Pump, belt driven from the present line shaft and motor - One tight pulley on the Pump only and 1 - 4 x 10 friction clutch pulley on the line shafts. One 2½" single belt. The Pump to replace the existing Keyers-Bulldozer Pump - The existing suction line is 2½" and as pointed out formerly, is much too small;

The cost of replacing the existing Pump as set out in proposal Five is Three Hundred and Forty-Seven ($347.00) Dollars.

Father Ballargeon also requires a new Toilet Tank in the Girls' Playroom Lavatory and some further plumbing repairs, one of them being a leak in one of the soil stacks which is badly staining the wall.

It is impossible to give you a figure on this class of work but the approximate price, including labor would be Thirty ($30.00) Dollars.

We trust that the information contained in this letter will be sufficient for the Department to act quickly as the state of affairs existing at the Indian School at the present time is not only dangerous but exceedingly inconvenient to the Residents and we are being urged for speedy action in this matter.

Yours truly,

THE CAMPBELL PLATING COMPANY,

Per. [Signature]

[Signature]
The Campbell Heating Co.

The electric work to be done in the approved manner with entrance switch, pressure switch and starting switch.

This proposal is the proper and thorough way to install this job -

The cost of carrying out the work according to this proposal would be Two Thousand and Seventy-three ($2073.00) Dollars.

SPECIAL PROPOSAL -

One 1500 Gallon per hour Fairbanks-Morse Pump with 2 Horse Power Motor, the pump to be chain driven - Install 1000 feet of 3" suction line with proper foot valves and relief valves as set forth in proposal one - Friction loss 3.8 feet per thousand in 3" suction line;

The cost of doing this work would be One Thousand Five Hundred and Sixty-six ($1866.00) Dollars.

GENERAL PROPOSAL -

One 2500 Gallon per Hour Fairbanks-Morse Pump, belt driven from the present shaft and motor with tight pulley only and one 17" x 4" clutch pulley on the line shaft - Supply one 4" Leather Belt - Install 1000 feet of 4" suction line, as laid down in first proposal;

The cost of doing this work in this manner would be One Thousand Seven Hundred and Seventy-six ($1776.00) Dollars.

SPECIAL PROPOSAL -

One 1500 Gallon per hour Fairbanks-Morse Pump, belt driven from the present shaft and motor with tight pulley only and one 10 x 4 friction clutch pulley on the line shaft - Supply 1 - 3" leather belt - Install 1000 feet 3" suction line with foot valves etc., as in first proposal;

The cost of doing this work would be One Thousand Three Hundred and Twenty-six ($1326.00) Dollars.

With the four preceding proposals the present pump and suction line could be put into shape at an additional cost and could be used as an auxiliary outfit.

May we point out to you that an auxiliary pumping outfit is very necessary in a Building of this kind. Not only could it be used as an auxiliary outfit, but in case of fire both pumps could be put into service.
KENORA, ONT
BRANCH April 30, 1930.

Department of Indian Affairs,
c/o Capt. F. Edwards,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Sirs:

As requested by yourself and Father Ballargeon we have inspected the present Water System and Pump Outfit in connection with this School and wish to report as follows:

The Lake level is about 22 feet below the Pump and this requires a Pump in first class condition to handle water with a lift of this distance. The present pump could be put into condition if it were possible to remove it for a period of from six to ten days, but this is impossible because it would leave the School without a water system of any kind or fire protection; in fact this has been one of their difficulties, that every time a repair was made to the pump, they were left without fire protection of any kind, as well as the inconvenience of being without water.

We find that the suction line into the Lake is only 2½". The suction line is approximately 1000 feet into the lake and the pump itself is not capable of taking care of a great deal more than the resistance created by the friction in a line of this size. The suction line should be 4".

We have five proposals which we wish to set forth,

1. Install a 2500 Gallon per hour Fairbanks-Morse Pump connected on the same base with a Three Horse Power Motor, the pump to be chain driven. Install 1000 feet of 4" suction line into the Lake; friction loss at this suction line would be 2.20 feet per hundred. On this suction line it would be necessary to place a 4" foot valve and also on the pump installation a relief valve along with the check valves and globe valves required.
Dear Sir,

The Principal of the Indian Residential School at Renora has been having a lot of trouble with the water system. As a result, the school has been without water. I requested the Campbell Hartin Co. to examine the water system.

As we are including in this report herewith, it seems that the water system is pretty well worn out and very old. To the best of my knowledge there is no way to supply for their needs, so there is no way to get anything done should be done.

I shall be glad to receive instructions as to what should be done in this matter and also instructions as to the new toilet tank in the girl's playroom lavatory and the further plans required.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards

Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
May authorize Campbell Heating Co., proceed with first proposal water supply Kenora School.

DUNGAN O SCOTT.

Very Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to conversation with Mr. Perrier when you were in Ottawa a few days ago. It was understood that approximately $4,000 could be expended on improvements at the Kenora Indian Residential School. It had been suggested that land be cleared, drained and fenced, that a hogpen be erected, the wharf repaired and some interior decorating undertaken. I now write to inform you that it has been found necessary to expend nearly $3,000 on very urgent repairs to the water supply and sewage disposal systems. Will you please correspond with the Rev. Principal and let me have a recommendation concerning how the $1,000 which remains for this school can best be expended.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I beg to report that the Catholic Indian School has been completely rewired and is in excellent condition.

The basement has been rewired in armoured cable.
The 1st floor in metal moulding except the kitchen & bakery which is in conduit.
2nd floor in metal moulding.
3rd floor in conduit.
A new service entrance has also been installed.
The through lights, switches, lights over wash basins also lights at fire escape have been installed according to rules.
The workshop has been rewired in armoured cable.

I am pleased to notify you that the whole school wiring is in a safe condition as regards fire and safety & now conforms to the rules & regulations of the school commission.

I would like to add that the wiring has been installed in a neat & creditable manner.

Enclosed please find certificate covering above installation.

Yours Truly

CAPT. FRANK EDWARDS,
KENORA, Ont.
I have long delayed to answer your letter of May the 14th because, at first, I did not know what recommendation to make to the Department.

We were sorely disappointed, the Reverend Father Principal of Kenora School and myself, to hear that the greater part, if not all, of the allowance of £4,000.00 already incurred for the many improvements and repairs contemplated for years past, would be expended on repairs to the water supply and sewage disposal systems. Naturally, these unexpected repairs must be done without delay, but we hoped that an additional grant could be granted for this purpose.

We will drop, if necessary, the hoeing, land clearing and repairing to the barn, though it is fast decaying and the level of the lake being low, it could be raised in order to have it repaired this summer, but we insist on having the land fenced, the warehouse enlarged and lined with galvanized iron sheets and the walls of the school strengthened for the following reasons: As there is no fence at all, the cattle wander far away from the stable in the bush and a great deal of time is lost every day in looking for them; the warehouse is very much too small and groceries, flour etc must be protected against rats; the school having been enlarged and the wiring changed, the walls are, in many places, in a very poor condition and need to be patched. We figure that the total cost will be about £2,500.00.

We believe that the Kenora School, being located in a city and many visitors asking to see the building, should be kept in a good condition, in the same condition as the other Kenora School.

We hope the Department will consider favourably our requests.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. J. Maclean
Provincial

Indian Residential School
Kenora, Ont.
June 12th., 1930.

Dear Sir:

Here we are nearing the middle of June, and nothing has been heard of our requisitions of May 6th. and May 22nd., in which, amongst other articles, screens for the windows and doors of the new addition were asked for. These are urgent for; the most troublesome little insect, the mosquito, is unceasingly molesting the Revd. Sisters and the children.

We presume that Captain Edwards sent our requisitions to the Department. It may be due to his absence from town that we have not, as yet, received a reply. Since his absence will continue for a couple weeks more, we can not wait until his return for a permit to have these screens made. Besides it will take time before they will be ready to be put in, and the screens are an absolute necessity just now.

On May 6th., I also reported to Captain Edwards that we were lacking of four cows, telling him that we had not a sufficient supply of milk for our children, and that it was urgent to have more cows. The situation is still the same after over a month, and I have not heard anything concerning the matter.

Now, just as I was writing this letter, an accident has occurred in the boys' toilet, where one of the boys has accidentally dropped a piece of wood over the bowl smashing it to pieces. The bowl will have to be replaced at the cost of approximately $30.00. I hope you will kindly see that authorization be given for this.

Please take our urgent needs into consideration and have the necessary expenditure authorized as soon as possible.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain Sir,

Yours very truly,

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education

J.E. Beallergon (...)
Principal.
R.C. Indian Residential School
KINORA, Ont.

June 14th., 1930.

Dear Sir,-

At the end of October 1929, I have received from the Department, authorization to paint on a day labor basis, the new addition and outbuildings at our school, at an estimated cost of $375.00. Very little painting was done last autumn because my painter left me after a few days of work. I presume that it is right for me to have the work done now. But, since the work was not performed during the winter, I am doubtful and I would be obliged to you for telling me if it would be in order.

Thanking you in advance, I remain Sir,

Yours very truly,

J.E. Brierley, D.M.
(J.-E. Brierley, D.M.)
Principal.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, with reference to improvements at the Kenora Indian Residential School. On the 4th instant, the Department wrote Mr. Indian Agent Edwards, authorizing a screen door and sufficient wire screening and other materials for 7 windows. It was understood that the school authorities would make up the window screens, without labour costs to the Department.

I regret there are no funds for the purchase of milch cows. It is the practice, at Indian residential schools, for the management to make replacements to live stock when necessary. Generally, the natural increase alone keeps the herd up to the required number.

Dear Sir:-

Re Septic Tanks at Catholic Indian School Kenora.

The above septic tank is in poor condition. It has for a load the wastes from all the toilets, baths, etc., as well as the discharge from all laundry and kitchen fixtures. It is at all times overloaded with grease, which appears to be carried to the disposal bed with the very large amount of flush water. This tank is kept working at this time by using large amounts of desolvent chemical. The staff at the school have for the last few years to clean out the different compartments every few months.

The syphon equipment is not in working order, and there is no way provided for emptying this part of the system to make inspection or make repairs.

The filter beds and distributing nozzles need attention and the outlet from field tile and underdrainage is at present emptying on open ground about ten feet from the shore line where it runs in a rotten stream above grade into the lake. The point where this sewerage enters the lake is not more than ten feet from where the drinking water line is taken to the pumps, although this water intake is said to extend some distance out in the lake. I would say that provision should be made to have it carefully examined as soon as the weather permits as this pipe has been in use for a long time and is likely rotted out.
Accordingly, I would recommend that a pipe line be laid to outlet the waste from the laundry and kitchen into the lake, but that a grease trap be constructed to remove greases and fats. Having these removed it might be possible to convince the Health Authorities that little or no bacteria is being passed into the lake and we remove the unsightly skim of grease and fat which frequently浮 on the surface of the water in the vicinity of the pipe outlet. No other solution of the problem of disposing of this laundry and kitchen waste presents itself owing to the rocky formation and lack of suitable soil to make a large laundry sump. I would recommend that the present septic tank and filter chamber be removed to make way for a new septic tank and siphon chamber similar in size and design to those erected at the Caribou Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora. The siphon chamber would overlap the sub-irrigation disposal bed. The space available for this bed is very limited and the nature of the ground is such that excavation will be necessary to provide for the laying of a gravel bed about fifteen inches deep, but depending upon the nature of the soil. The four inch tile would be laid upon this gravel bed and the whole covered with an 18 inch layer of sand and clay mixture.

It is difficult to make an estimate of the probable cost of this work owing to the uncertainty of the size of the disposal bed obtainable. The preparation of this bed would be costly. However, in my opinion the probable cost of the work recommended would be as follows:

1 - Laying of new pipe line for disposal of laundry and kitchen waste with grease trap.......................... $ 400.00

2 - Removal of present septic tank, filter chamber & disposal bed........... 200.00

3 - Construction of new septic tank complete.................................. 1,000.00

4 - Laying of sub-irrigation disposal bed... 1,600.00

Total estimated cost............... $ 5,200.00

As previously mentioned this school was apparently located without regard to the present requirements of a sewerage disposal system that will permit of no contamination of the water supply from the Lake of the Woods, so the conditions are unfavorable and to overcome these conditions and install an satisfactory disposal system will be expensive. The work should be done in July or at such time as the school is closed for the summer.

Engineer in Charge,

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
June 14th, 1930.
In operation, not only the sewerage but all waste from the laundry and kitchen is passed into the septic tank. Without any screen in front of the outlet to the tank, old clothes, boots, etc., pass into the tank, block the overflow pipe and syphon and have at times caused overflowing of the tank through the syphon chamber manhole. The passing of the laundry and kitchen waste through the septic tank and filter chamber results in the soaps and greases rapidly plugging the filter beds, rendering that part of the system useless so that the filter chamber has merely become a cesspool. If there is any disposal bed it is probably useless owing to the nature of the soil in which the tiles were laid. The septic tank is not sufficiently large to take care of the waste from the toilets and baths alone, not to mention the additional burden of the laundry and kitchen wastes and in any case the laundry and kitchen wastes should not be passed through the septic tank and disposal beds.

The chief complaint the Principal of the school had to make of the present installation was that they had to clean out the tank two or three times a year, that it occasionally overflowed and that there was a disagreeable odor from the outlet. However the situation is probably more serious than that. The new water intake main about to be installed extends out about 1,000 feet to what is supposed to be a channel of slow moving current towards one of the lake outlets. The intake of the Kenora Water Supply is downstream some distance from this point and the Ontario Department of Health are now taking measures to compel summer campers on the lake to cease polluting the waters by passing untreated sewerage etc. into the lake. Dr. Ferguson, Medical Health Officer for Kenora, and also for the Department of Indian Affairs, when interviewed by the writer stated he could not agree with my suggestion that we pass the laundry and kitchen wastes from the Indian school directly untreated into the lake and doubtless he would strongly object to the passing of dangerous bacteria into the lake as is now being done through the present system.

It was my intention to recommend the placing of a new pipe line from the school direct to the lake to carry the laundry and kitchen wastes and to clean out and put into condition the existing septic tank and filter chamber and eliminate the disposal bed for the disposal of the sewage from the toilets and baths. With the existing system this would probably not eliminate the passing of some colén bacilli germs into the lake, but the contamination would be slight and would not affect the water supply for the school and the town of Kenora's water supply is chlorinated anyway. In view of the probable attitude of the Health Authorities I do not believe this recommendation could be carried out.
REPORT ON SEWERAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM

ROMAN CATHOLIC INDIAN SCHOOL,
KENORA.

On May 30th the undersigned visited the Kenora Roman Catholic Indian School and insofar as conditions permitted made an examination of the sewage disposal system. The plans of the school were not there when the system was installed but he kindly loaned me a set of plans of the sewage disposal system but could not say whether the system was actually installed in accordance with the plans. I also saw Captain Edwards, Indian Agent at Kenora, and secured from him a copy of a report made November, 1929, by Mr. Chas. Matchford, a plumber at Kenora, on the condition of the sewage disposal system. A copy of this report is attached.

Evidently this school was located without thought of the installation of a system for rendering the sewerage harmless. The school is located in close proximity to the Lake of the Woods in such a way that the natural drainage into the lake. Solid rock is exposed in many places and the soil covering is generally shallow. The present location of the septic tank, filter and disposal bed is the only place where conditions permit unless expensive rock excavation was resorted to. The available area for the sewage disposal system is too limited for satisfactory results.

According to the plans the septic tank is constructed of concrete, with inside dimensions of five feet by ten feet and eight feet deep, divided into two chambers, each accessible by a manhole. The siphon discharges through piping to a filter about 20 feet distant. This filter chamber is nine feet by fifteen feet and six inches inside dimensions, built of concrete and provided with a manhole. This filter outlets to a disposal bed 20 feet by 50 feet extending to the lake. The septic tank and filter were filled with sewerage and no examination was possible. There was some flowage into the lake from the disposal bed area, this flowage having a very obnoxious odor and doubtless containing dangerous material. I am unable to learn whether there actually is or is not any disposal bed installed, but I doubt whether there is such a bed.

J. T. Johnston, Esq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power & Reclamation Service,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ontario.
In further reference to your letter of May 15th regarding the condition of the sewage disposal system at the Kenora Roman Catholic Indian school, I enclose herewith a report received from Mr. D.B. Gow, our Acting District Chief Engineer at Winnipeg, dated the 14th instant. This report is based upon information obtained during a visit to the school on May 30th and Mr. Gow states that before deciding upon a definite scheme for improving conditions at the school it will be advisable to have borings to ascertain depths to rock and space available for disposal beds, etcetera; also a definite understanding is required with the Ontario Board of Health so that the proposed works will meet their requirements with respect to Lake of the Woods water supply.

The estimates of cost given in this report are accordingly provisional and subject to revision if borings are taken and conditions not confirmed as assumed in making the report.

If the Department of Indian Affairs desire to have this work undertaken during this summer along the lines recommended in the report, we will arrange for one of our engineers to make a thorough study of soil conditions, and also take up the matter with the representative of the Ontario Board of Health at Kenora to learn what is necessary to satisfy their requirements.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

DOMINION WATER POWER AND HYDROMETRIC BUREAU

Winnipeg, Man.,
July 7, 1930.

Sir,

Re R.C. Indian School, Kenora.

I have received your letter of June 26th with reference to the above mentioned subject. I note that the Department of Indian Affairs state there are no funds available now to carry out the work as recommended in my report dated June 14th, but that $3,500.00 is being placed in the estimates for next year and that in the meantime a report is asked for as to what is considered absolutely necessary to be done now in order that the system will function until next year.

As pointed out in my report of June 14th, the Principal of the School complained principally that it was necessary to frequently clean out the septic tank and that there was a very disagreeable odor from the outlet. However, the main faults of the present system were fully covered in that report. The system is not properly designed, is inadequate, and a sludge on the surface of the lake in the woods is resulting. No temporary measure will relieve these conditions and it is therefore recommended that no work be done this year. Conditions for the coming year will be no more serious than for the past two or three years and the system will function unsatisfactorily of course.

When in Kenora recently, I explained to the School Authorities and to Captain Edwards, Indian Agent, the Department's position as regards lack of funds, their decision to make provision for doing the work next year, and explained that under these conditions I considered it inadvisable to make any alterations in the existing system this year, and was so reporting. They expressed approval of this attitude.

At some convenient time this summer I plan to have one of our engineers carry out a detailed survey of the school grounds, so that a more accurate estimate of what is required may be made. The site is rocky and it is planned to draw up plans and estimates of costs covering the work outlined in my previous report.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) D. B. Cow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

J. T. Johnston, Asq.,
Director, Dominion Water Power
and Hydrometric Bureau,
Department of the Interior,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Campbell of the Campbell Heating Company came to see me on Friday the 12th instant and informed me that the pump installed at the Kenora (R.C.) School would not supply water to the school owing to the extremely low level of the lake. I asked what he would suggest and he informed me he had a representative from the Fairbanks-Morse Company, who supplied the motor, and had also had Bro. Eugene Gauthier down, and it was not the fault of the pump, but was on account of the high lift. He suggested a new pump house be built near the lake, and the pump placed there so that the water could be pushed up instead of drawn up. In that case the pump would have ample capacity.

I do not like authorizing any further expenditure and got in touch with Mr. Gow of the Dominion Water Power Branch Winnipeg. He came down on Saturday morning and went to the school with Mr. Campbell and myself. He returned to Winnipeg and will make a report, and I trust you will receive this shortly, as the weather is commencing to get cold and something must be done before the ice forms. The old pump is at present operating, but is liable to stop at any time.

It was also suggested that some material, either straw or gravel would do, be placed over the intake to prevent it freezing. As soon as you receive this report I shall be glad if you will send me instructions as it is important that this be done without delay otherwise the school will probably be without water during the winter, in which case it would have to be closed down.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian agent

Water losses this year than for many years will be lower still during winter months.

Form No. 101
access to the check valve. I would set the motor and pump as low as possible but resting on a concrete platform, say 4" or 6" above the concrete floor.

The 4" pipe line should have been laid at least 3' below the lowest anticipated water level of the lake. It has been laid only about 1' below the water level prevailing in April and May, and at the present time, for a considerable distance from the shore. The fact that the old pipe line never froze, is no reason to assume that the new one won't, especially since the old pipe is set nearly 3' lower and appears to be ensconced within an outer pipe. The only safe measure for ensuring that this new pipe line will not freeze, is to lower it so that there is five feet of solid earth covering out to the point where the water is now 4' deep. I would not care to recommend any other course. It might be possible to so cover up the pipe line as it now rests, in shallow water, so as to prevent freezing, but I have no suggestions to make along these lines. You know what the consequences would be should this pipe line freeze up, so no expense should be considered too great to ensure interrupted water service.

I expect that Mr. J. T. Rose of this staff will be proceeding to Menora this week to carry out some investigations in connection with the proposed new sewerage disposal system for the R.C. School, and I have instructed him to accurately measure the suction lift, as the pump is now located, also in the recommended new location, also to determine the profile of the pipe line as laid. Mr. Rose's services will be available to you for any further investigations you wish made and for consultation.

Yours truly,

D. B. Gray,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
September 16, 1930.

Captain Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Captain:

Following our examination of the new pump and pipe line installed at the R.C. Indian School at Kenora, I have studied the Campbell Heating Company's proposals, made in writing to you under date of April 20, 1930. This firm reported that the lake level was about 22 feet below the pump, and recommended their "First Proposal" as "the proper and thorough way to install this job", and "For the reason that this pump motor and suction line are of the proper capacity to do this job thoroughly". Acting upon their report and recommendations, I understand you advised that the work be proceeded with. Later, this Company demanded and secured, an additional $600.00, above their original offer for doing the work. The Campbell now states that the lake level is 8' below the pump. I would here like to point out that on September 13th, the lake level was 1055.90, and on no day during the month of April, 1930, did the lake level reach this elevation; it was always lower. Had the suction lift been only 22 feet and had the 4" pipe line been properly laid below the frost line, and otherwise properly laid, in all probability the system would have worked, but however, with little margin or safety. I am now assuming that the suction lift has been found to be nearly 25 feet. The Campbell Heating Company, acting in the capacity of Advisory Engineers, as well as Contractors, have therefore, the responsibility of seeing that the system is made to work in a "thorough way".

Assuming the suction lift to be 25 feet, I am of the opinion that taking into consideration friction losses in the pipe line, and the possibility of still lower water in the lake, that the new pump, as installed, cannot be made to serve satisfactorily, and that no time should be wasted in attempting to make it do so. The pump and motor are efficient, but not dependable against a suction lift in excess of 25 feet, when there are several friction losses. The remedy is obvious, and to increase the suction lift by lowering the pump, being as it is necessary to move the pump, it would be advisable to lower it sufficiently to ensure efficient operation. I would suggest that a new pump house be erected immediately over the check valve now installed below the old pump house. This pump house should be 8' x 10', with an 8" wall, with an 8" concrete floor slab resting on gravel with wooden trap door giving
The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

On Friday the 12th instant, Mr. Campbell informed me the new pump installed at the Kenora (R.C.) School would not work. I got Mr. Gow, Acting District Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch to come to Kenora and go to the school with me. I enclose a letter received from him today.

His suggestion is that we build a new pump house at a cost roughly of $250.00 and also that the only safe measure for ensuring that the new pump line will not freeze is to lower it so that there is at least five feet of solid earth covering out to the point where the water is four feet deep. He says it might be possible to cover up the pipe line in shallow water so as to prevent freezing, but he has no suggestions to make along these lines, and no expense should be too great to ensure uninterrupted water service.

I have seen Mr. Campbell today and he informs me that the old pipe is only cased from the pump house to the check valve, and not in the lake. The new pipe when it strikes the water and from there on, is lower than the old one. He believes that if we were to cover the pipes which lay alongside each other until they strike deep water there will be no chance of them freezing. I would recommend the pump house be built and the pipe either covered or lowered and I should like to get instructions along these lines and in view of Mr. Gow's letter, should like to know who is to pay for the pump house and the work on the pump line. The water is lower in the lake than it has been for many years and the old pump is liable to give out at any time. I shall be glad, therefore, to receive instructions as soon as possible as cold weather will soon be setting in.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Enc.1
Kenora, Ontario,

Assistant Deputy Inspector,

Dear Sir:

Reference my letter of the 18th., which was held back until today, awaiting estimate from Kelly and Kimberly.

This firm now write me it would cost $249.00 to erect a pump house, and $650.00 to extend present crib over pipe line twenty five feet, filling same and existing sixty feet of old crib to depth of six feet over pipe line.

This is a large expenditure, but I think it should be done if possible, as I am afraid of everything freezing up this winter, owing to the excessively low level of the lake.

Your obedient servant

R.C. Indian Residential School

KORA, Ont., Sept. 30, 1930.

Sir,

I inform the Department that our heating system is far from giving satisfaction; some parts of the school are overheated, while in others the radiators give no heat whatever; in fact, although a sufficient fire is made for the season of the year we are suffering from the cold.

Until this is done I respectfully ask that seven Electric Heaters be granted us for our private rooms; they are really needed, and will likely be every winter, spring and autumn. The cost of each radiator would be approximately $14.00.

May I note that one room has not even one radiator; the Sister who lived in it last winter had no heat at all. There is surely no other school where such a thing can be found.

Thanking you in advance, Sir, I am

Yours respectfully,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

[Signature]

Lee Edwards Little
Kenora, Ontario
October 3rd, 1930.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find voucher #5306 for $159.09, expended on the new addition to the Kenora Indian Residential School.

The Principal informs me that this was authorised in connection with the new addition, but I cannot find the Department's authority on my files.

The amount of $30.60 for doors to fire escapes was authorised by me, as it was absolutely essential to enable the children to get out in case of fire.

I enclose letter received from the Principal, in which he asks an appropriation of $1300.00 to repair the road to the school. This road is in bad shape, and the school authorities apparently do very little work on it. We could probably obtain cinders from the C.P.R., and if the school authorities or the Department would pay for the labour of hauling, a passable road could be made at much less cost than estimated by the Principal.

I also enclose letter re the heating system. This was put in good shape a short time ago by Heale and Yeats of Brandon, and the heating of the new addition was done by the Campbell Heating Co., of Kenora. Mr. Campbell informs me that he thinks the reason is, the school authorities put a fire on, then do not keep it up, hence the trouble; so I am writing the Principal requesting him to have Brother Gautier make a report, as any previous reports we have received from him, always seem reasonable and honest.

Your obedient servant

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Dear Sirs:

Re Kenora R.O. Indian Residential School

FIRST PROPOSAL -

Install a 2500 Gallon per hour Fairbanks-Morse Pump connected on the same base with a Three Horse Power Motor, the pump to be chain driven - Install 1000 feet of 4" suction line into the Lake; friction loss at this suction line would be 2.20 feet per hundred - On this suction line it would be necessary to place a 4" foot valve and also on the pump installation a relief valve along with the check valves and globe valves required - The electric work to be done in the approved manner with entrance switch, pressure switch and starting switch.

This proposal is the proper and thorough way to install this job -

The cost of carrying out the work according to this proposal would be Two Thousand and Seventy-Three ($2073.90) Dollars.

Dear Sir,

The work required to be done at present in connection with the Indian Residential School R.C. Kenora sewage system is as follows:

Clean out both chambers of main septic tank, clear pipe line between main septic tank and filter tank, and repair broken tile, remove rock and gravel from filter tank. Clean out Filter Tank and all connections. Put back filter rock and cover with new gravel. Take up end of discharge from filter tank and continue line to present low water level more line. Cover this line which will be 20 or 30 feet with gravel, earth, manure or other filling.

The above work including excavation work should cost between $250.00 and $300.00.
