Dear Sir,

On my return from a trip north yesterday, I was informed that the Septic Tank at the Kenora Residential School had broken down, and was not functioning. The Principal has immediately instructed Mr. G. Ratclifford of honour to investigate and do what he could to remedy same. I went to the School this morning with Mr. Ratclifford and it appeared that the main Septic Tank and Filter Tank are apparently blocked as is also the overflow pipe to the lake, and the tile pipes are broken.

I spoke to Mr. Rose, of the Dominion Water Power and Irrigation Bureau, who I met on long distance telephone and Mr. Ratclifford explained the situation to him. Mr. Rose assured me to carry out all suggestions of Mr. Ratclifford, and as this is the best that can be done as a temporary measure, I have accordingly instructed him to carry out the work as recommended in his letter, enclosed herewith, as otherwise, if nothing is done, the School would have to be closed.

I understand there is an appropriation of about $3500.00 recommended for a new Sewage disposal next Spring at this School.

I know I have received instructions to give this kind of work to Kelly & Kinneir, Mr. Smith, or Mr. Brown, but as the Principal

REPORT ON
PROPOSED SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM
ROMAN CATHOLIC INDIAN SCHOOL
KENORA, ONTARIO

by

D. B. GOW.

Winnipeg, Manitoba
January 3rd, 1951
REPORT ON
PROPOSED SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM
FROM
ROMAN CATHOLIC INDIAN SCHOOL
KENORA - ONTARIO.

Winnipeg, Manitoba,
January 3rd, 1931.

D. B. Gow.
TABLE OF CONTENTS.

Introductory........................................... 1
Sewage Disposal........................................ 1
Scheme No. 1............................................ 3
Scheme No. 2............................................ 4
Conclusions and Recommendations...................... 5
Estimates............................................... 7

LIST OF PLATES.

Water Supply and Sewage Disposal as Existing..., No. 1.
Sewage Disposal System, Scheme No. 1,
as proposed............................................. No. 2.
Sewage Disposal System, Scheme No. 2,
as proposed............................................. No. 3.
Sewage Disposal and Laundry Drain,
Profiles of Scheme No. 2............................. No. 4.
Septic Tank - Scheme No. 2........................... No. 5.
The Roman Catholic Indian School is located close to the shore of a small bay of Lake of the Woods, about three miles from Kenora. It is accessible with difficulty by automobile and readily accessible by boat during the open water period. This report deals with the present condition of the existing sewage disposal system and outlines alternative systems that might be installed to provide an adequate sewage disposal system. Plans and profiles of the proposed works, together with estimates of the cost, are included in the report. The elevations given on the plans and profiles are to Geodetic Survey of Canada datum and the surveys were made by an engineer of this staff.

The school was erected by the Church and was located without regard to the difficulty of installing an adequate disposal system as later became necessary, due to the enlargement of the school and the necessity of preventing pollution of the water of the lake. Originally all sewage was piped directly into the lake, but later a disposal system was installed. This system consists of a septic tank with inside dimensions of 5' x 10' and 8' deep, divided into two chambers, each accessible by a manhole. The tank is constructed of concrete. The septic tank is connected by a pipe to a filter chamber with inside dimensions of 9' x 15' and 8' high, constructed of concrete and provided with a manhole. The filter
outlets to a disposal bed 20' x 50', the particulars of which are unknown. All sanitary, laundry and kitchen sewers in the building are connected to the system. It is quite apparent that the system is not functioning properly, the siphon frequently becomes blocked; the filter bed requires replacing and the disposal bed is apparently completely out of order. The effluent can be seen running out into the lake and gives off a very obnoxious odor.

PROPOSED SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS.

General.

The school is located about one half a mile above the intake of the Kenora Water Supply System. This system is located above the town of Kenora, so that none of the town sewers discharge above the intake. However, along the shores of the mainland and on many of the islands there are located many summer homes that are also polluting the water of the lake. Kenora's water supply is being sterilized to such a degree as to render it very disagreeable to drink and still the Ontario Department of Health is not satisfied as to its safety. Steps are now being taken to prevent the pollution of the water of the lake and this Indian School is considered to be a very great offender in this respect. Any proposed alteration to the sewage system at the school will evidently have to meet with the approval of the Ontario Board of Health. Accordingly, in this report two alternative schemes for a sewage disposal system are outlined, varying considerably in cost. It is hoped that if the cheaper scheme will not meet with the approval of the Health Authorities that the more expensive scheme might. It is
Realized, however, that neither scheme will prevent some pollution of the water of the lake.

A - Scheme No. 1.

This scheme provides for making use of the existing septic tank and the filter chamber and the entire reconstruction of the disposal bed. Also, it is intended to pass all sanitary drainage from the school through the disposal system as is done at the present time.

(a) Septic Tank.

It is proposed to partially remove the existing partition, thus converting the structure into one compartment to be utilized as a settling chamber. Some minor changes will be required in the outlet pipes of the tank. A new 4" vitrified pipe line will be necessary to connect this tank to the filter tank.

(b) Filter Tank.

This tank will be cleaned out, leaving only the walls. A siphon chamber will be built in, thereby converting the structure into a septic tank. An Anthee siphon will be installed. The siphon will discharge into the feeder line of the disposal bed.

(c) Disposal Bed.

The old disposal bed will be entirely removed and a new bed built up in accordance with the design for Disposal Bed No. 2, as shown on accompanying plans. This disposal bed, 36' x 120', will provide in excess of 1,000 lineal feet of tile drainage, or about 15 lineal feet per capita. The disposal bed, being built up of gravel and sand, should be very efficient. The disposal bed is entirely above the high water level of the lake, yet in close proximity to the shore.
Scheme No. 2.

This proposed scheme provides for a more complete disposal system and more in conformity with modern installations. It involves the complete scrapping of the existing disposal system and for separate disposal of the laundry and kitchen waste. No use will be made of the old septic tank; the filter tank will be partially demolished to make way for the disposal bed, and the old disposal bed will be entirely removed.

(a) Septic Tank.

A new reinforced concrete septic tank will be constructed as shown on the accompanying plans. This tank will be similar in type to the septic tank built at the Cecilia Jeffrey Indian School, Kenora. Each siphon will discharge into separate disposal beds.

(b) Disposal Beds.

Two disposal beds are provided, each 36' x 120', adjoining each other but constructed on different levels to conform to the steep slope of the ground. No. 1 bed is built up of the natural earth excavated from Bed No. 2, while No. 2 bed is to be built up of gravel and sand. The beds will be terraced and made attractive. The accompanying plans give details of both beds.

(c) Laundry Drain.

Disposal of the laundry and kitchen drainage presents a difficult problem, as all natural drainage leads directly to the lake fronting the school grounds. It is very undesirable to have a greasy film covering the water surface in any conspicuous area. Accordingly, it is
proposed to lay a drain from the laundry end of the school to a small sheltered bay of the lake, well away from the school grounds. The location of this drain is shown in red on one of the accompanying plans. As the depth of soil overlying the rock is shallow and in the vicinity of the shore there is no covering, it becomes necessary to build up a covering for the drain throughout almost its entire length and to protect the outlet with crib-work and filling. The drain will be 6" vitrified piping and that portion projecting into the lake will be cast iron pipe. Alterations in the plumbing system in the school will also be necessary to convey the laundry drainage to the proposed drain.

Conclusions and Recommendations.

The sewage disposal system designated as Scheme No. 1 has the disadvantage in that the laundry drainage is not separated from the other sewage and results in overloading the whole system on certain days so that bacteria is very likely to be passed through the disposal beds into the lake. The great advantage of the scheme as compared with that designated as Scheme No. 2 is the difference in cost. Scheme No. 2 offers the objectionable feature that the laundry and kitchen waste is drained directly into the lake, a feature probably objectionable to the Ontario Department of Health. It does, however, provide a very efficient method of treating the sewage from the school and preventing dangerous bacteria from reaching the lake.

Taking into consideration the fact that this Indian School is an old structure and has almost
reached the end of efficient usefulness, the writer cannot recommend that any such elaborate or expensive drainage disposal system as Scheme No. 2 should be proceeded with... Should, however, the Department of Indian Affairs contemplate utilizing the present school for an additional term of ten years, then the writer would urge that consideration be given to the construction of a new disposal system in the summer of 1931 along the lines outlined in Scheme No. 1.

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

Sir,

Re Indian School at Kenora.

In further reference to your letter of July 18th last regarding the sewage disposal system at the Roman Catholic school at Kenora, I enclose herewith a report prepared by Mr. Gow dealing with this subject.

Two schemes are suggested for consideration, one making use of the existing septic tank and filter chamber and providing for the reconstruction of the disposal bed, at an estimated cost of $1600; the other providing for complete reconstruction of the septic tank and disposal beds and separate provision for laundry waste, at an estimated cost of $4000.

I understand that Mr. Gow has discussed this matter with the Departmental Architect and that they have reached an agreement as to the most satisfactory method of dealing with this matter under existing conditions.

Your obedient servant,

February 16th, 1931.

T. J. Hooper, Esq.
Secy.,
Board of Health,
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of 11th inst., re report to your Board on the 2nd, that the Septic Tank at the Kenora R.C. School wasn't functioning properly, and the resolution passed thereon.

We beg to advise you that an amount has been put in the Estimates for the remodelling and rebuilding the Sewage disposal plant at the School.

Owing to the low water in the lake, the outlet pipe from the present disposal plant froze up, and caused a stoppage a short time ago.

On the recommendation of the Acting Chief Engineer, of the Dominion Water Power Branch and Reclamation Bureau, the Department decided to make temporary repairs, until we had the money voted for the remodelling, and this was done as follows:- The Tank has been cleaned out, and the contents disposed of, Broken Pipes have been removed and replaced by new ones, Drains have been cleaned and the Syphon put in order, the Outlet to the Lake has been taken up and rearranged so that it will discharge into a Gravel Bed before entering the Lake, and so far as we have been able to learn, there is no trouble with the system at present.

In company with Dr. A.D. Ferguson, Medical Officer of Health, and Mr. Chas. Ratchford, who made the temporary repairs, I inspected the work, and we were unable to find any spot where unfiltered sewage entered the Lake.

Provincial Sanitary Inspector,
Box 161, Sioux Lookout,
Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of 11th inst. re Indian Residential Schools, in this Agency:

Kenora R.C. School:- We had trouble with the sewage disposal plant here, in January, owing to the low water in the lake, and on the recommendation of the Acting Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power and Reclamation Bureau, the Department decided to make temporary repairs, until we had the money voted for the remodelling, and this was done, as follows:- Tank cleaned out, and contents disposed of, broken pipes removed, and replaced by new ones, Drains cleaned out, and Syphon put in order. Outlet to the lake, taken up and rearranged so it will discharge into a gravel bed, before entering the lake.

In company with Dr. A.D. Ferguson, Medical Officer of Health, and Mr. Chas. Ratchford, who made the repairs, I inspected the work, and we were unable to find any spot, where unfiltered sewage entered the lake, and that the system at present is much better, than it has been in years.

Sioux Lookout School:- We were not aware of the fact that prior to the low water, the end of the original effluent is now exposed some 15 feet above the normal water line. As this outlet is below the Rapids, there is no danger, now or at any other time of pollution at the intake of the water supply, or for the water supply for the town of Sioux Lookout or the National Railways.

[Signature]
Kenora, Ontario.
March 16th, 1931.

Frank Edwards

Form No. 101
Department of the Interior, Canada,
Union Water Power and Hydrometric Bureau,
Winnipeg, Sept.16th. 1930

Captain Edwards,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.

Dear Captain,

Following our examination of the new pump and pipe line installed at the R.C. Indian School at Kenora, I have studied the Campbell Heating Company's proposals made in writing to you under date April 30th, 1930. This firm reported that the lake level was about 22 feet below the pump, and recommended their "first proposal" as "The proper and thorough way to install this job", and "For the reason that this pump motor and suction line are of the proper capacity to do this job thoroughly." Acting upon their report and recommendations I understand you advised that the work be proceeded with. Later, this Company demanded and secured an additional $600 above their original offer for doing the work. Mr. Campbell now states that the lake level is 24'8" below the pump. I would here like to point out that on September 13th, the lake level was 1055.90 and on no day during the month of April 1930 did the lake level reach this elevation; it was always lower. Had the suction lift been only 22 feet and had the 4" pipe line been properly laid below the frost line, and otherwise properly laid, in all probability the system would have worked, but however, with little margin of safety. I am now assuming that the suction lift has been found to be nearly 25 feet. The Campbell Heating Company, acting in the capacity of Advisory Engineers, as well as contractors, have therefore, the responsibility of seeing that the system is made to work in a "thorough way."

Assuming the suction lift to be 25 feet, I am of the opinion that taking into consideration friction losses in the pipe line, and the possibility of still lower water in the lake, that the new pump, as installed, cannot be made to serve satisfactorily, and that no time should be wasted in attempting to make it do so. The Pump and motor are efficient, but not dependable against a suction lift in excess of 22 feet, when there are several friction losses. The remedy, therefore, is to decrease the suction lift by lowering the pump. Being as it is necessary to move the pump, it would be advisable to lower it sufficiently to ensure efficient operation. I would suggest that a new pump house be erected immediately over the check valve now installed below the old pump house. This pump house should be 8' x 10' with an 8" wall with an 8" concrete floor slab resting on gravel with wooden trap door giving access to the check valve. I would set the motor and pump as low as possible but resting on a concrete platform, say 4" or 6" above the concrete floor.
the 4" pipe line should have been laid at least 3' below the lowest anticipated water level of the lake. It has been laid only about 1' below the water level prevailing in April and May, and at the present time, for a considerable distance from the shore. The fact that the old pipe line never froze, is no reason to assure that the new one won't, especially since the old pipe is set nearly 9" lower and appears to be encased within an outer pipe. The only safe measure for ensuring that this new pipe line will not freeze, is to lower it so that there is five feet of solid earth covering out to the point where the water is now 4' deep. I would not care to recommend any other course. It might be possible to so cover up the pipe line as it now rests, in shallow water, so as to prevent freezing, but I have no suggestions to make along these lines. You know what the consequences would be should this pipe line freeze up, so no expense should be considered too great to ensure interrupted water service.

I expect that Mr. J.T. Rose of this staff will be proceeding to Kenora this week to carry out some investigations in connection with the proposed new sewerage disposal system for the R.C. School, and I have instructed him to accurately measure the suction lift, as the pump is now located, also in the recommended new location, also to determine the profile of the pipe line as laid. Mr. Rose's services will be available to you for any further investigations you wish made and for consultation.

Yours truly,

(signed) D.B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.
Kenora, Ontario

September 18th, 1930

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

On Friday the 12th instant, Mr. Campbell informed me the new pump installed at the Kenora (R.C.) School would not work. I got Mr. Gow, Acting District Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch to come to Kenora and go to the school with me. I enclose a letter received from him today.

His suggestion is that we build a new pump house at a cost roughly of $250.00 and also that the only safe measure for ensuring that the new pump line will not freeze is to lower it so that there is at least five feet of solid earth covering out to the point where the water is four feet deep. He says it might be possible to so cover up the pipe line in shallow water so as to prevent freezing, but he has no suggestions to make along these lines, and no expense should be too great to ensure uninterrupted water service.

I have seen Mr. Campbell today and he informs me that the old pipe is only cased from the pump house to the check valve, and not in the lake. The new pipe when it strikes the water and from there on, is lower than the old one. He believes that if we were to cover the pipes which lay alongside each other until they strike deep water there will be no chance of them freezing. I would recommend the pump house be built and the pipe either covered or lowered and I should like to get instructions along these lines and in view of Mr. Gow's letter, should like to know who is to pay for the pump house and the work on the pump line. The water is lower in the lake than it has been for many years and the old pump is liable to give out at any time. I shall be glad, therefore, to receive instructions as soon as possible as cold weather will soon be setting in.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.
Kenora, Ontario.

Dear Sirs,

We have received a telegram from the Department authorizing the new Pump House at the Indian Residential School R.C. Kenora, at a cost of $249.00 and extending the present crib over the pipe line a further 25 feet, filling same and the existing 60 feet of old crib to a depth of 6 feet over pipe line at a price of $650.00.

It is presumed the extension will be filled to a width of 5 feet from the centre of the pipe, and we expect you will sheet the crib so that the material will not wash away.

This will be your authority to start this work at once, the Campbell Heating Co., to move the Pump and install it in the new Pump House so that it will function properly.

Please see that everything is done in a correct way so that we will have no trouble in the future with this work.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Edwards:

Thank you for your letter of the 22nd inst. We have, indeed, found from our records, that washer 1215 M 7119 was shipped, together with other equipment, to the above School, on the 13th of March 1922. It is a 36"x72" Washer supplied on our Requisition No. R.7748.

From what you say in your letter, it is evident that a new tub is needed for this washer. The cost of same would be $110.00 f.o.b. our factory, Toronto, Sales Tax not included. Price is for woodwork only and does not include bumper strip, tub door, hoops nor drain tee, you using the old fittings and attaching them to the new tub when making the change.

Our nearest Representatives are Stanley Brock Limited, of 145 East Market St., Winnipeg, Manitoba, who have a direct Representative calling in your vicinity periodically. We have taken the liberty of forwarding a copy of this letter to them, for their information, and any further information you desire to obtain on our products may be had either from Messrs. S. Brock Limited or from ourselves.

In the meantime, and agreeable to your request, we are enclosing in Duplex envelope, a catalogue of our equipment, and we trust this proves entirely satisfactory.

In closing, may we state that such a tub as described above could be built by us within ten days from date of receipt of your order by this office, and such an order would receive our prompt and careful attention.

Very truly yours,

The Canadian Laundry Machinery Co., Limited.

May 9, 1931.

Dear Mr. Orr:

This will acknowledge the receipt of your communication of May 6th with reference to the unsatisfactory conditions at the R. C. Indian School and the Cecilia Jeffrey School at Kenora, Ontario.

I am indeed surprised to hear of the unsatisfactory condition of the laundry sump at the Cecilia Jeffrey School as upon the occasion of my last visit to Kenora, some two months ago, Captain Edwards informed me that owing to his recommendation efforts have been made to deepen the laundry sump in order to reach a gravel bed and that these efforts have been successful and that the sump was operating satisfactorily. I will write Captain Edwards and ascertain from him further particulars as to the condition of the laundry sump.

There is no doubt that Captain Edwards will be more or less worried by the efforts of the Sanitary Inspector at Kenora to have the proposed new work at the R. C. Indian School carried out as the town authorities are making a drive to stop the pollution of the lake of the Woods water by summer campers and permanent inhabitants bordering the waters of the lake. However, the conditions at the school are not any more serious, in my opinion, than they have been for some years past so far as pollution of the lake water is concerned. Eventually if this R. C. Indian School is to be carried on in its present location the sewage disposal system will have to be remodelled and in view of the possibility of the Ontario Department of Health taking drastic action, such as closing down the institution, I would strongly advise that you submit the proposals forwarded from this office to you in January covering the proposed sewage disposal system at the school to the Department of Health at Ottawa for their approval of the same. Rather than have the institution closed down I believe it will be necessary for you to proceed with the remodelling of the sewage disposal system during the present summer when the school is closed down for the holidays.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,
Acting District Chief Engineer.

R. G. Orr, Esq.,
Chief Architect,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

The Indians' identity, culture, and way of life are threatened by the proposed plans (21 routes in all) which would destroy a great deal of their land and resources.

In order to protect these lands, the government has proposed a plan which would require a reducing valve on each pipeline to control the flow of oil and gas from the source. This plan also calls for additional storage tanks and pipelines, an essential part of any oil and gas development project.

One major concern will be the impact on the environment. The oil and gas industry is committed to minimizing its environmental footprint, but the potential for damage cannot be ignored. The government's responsibility is to ensure that the industry operates within acceptable limits and that the environment is protected.

The government has already implemented several measures to address these concerns, including the establishment of strict regulations and the implementation of advanced technology to reduce emissions and minimize waste.

In conclusion, while the proposed plans may have significant benefits, they also pose serious threats to the environment and the way of life of the Indians. It is crucial that we find a balance between economic development and environmental protection, ensuring that both the Indians and the environment are protected for future generations.

aggravating the condition. Last spring Mr. Ralphsfield, a local plumber made some temporary repairs which consisted chiefly in placing an obstacle between the breaks and the shore line. This obstacle was in the shape of a dam & consisted of rocks, clay, gravel, and sand and it was expected to act as a filter for the sewage before entering the lake. Formerly there was bound to be currents through this dam and raw sewage went its way into the lake.

The Town of Kenora with a population of 7,700 has its intake pipes for its water supply 5/8 of a mile below this obstacle; hence it is important that the water used about the intakes should be as clean as possible so that all septic tanks situated above the intakes, should be in good working order. The more waste matter getting into the water the more chlorine will be needed to neutralize it in any way that can have had 4 cases of Typhoid fever in the hospital since spring & that these cases are thereof innocent.
Capt. L. Edwards,
Indian Agent
Kenora.

Dear Sir:

With reference to Mr. McKenzie's letter which you showed me referring to the sewage system at the Little Norway Indian School I would like to inform you of the situation as it exists today. The septic tank was installed at this school situated on the face of a hill and was installed in an unlined manner. It had a capacity to take care of about 50 people. Since then the population at this school has increased gradually until there are about eighty people. The wash water and waste from kitchen also passed through the tank with the result that the system was carrying too big a load so there has been an overflow occurring for some time which runs down the hill into the lake. The overflow is practically raw sewage. The past winter the pipe became frozen and there they burst.
Kenora, Ontario.
July 21st, 1931.

Replying to your letter 129-1-5 of 10th inst. re sewage disposal system at the Kenora R.C. Residential School.

We would be glad therefore, if you possibly could do something immediately, when the children are on holiday, so that the School would not be closed up.

Sir,

I beg to refer to your letter of the 17th of February this year, with reference to the sewage disposal system at the R.C. Indian Residential School at Kenora.

Owing to the limited funds available this year it was hoped that the work could be postponed until some future time, but on account of the many complaints being received of the polluted condition of the water of the Lake of the Woods, it will be necessary for the Department to take action immediately, and I would ask you, therefore, to kindly instruct Mr. Gow to proceed with the necessary alterations to the sewage disposal system, as outlined in Scheme No. 1 of his report, in which it is noted that the cost will be approximately $1,600.00.

It would be well to ascertain if the Ontario government will approve of scheme No. 1, before the work is commenced.

Your obedient servant,

Duncan C. Scott Edg.
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I have just received your telegram asking me to "Kindly report what work I am doing around agency house, and not to make any arrangements without special arrangements."

I have replied by wire as follows:- "No work done at Agency except small amount of painting."

I have been calling for tenders to straighten the fence to conform with the new concrete sidewalk, laid by the town last year, and asked the following firms to tender on the work.

| Contractor                  | Amount of tender |
|-----------------------------|-----------------|
| Neely and Kimberley         | No tender       |
| Gordon Hudson               | Refused to tender |
| Bergman and Nelson          | $160.00         |
| Lindstrom and Nilson        | $90.00          |
| Conrad Swanson              | $95.00          |

Lindstrom and Nilson being the lowest tenderer, I had intended accepting their tender, after receiving authority from the Department, as this work was included in my estimates, and should have been done last fall only for the early freeze-up and snow.

I asked Mr. Hudson to tender, but he refused to do so, claiming this was not necessary as the amount was under $700.00 and that he should get the work without tender. I informed him I could not do this without getting prices from other firms. He also informed me that when we built the barn at the Kenora School a couple of years ago, he was not asked to tender, but I may say the barn was built by day labour, no tenders being called for the work, as the school assisted by supplying part of the labour.

For your private information I may say Hudson told me he should have all the Dominion Government work, as he was a supporter of the Government, but I told him I was not influenced in this way as any work we had went to the lowest tenderer, irrespective of politics, providing it was a reliable firm.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

The Principal of the Kenora R.C. School informs us that the motor of the new water pump has burned out and that a new one will cost in the neighbourhood of $75.00. The old motor could be rewound for approximately $55.00.

INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE

Kenora, Ontario.

July 31st, 1931

Sir,

Referring to your letter 12-1-31 of 9th inst., we have instructed Messrs. Melby & Co. to rebuild the Bakery chimney and a new main chimney at the Kenora R.C. School.

The old main chimney will be used as a ventilating shaft and will be much more satisfactory than using the old chimney, and meets with the approval of the Principal.

The Principal informs us that the brick work on the north west corner of the building is in bad repair and needs a few bricks and the remainder pointed, and also a little mason work done. The windows are in bad shape, the framework spreading causing a loss of heat etc.

To repair this will cost in the neighbourhood of £125.00 and we will be glad to have authority to have this work done.

The building of the chimneys is now underway, having been left over till the children were on holiday.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, August 5, 1931.

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, informing the Department that you have issued the necessary authority to rebuild the bakery chimney and a new main chimney at the Kenora Indian Residential School, and requesting authority to incur an expenditure in repairing the brickwork on the north west corner of the building and also in repairing the framework of the windows.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure not exceeding approximately $125 in the repairs to the brickwork, windows, etc.

I have also your letter of the 30th ultimo, relative to the condition of the motor of the new water pump.

In reply I have to say that the school authorities should provide the expenditure required from their per capita grant or other receipts in the purchase of a new motor or in repairing the old motor.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Frank Edwards, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kenora, Ont.
August 7, 1951.

Resuming:

MR. BURKARD,

With reference to your memo-
ram of yesterday's date, I have
to inform you that the small store-
house at the Kamora Indian Residential
School will not be erected this year.
This decision was made pursuant to
information that the funds originally
intended for a store-house would have
to be used to make necessary repairs
to the sewage disposal system at this
school.

[Signature]
Sir:

I have received your letter of the 5th instant with reference to proposed improvements to the sewage disposal system at the R.C. residential school at Kenora.

A copy of this letter has been sent to Mr. Gow and he has been asked to carry out the instructions contained therein.

I will advise you as soon as a reply is received and when money will be required.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

Per

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary,

Ottawa.

Honora, Ontario,
August, 22nd, 1931.

Dear Sir;

Inclosed please find boiler inspector Kelly's reports on boilers at the Indian Residential Schools in this agency.

We have passed on his instructions to the several schools and on Mr. Kelly's advice have instructed the Honora R.C. School Principal to purchase spare lamhole and handhole gaskets.

These are inexpensive, but we will be glad to have your approval.

We also inclose voucher for expenses for these inspections.

Your obedient servant,

Frank Edwards
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Form No. 101
Sir,

In further reference to your letter of the 6th inst., regarding proposed improvements to sewage disposal system at the R. C. Residential School at Kenora, a reply has been received from Mr. Gow regarding your request to have the improvements carried out as outlined in Scheme No. 1 of his report of January last.

Mr. Gow refers to his letter of May 9th to Mr. R. G. Orr, Departmental Architect, in which he suggested that the Indian Department should submit the proposals contained in his report of January 3rd to the Ontario Department of Health for approval before any action is taken regarding carrying out the proposed improvement. Mr. Gow repeats this suggestion and considers it advisable that the Department of Indian Affairs should deal directly with the Ontario Department of Health in securing approval of the proposed work. It seems desirable that this suggestion should be followed and it might be possible for Captain Edwards, the Indian Agent at Kenora, to arrange with Dr. Ferguson, the Medical Health Officer at Kenora, to have this approval given without undue delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. T. Johnston,
Director.

A. F. MacKenzie, Esq.,
Secretary, Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
